I love this game!

One of the most polished shooters and games I've played in a long time.

The gunplay feels amazing, learning how to push each gun's potential to it's limits is very fun, classes feel like they actually matter and attachments feel nice and solid.

I also really love the customization of things, somehow it's more satisfying to kill people with my own personalized AK15 while being dripped out.

There are some little things that bother me, like gun attachments not saving when you prestige or DMRs being annoying to fight against, but those are very minor things.

Definitelly worth the price!

Game is fun, easy to get into and hard to master. Has a small amount of realism in it that increases if you go to Hardcore servers or play in a Milsim-type group. Can always get into a game super quick and has good server-searching tools. Overall I enjoy it and would recommend. 5/7

Post 1/DEC/2023 update edit:
Nevermind. The game is getting run to the ground thanks to a braindead community that wants to remove core mechanics of the game to make it more like Battlefield/CoD. The game is good, don't get me wrong, however the community here is getting increasingly dumber by the minute, which wouldn't be a problem, but somehow these ideas get traction an eventually make it in the game.

Some of the community's ideas are:
 - remove sniper
 - remove armours and make them cosmetic
 - remove bleeding
 - add back old, crappy non reworked maps (they are in the game, this just shows community brain rot)
 - make gadgets available to all classes

Some of these ideas already made it in the game, like:
 - remove the Mario Kart like voting system (it added variety instead of having only Namak and Wakistan on Infantry)

At least this shows that the devs listen to the community, however they should draw a line before players start leaving the game (as it's already happening) because a small, loud and salty part of the playerbase is being annoying about stuff on their discord.

First FPS that I came into after being a console pleb for 20+ years, it feels like the introduction onto what to expect with FPS on console. 

Enjoying the simplistic leveling system and the wide variety of gamemodes. Too bad there isn't a tutorial because I hadn't found out about armor customization (through "Character" in the loadout screen) until after first prestige.

Extremely fun game. Easily one of the best FPS games I've ever played.

The gameplay gets somewhat monotonous at times, and I believe that is the biggest reason for the game not retaining its playerbase. One way they could possibly fix this issue is with some kind of gamemode overhaul. All of the gamemodes in rotation are the dime-a-dozen type that every FPS game has. While these gamemodes are time proven to be fun, everyone has played them many times over, and it gets boring.

The updates and balance patches are way too slow, leading to most of your deaths being by the same 3 weapons over and over. The playerbase has condensed down to only the more hardcore/enfranchised players, leading to very sweaty matches and single squads dominating the game with 95/10 K.Ds.

The only way to progress with any gun in the game as of right now, is via kills only, assists not counting, making the most efficient way to play the game being playing it like it's quake, and suicide rush enemies for quick easy kills, die, and repeat.

it can be good fun with friends, that's how I clocked in most of my hours, but do know you are signing up for a fast passed movement shooter, and NOT battlefield with more simple graphics.

Why recommend against with 100hrs+ played?

Well, it's changed a lot from launch. It seemed like the Battlefield the players wanted, not what EA execs THOUGHT we wanted.  A mix of old-school BF2 + Bad Company and a touch of 2142.  Old school classes (medic, support, recon, engie). Medic trains like it's BF2. Destructible buildings. Plenty of unlocks. $23AUD and no microtransactions.  Gameplay > Graphics. Yay, right?

However, the game has changed quite a lot. It seems unsure if it wants to be a milsim-lite or a CoD with more frenzied 127v127 servers.

-Everyone gets bandages (not just medic); at this point may as well just regen health
-Map voting changed= Enjoy playing the same map 24/7
-Community servers suck = the 2 in your region may be no grenades or no sniper - enjoy being forced to play the way others want you to. Plus, even more repetition.
-Audio is bad and if anything has got worse

-SMG+medic has remained OP for ages. No point having armour when you can just sprint 50kph, spin midair and laser folk from 100m with a SMG... 
-Assault is just worse medic; support class has 2-3 weapons in ~100 levels and is unattractive.
-Sniper has spotlight scope glint and trails added, forcing longer ranged camping at expense of mid range sniping

^Basically, class balance is bad and feels like devs either have their own favoured playstyle/ or listen only to a small circle of folks/echo chamber.

The focus seems on skins and charms rather than fixing issues and OP weapons.The game is a weird mix of too slow AND too fast gameplay.

It seems to be having an identity crisis - what sort of gameplay do they want? ...Battlebit seems to be making big changes that should have been decided BEFORE release: players are having the game changed from under them.

The game has changed a LOT since launch and in 6 months will probably be unrecognisable. 

It's not a dead game yet, but it is haemorraging steadily...

An arcady, battlefield-esque shooter that does a better job at promoting teamplay than battlefield. Who would have thunk? The game is solid on all fronts. The gunplay is smooth, the animations are fast and fluid, and the pacing is very flexible with any play style you wish to adopt (tactical or run n' gun). Although graphical fidelity may be low, the low polygon artstyle makes up with both better visual clarity and performance than 99% of the shooters I've played in these recent years. All of this combined with 254-player servers and maps that offer immense destruction and vehicles at the price of $15 USD is a steal.

BattleBit has lots of cool guns all of which are pretty pwerful and with lots of attachments and I love that there's no "pay-to-win" anything in this game and that players have to play to get guns, attachments, and some skins. 
This game is fun but kinda hard to master just because of how fast people can master the controls and the fact some players come from other games like battlefield and just go pro in mediocre skilled matches. 

  The weapon balancing needs a little bit of tweaking because some powerfull weapons are kinda usless when players mostly go for "spray and pray" guns but adding something like a drum magazine shotgun with some slow full auto would be fine and go great in the assault and engineer classes. 
Shotguns would be a good adition but I also know they'd be hard to code in and do some game balancing on them. 
I also wish that the respawn system didn't have a seizure every ten minutes though sometimes it helps that it's jank lol. 
All in all BattleBit is really fun even if it's a little jank.

After playing for a few more hours, I came to the conclusion that I cannot stand this game, no matter what.

First, BattleBit has a severe identity crisis wherein it doesn't know what it wants its gameplay to be like. Slow? Tactical? Fast? Arcadey? Who knows! There's such a jumble of features that it's really hard to tell what the devs had in mind. 

TTK is horrendously inconsistent to the point where it will make you question your sanity. I just left a game after I had put FOUR rounds into an enemy, which did NOTHING except break his armor. He then placed two rounds into me, and I was dead. Who playtests this and thinks "yeah, this is fair and balanced"? It's jarring to die in 1-2 shots only to then see 6-7 hitmarkers when shooting at a single enemy, and makes it feel as though everything is up to RNG.
Speaking of armor: for the love of all that is holy STOP PUTTING ARMOR SYSTEMS IN YOUR FPS GAMES. PLEASE. It's all so tiresome. I blame WarZone for this.

Maps feel as though they were hastily outlined in Microsoft Paint before being fully implemented into the game. There's no flow, no direction, and of course, hundreds of spots where you can be sniped/mowed-down from. They tried rectifying this by blocking off windows, but all that did was make maneuvering around a major pain in the ass. 

The proximity voice chat was a fun gimmick for all of about 10 minutes before it started being used by rancid roundfaced redditors to blast their shitty music and repeatedly yell "Allahu Akbar" whenever using the suicide vest (pinnacle of humor). I played during a few of the playtests and it honestly felt as though the proximity chat then was being used for a greater purpose, whereas now it just seems like something you can, and maybe should, ignore.

Reloading takes far too long with some weapons. Even emergency reloads feel sluggish and slow despite being, well, emergency reloads. There's zero sense of urgency with your character and it feels more like he's switching mags as he chronos his gun at an airsoft field. Considering just how fast players can move, it really exposes how janky the game feels.

Sound design is still incredibly lacking, even during intense firefights and battles. In some matches, I noticed that anything further than 30 meters away from me sounded as though it was submerged underwater. 

To further reinforce the fact that this game doesn't know what it wants to be, the devs added in squad types, which include recon, tactical, default and vehicle. I think it's perfect because it resembles just how much of a Frankenstein this game is, with all of these separate parts crudely stitched together to form... something. 

Shotguns are nowhere to be seen, and apparently this is due to one of the developer's refusal to even consider adding them in. It's pretty funny considering how much they appeal to other toxic playstyles, but see shotguns as a no-go. 

BattleBit had enormous potential when it first released, but I think much of it has been pissed away, and now it's just floating on by. Never really killed Battlefield, but sure did expose a lot of its flaws, so there's a plus.

As a player, I find BattleBit Remastered to be a delightful blend of nostalgia and innovation. It’s a multiplayer shooter that values large-scale battles over cutting-edge graphics. The game takes me back to the glory days of Battlefield, but with a unique twist - everything is made out of blocks. This Minecraft-like world adds a new dimension to the gameplay, making it unpredictable and exciting.

The game is still in early access and could use some fine-tuning. However, the 127vs127-player skirmishes are a sight to behold, especially with the destructible environments. It’s like being in the middle of a Transformers movie, with everything exploding around you. Plus, there are no microtransactions, and it doesn’t feel like a grind to get the coolest gear.

One thing I appreciate is the class balance and the open-ended map design. It allows for a lot of tactical play and keeps the matches interesting. However, the lack of a single-player campaign or a simple Deathmatch mode might be a downside for some players. The primary mode, Conquest, works well, but it would be nice to have more options.

The graphics are simple, but this allows for smooth performance even in large battles. Each of the 19 maps is geographically diverse, offering a variety of scenarios for strategic play. The destructible buildings add an extra layer of strategy, as you can literally reshape the battlefield.

In conclusion, BattleBit Remastered is a promising game that offers a lot of fun and chaos. It’s not perfect, but it’s definitely worth checking out if you’re a fan of large-scale multiplayer shooters

I like this game, but I would like to talk about what I don't like about this game. When the developers fix these things, I'll revise the review.

GAMEPLAY:
1. Why can't I respawn on a squad member?! He doesn't exchange fire with anyone for more than 10 seconds, but the game considers he's in a combat. In 90% of cases, it's easier to respawn at the base and run to the point than to wait until the game allows you to respawn on a squad member...

INTERFACE:
1. The interface looks very outdated, as if I entered the game in 2005.

GRAPHICS:
I will not scold the game for pixels, I played Unturned a lot, but ...
1. Characters. I think they should be more detailed. They look much worse than the environment and weapons.

Comments are open, I'm ready to discuss)

can't even have fun on this game anymore because of all the sweats and cheaters in almost every lobby who rack up ridiculous kill counts and then everyone else will one-hit KO you while you have to dump a mag to get any kills to register on this game.

also development has slowed down, the content is dogwater from the lack of diversity, no way of playing custom matches with friends (if those are still a thing), and then the dwindling playerbase (at least where I live) makes this game not enjoyable anymore. Even the proximity chat that this game has is particularly useless with barely anyone using it or just using it to earrape you with their bad music/meme taste. 

after ~400 hours on this game, I still do believe it's very good; no battle pass, microtransactions, over the top cosmetics that are as useless as they look (save for the gun skins, at least most of them are unlockable), or some pay2win bs that is in almost any modern multiplayer shooter. On top of that the gameplay is actually more focused towards the gunplay and not just slide cancelling every chance you get. But with the stuff I mentioned and how this game is just not fun to play casually anymore without it getting ruined by the more sweatier playerbase then it's safe to say that it was fun while it lasted. 

So no I won't be recommending this game, it's practically on life support at this point.

I once considered giving it a good review, but the problem is not the game itself, but the players.
First of all, the game itself is good, maybe a bit expensive, but it is fine. Runs fine, haven't run into any major bugs or things.
The player tho, cant really say much, I played the 256 player server for about 3 hours now, only one squad mate talks about how to push and defend. Most of the time it just like a bunch of people running from point to point, and no one put choose the squad leader load out and put down squad rally point.
Kind of like the Squad had, before the game exploded, the core is still about the squad and communication, but after a lot of new player joined who does not  listen or talk, the game kind of went dead for me.
Maybe it is a me problem where I don't have many friends to play with, causing me to not really have much fun in the game. 
BTW, toxicity is still a thing. There are just too many player in one game, meaning you can always run into one that does not brush their mouths nor have a decent family to begin with. I really feel bad for them for having to let out their toxicity online instead of finding someone to talk about their mental status.
To wrap it up, while the game shows great promise, the lack of teamwork, poor communication, and prevalent toxicity among players held it back for me. Thus the negative review, tho I kind of feel bad for the developer, but this game try to be everything at once, and I am happy that they really tried, but I think there is still a long way to go, such as making a player preference so that people that want to cooperate with each other can get into one squad, and those who just want to rush and kill can just enjoy themselves or help in a big push.
But in the end, this is just my thoughts, you knowledge may very a lot.

PS. almost forgot the grind! If you have a life, do not think about unlocking any good attachment or new guns for just hours of game play. You need to really grind for it.

//update from 2024/02/21
it has been a while, and the game is now kind of at a stable state of around 3000 player, which is no surprise to me, lower than the number of Squad or Call of Duty even lower than BF 2042 which is the game said it would take over. The player count is just low, not to say that you wont get a full server, it is just kind of said that this game's true normal state is like this.
But the community is a lot better now and nowadays there is a lot less people cursing on the server. And the grind for new weapon has been shortened. Thus the reason why I now recommend you to buy this game.

Maybe just like Palworld, this is sort of the game that blows up and than just settle down into a not-that-popular game. 
I can see there is more this kind of things happen in the future, and if you are fine with just a game that you occasionally logs on and play for a bit, this game is fine, and you should consider it.

Now for my Chinese friends:
我曾考虑给它一个好评，但问题并不在游戏本身，而在于玩家。
首先，游戏本身很好，可能有点贵，但还好。运行正常，没有遇到任何重大错误或问题。
然而，玩家方面就不好说了。我在256人服务器上玩了大约3个小时，只有一个队友会讨论如何进攻和防守。大部分时间就像一群人从一个点跑到另一个点，没有人选择队长配置并设立队伍集结点。
有点像游戏在爆发前的《战术小队》一样，核心仍然是关于小队和沟通，但是随着许多不听不说话的新玩家加入，这款游戏对我来说变得无聊了。
也许这是我的问题，因为我没有很多朋友一起玩，所以在游戏中没有太多乐趣。
顺便说一句，毒性问题仍然存在。一个游戏中有太多玩家，意味着你总会遇到那种不洗嘴巴、没有良好家庭背景的人。我真为他们感到难过，他们不得不在网上释放自己的毒性情绪，而不是找人倾诉他们的心理状态。
总之，虽然这款游戏展现出很大的潜力，但缺乏团队合作、沟通不畅和玩家之间普遍存在的毒性问题让我失望。因此，这是一个负面评价，尽管我对开发者有点愧疚，但这款游戏试图一次性满足所有需求，我很高兴他们真的尽力了，但我认为还有很长的路要走，比如制定玩家偏好，让那些想要相互合作的人能够进入同一个小队，而那些只想冲杀的人可以自己尽情享受或在大规模进攻中提供帮助。
但最后，这只是我的想法，你的观点可能会有很大不同。


补充一点，我差点忘记了这个问题！如果你有生活，千万别指望通过几个小时的游戏来解锁好的配件或新的武器。你需要非常努力去刷。

I really enjoyed this game when it first came out, but I don't feel as though it has maintained its draw.
Here are my biggest complaints:
-Weird interface things that make navigating menus frustrating and confusing
-Repetitive Gameplay
-Skill/progression gap

Regarding the interface, I find it frustrating that you can't customize your loadout unless you're in an active game. I don't understand how this game has been out so long and not made this possible. When you are in-game customizing your soldier, I find the menu confusing to navigate. I also don't like this new squad sorting feature they have added. Like other menus, I just found it confusing to understand and navigate at first. I joined a couple of games to find a bunch of tiny fragmented squads or I don't think many people really utilize it.

I think the repetitive gameplay and skill gap kind of go hand in hand for me. It's really hard to participate in the action without getting laser beamed by a really good player that has a better gun that I can't use because it's locked behind progression that I am far from unlocking. I just don't find this game very rewarding.

I am used to this kind of progression as I sank a lot of time into Battlefield 3 and 4, but for some reason this game just doesn't quite feel as good. However, battlebit is a lot better than current Battlefield offerings.

That feeling when youve been playing for an hour and a half, only to stop, then realize something.

You have spent an hour and a half of your life getting unreasonably angry at pixels on a screen.

You have spent an hour and a half of your life desperately clinging to the momentary cling of that head shot, only to have that dopamine hit immediately replaced with anger when you get killed by unreasonable odds.

You have spent an hour and a half of your life  realising which one has the most hackers or COD baby try-hards, and switch to the team just so it isn't your tenth loss in a row.

You have spent an hour and a half of your life wishing every waking moment, bargaining with devils and pleading to gods that don't exist that everyone around you would DROP DEAD so you could desecrate their corpse and eat it out of sheer spite.

You have spent an hour and a half of your life being miserable, angry, irritated and wishing unimaginable evil on someone who doesn't know your existence, nor cares to.

You realise you have wasted your time, and you must now ask a series of questions.

Why am i here?
How did I once find this fun?
Why do I hate this SO much now?
Why is everyone so... worthless now?
Why did I wish all this?

You realise it was all for nothing. You put the gun to your temple, and wonder if heaven is actually worth the effort.

TL;DR: If you like Battlefield, consider picking the game up when it is on sale.

Don't get me wrong, for what it is, BattleBit is a fun game that fans of both the Battlefield and the Call of Duty franchise will enjoy. However, this is also one of its weaknesses, since it can not decide on what it wants to be.

In addition, the game's future looks uncertain, as the game's player base has dwindled significantly in the last few months, making it hard to find populated servers during downtimes.

BattleBit Remastered, developed by Blazing Sword Studios, is a reimagining of the classic tactical shooter, BattleBit, originally released over a decade ago. This highly anticipated remaster aims to breathe new life into the beloved franchise, offering updated graphics, refined gameplay mechanics, and an expanded arsenal of weapons and equipment. As veterans of the original game eagerly return to the battlefield, and a new generation of players prepares for their first taste of tactical warfare, BattleBit Remastered promises to deliver an unforgettable gaming experience.

Gameplay Mechanics:

At its core, BattleBit Remastered retains the tactical depth and intense firefights that made its predecessor a cult classic. Players are thrust into the heart of modern warfare, where every decision can mean the difference between victory and defeat. The game offers a variety of game modes, including classic team deathmatch, capture the flag, and objective-based missions, ensuring that there's something for every type of player.

One of the standout features of BattleBit Remastered is its emphasis on realism. From realistic weapon handling and ballistics to dynamic weather effects and destructible environments, every aspect of the game is designed to immerse players in the chaos of the battlefield. Players must carefully coordinate with their teammates, utilize cover and concealment, and adapt to changing conditions if they hope to emerge victorious.

Graphics and Visuals:

Visually, BattleBit Remastered is a significant step up from its predecessor. The game boasts stunning graphics, with highly detailed character models, lifelike animations, and breathtaking environments that truly bring the battlefield to life. From sprawling urban landscapes to desolate desert outposts, each map is meticulously crafted to provide a unique and immersive gameplay experience.

The remastered version also introduces a host of new graphical features, including improved lighting effects, dynamic shadows, and advanced particle effects. Whether you're navigating the smoke-filled streets of a war-torn city or engaging in a fierce firefight under the cover of darkness, BattleBit Remastered delivers stunning visuals that rival even the biggest AAA titles on the market.

Single-Player Campaign and Multiplayer:

BattleBit Remastered offers a robust single-player campaign, with a compelling storyline that unfolds across a series of challenging missions. Players take on the role of an elite soldier tasked with combating a ruthless terrorist organization, facing off against increasingly difficult odds as they progress through the campaign.

In addition to the single-player experience, BattleBit Remastered features a robust multiplayer mode that offers endless replayability. Whether you're teaming up with friends to dominate the competition in classic game modes like team deathmatch and capture the flag, or testing your skills against players from around the world in intense online battles, the multiplayer component of BattleBit Remastered is sure to keep you coming back for more.

Community and Support:

The developers at Blazing Sword Studios have shown a strong commitment to engaging with the community, regularly providing updates, addressing player feedback, and implementing requested features. The game's dedicated modding community has also contributed to its longevity, with a steady stream of user-generated content keeping the experience fresh and exciting.

Conclusion:

BattleBit Remastered is a triumphant return to form for the beloved franchise, offering a modern take on classic tactical warfare that will satisfy both longtime fans and newcomers alike. With its immersive gameplay, stunning visuals, and robust multiplayer experience, BattleBit Remastered is a must-play for any fan of the genre. Whether you're reliving the glory days of the original game or experiencing the thrill of tactical warfare for the first time, BattleBit Remastered promises to deliver an unforgettable gaming experience that will keep you coming back for more.

This is my latest review of the game after returning from a long break.  In short: If you like COD/BF4 (not tactical gameplay), this game might be for you, if you don't mind a smaller player size at the moment.
-----------------------
I started playing this game during the beta test and bought it on day one. At the time of the game's launch, when it was popular, it was really fun and exciting. But now it has become frustrating and boring. 

First of all, the game has seen improvements to some mechanics, classes, weapons, skins and some maps. However, I don't think the vision the developers have for a semi-mil-sim game will ever work with what they currently have and the player base the game has brought in.

I apologise for my poor structuring, but I will try to explain:
* My understanding is that the developers want a semi-mil sim game that encourages teamwork and tactical gameplay. However, at this point both of these things are completely unnecessary to play the game. The whole game can be played by just running around the map and trying to get kills. You can do this because the movement is really fast, you can jump around, duck to avoid being shot, run around quickly and kill your opponent. There is no tactical gameplay, it is all about avoiding being shot in order to kill someone. The closest you get to teamwork is with the sniper squad, who usually camp together (which is also a separate problem). The best way I can sum up the gameplay is sweaty COD or BF4 metro lobbies. At the moment there are no tactical-only servers or anything, so this game is pure arcade, I can't see it becoming tactical any time soon.

Also the maps are not that good, they are too small, too big or have other problems. They are often too objective-oriented, to the point where certain objectives are just chaotic. The vehicles in the game also are terrible, the handling is awful, the mini-guns suck, etc. Audio is also a massive issue in the game right now, (it's bad). Playerbase is also kinda toxic.

I could go on nitpicking, but I don't want to write too much.

I understand that the game has like 3 devs, but the game is dying and has no clear vision that corresponds with the player base. I will check out the game in the future if the player base is not completely dead by then. Can't recommend buying the game if you are short on cash. To be honest wish the game went free to play.

Cool game for focusing on the scale of servers and destructability of the environment with some neat combined-arms gameplay, but the game lacks a significant amount of polish even months after release. To hit my major gripes:
[list][*][b]Spawning[/b] - Being able to spawn on any member of a squad turns even loosely clumped squads into a massive rat hunt. Unless you want to be killed by the same few squaddies spawning on one another repeatedly (with a very low cooldown and very generous in-combat detection), you need to pressure and hunt down squads relentlessly and fully wipe them. It also tends to trivialize the need to transport players to objectives in favor of spawn-in-shoot-guy-dead-spawn gameplay loop.
[*][b]Balance and Customization[/b] - Customiziation is annoying and clunky, and prestiging resets all of it because you have to unlock all of your weapons and armors again (but keep everything else, for some reason). This makes different loadouts an excessive amount of micromanagement. Attachments for weapons generally fall into "whichever one gives you the least recoil". Few of the other stats seem to matter for vast majority of weapons. Lots of attachments like larger magazines do counter-intuitive things like negatively affecting all of your gun's stats (including recoil, even though a heavier magazine would probably make recoil less apparent) which means unless its on a sniper rifle they're almost always flatly worse to take. For having 20-30 attachments per gun, majority of them are recycled and majority of them are not typically useful.
[*][b]General Gameplay[/b] - It hits the battlefield itch and the scale helps make things feel alive, but there's a lot of nagging issues with some areas of the gameplay. Dropping magazines when reloading, for instance, is only slightly faster and there's no way to get more magazines outside of respawning if you don't pick it up. Schizophrenic movement patterns to evade fire are extremely common, like sprinting and jumping wildly or constantly leaning left and right which still seems to be a valid strategy depsite nerfs. "Mil-sim" features like freelook are included even though freelooking is largely useless due to the game's TTK being so obscenely low that any lapse of focus usually gets you killed. Supplying ammo in the field with support is largely useless as most players don't survive long enough to need it, there's no way to get more ammo to supply outside of respawning or going back to your main base (functionally respawning, and slower), and it doesn't provide very many points. Classes outside Medic, Engineer, and Recon (assault and support) largely have no niche.
[*][b]Vehicles[/b] - Vehicles feel pretty lifeless. There's a grand total of about 8 (larger transport helicopter, smaller transport helicopter, big boat, little boat, tiny boat, IFV, Tank, and a jeep, sometimes with a gun). Factional differences are entirely cosmetic and the vehicles largely don't stand apart from one another and functionally they are identical. Aircraft can get instantly disabled by getting grazed in the tail rotor, yet for some reason the Blackhawk/KA-60 can take FIVE hits from a standard RPG-7 HEAT before getting destroyed, if its not being repaired from inside. Vehicle weapons range from laser beam (7M .50 cal turrets on jeeps) to super soaker (Transport helicopter miniguns are famously almost impossible to kill anyone with despite their volume of fire, and to boot take 5-6 hits to kill someone). There's no way to resupply lighter vehicles in the field (50 cals being resupplied by supports or drops would be cool), so light vehicles often get abandoned as soon as they are out of ammo and transporting people with them outside of accidentally doing so is worthless.
[*][b]Gamemodes[/b] - Conquest is the only real gamemode I play because the other gamemodes kind of suck. To boot, a lot of official servers force gamemodes to rotate (and the developers even made community servers force gamemode rotation until the shouting was loud enough to let it be turned off). Invasion's three-objectives-unlimited-attackers ends up in a mosh pit at each point until they eventually get overwhelmed and the allowed map area is too narrow to allow interesting flanks, on top of the timer being set to 15 minutes for each group of 3-5 objectives leading to matches that drag on excessively. Frontline has less of an issue of this since it is back-and-forth. A lot of gamemodes like 8v8 aren't really even worth mentioning. Infantry conquest is fun if the light vehicles were more reliable and less useless.
[*][b]Snipers[/b] - Snipers behind every rock, corner, every side of the map, and if you kill them once from a distance they'll reappear on another nearby sniper. They'll set up a spawn beacon back there and they can call down as many bigass boxes of supplies down as they want which even with a full squad defending a point I have never used entirely. No suppression mechanics means shooting at them without intent to kill is useless as they'll just blow your head off. Zeroing is easy and getting a rangefinder is trivial. Lots of maps have chronic sniper issues or sniper areas, usually assymetrically favoring one team over the other, often letting those snipers sit inside their base borders simply requiring someone to occupy all of their time by countersniping. Thankfully at least the game lets you build cheap sandbags to ignore most snipers from a specific angle.
[*][b]Consistent, nagging lack of polish[/b] - This is hard to nail down into one thing, but there are many small things that bother me that give of the vibe of the game being largely unfinished and developers largely overtaxed or doing other things. Menus feel clunky and frustrating to navigate. Unexpected bugs like your screen staying black if you get revived right when you try to give up and respawn. The server browser is rather awkward to use. No queueing for a server solo, but apparently you can if you're in a party. Aforementioned menu clunkiness extending to the entire lackluster loadouts system making me give up on anything but the bare essentials. All in all its a frustrating end user experience.[/list]

This game is extremely good, the weapon feedback is exquisite, it does exactly what you want and gives you perfect feedback on what you made/shot wrong. The combat is very intense and usually rewards the better player. Stuff like red dots/holos, sights, laser, night vision are made in a quite realistic way, it's so good and responsive/interactive you forget it's a boxy game. Also there is no pay to win, you unlock more weapons and loadout options as you play (level up and get kills on weapons), so it's a fair system. Skins are unlocked by doing kills on weapons and leveling up "prestige" which resets your level to 1, so you have to go through lower lvl weapons again, so it's again quite fair, gives you an opportunity to properly try out every weapon. Different weapon classes are indeed working completely differently, so you can choose between various playstyles. 

However game still needs some work, gameplay pacing seems off and frontlines are getting messy, maybe movement is a bit too fast or it's too easy to spawn on allies in your squad, so people just tend to go straight to nearest enemy spawnpoint and fighting seems to be all over the place quite often. Also when leveling up prestige, game should remember my loadout on each weapon and not reset it! Same with in-game options, game should remember them, I don't want to rebind my keys again after each reinstall. And I hate snipers, man…

Battlebit is a really fun game, love the VoIP and the gameplay is awesome. People are often very nice and fun to play with, and screaming things like "my leg!" through proximity chat when you get shot is just the icing on the cake. There's so much flexibility in the way you can play the game, it's pretty easy to do a little bit of everything. Great for playing seriously, casually, or just dicking around.

It seems like the devs are making changes most of the playerbase doesn't really like, and seeing the player count this low due to that (among other factors, such as the initial hype dying off) breaks my heart. Yeah, SMGs are kinda broken, balance is a bit wack, but I love the game a lot and I wish there were more people on to play with. I'm hyped for the next update too, and hopefully the game will see a spike in new folks on when it comes out. You can still definitely get a full 127v127 lobby here in the US pretty easily, but I'd still really like to see more players because it's teetering on the edge of death and it's a great game that I don't feel like putting down anytime soon.

If you see this and you're looking to buy the game, do it! Despite the "low player count" I've been talking about it's still very much active and you can find lobbies fast. There are usually a couple full active official lobbies here in the US, and others on community servers (which I don't often check). I'd love to see more people playing and I'm hyped for the audio and animation changes with this new update.

BattleBit Remastered initially struck me as all hype with lackluster visuals, but it quickly proved me wrong. The more I played, the more I was drawn in by its unexpectedly smooth gameplay and novel team sizes. The continuous development and surprising depth of the game are impressive, especially considering its initial appearance. It's a unique experience that's hard to find elsewhere. While I'm eager to dive back in with friends, they seem to have burned out on this style of gameplay for now. I'm hopeful that a new twist or update might rekindle our collective interest. Despite the mixed first impressions, I'd still recommend BattleBit Remastered to anyone curious, and I'm definitely open to playing it again. It's a testament to the idea that sometimes, the most rewarding experiences come from the most unexpected places.

This really hurts for me to do. When I first picked up the game and played it, it was incredible. A game that brought back the appeal of the Battlefield franchise. The community was lovely. The gameplay was fun and adaptable, and the future for this game looked bright.

But over time, things began to unravel. I think it all started when players started complaining about snipers killing them from a long distance away and being difficult to spot. You know, the very things a sniper is supposed to do?

So what did the devs do? Did they properly assess the balancing and look for fun creative ways to balance things out? No! They nerfed the snipers like no tomorrow. Suddenly, mid range scopes were giving off glint giving away their position, and then smoke trails were added to sniper bullets, ensuring that no matter what a sniper did, they would always be spotted and gunned down.

Meanwhile, running around with an SMG like a headless chicken with no regard for your team, vehicles or anything for that matter became the only viable way to play and the devs did nothing about it. Suddenly the game became appealing only to sweaty COD players and the community turned more and more toxic.

But the last straw for me was when they took a perfectly good map with different areas that appealed to different playstyles (Basra) and completely remade it into what can only be described as a cluttered mess that looks like an eight year old just randomly threw terrain and buildings around haphazardly with no regard for level design.
Of course the worst map in the game which severely limited player movement got you constantly pinned by bullets and grenades and had little to no destructible elements in its environment (Namak) remained exactly as it was.

It's a damn shame. This game had everything great going for it, but the developers destroyed it bit by bit by catering solely to the worst members of the community.

Now the game is a hollow shell of what it once was and is no better than the titles it once outshone.

I'm a big "classic" Battlefield guy. I prefer simpler big-scale combat games and I've dabbled in Mil-sim games like Arma. Don't let the graphics dissuade you, this game is incredible. I can't say enough good things about it. Thousands of potential hours of gameplay from a $15 game. The community is light hearted, the gameplay is challenging but actually fun. Solid buy, 1000% recommend. If you miss "old" Battlefield, this is the game for you.

EDIT: After a bit more time in the game, there are a few glaring flaws - No choppers/vehicles in the training area - Choppers are a commodity in live servers, they only respawn every few minutes and the amount of times you get pilots that either troll and crash them, don't know how to fly and crash them in the spawn and kill 3-12 players, or do not put down the "rope" which is required for you to exit the chopper without dying if it hasn't landed.

The rope feature is a cool thought, but a game of this scale with this type of gameplay relies on people having the knowledge to know they need to put down the rope for players to exit the chopper and also have the knowledge to know they need to fly low enough to allow players on the rope to dismount safely from the rope.

This leads me to my next gripe - no parachutes. Battlefield has them and they work well. It seems Battlebit tries very hard to stick to it's milsim roots by refusing to add features that benefit individual players over forcing them to rely on teamwork. Relying on your pilot for the rope and knowledge to both not put you down in the middle of the enemy team while you are danging on the rope or to just never put the rope down at all until you either jump out and die thinking the rope is down and not paying attention, jump out and die because you know the rope isn't down but have to respawn because the pilot is just flying you around aimlessly, or hitting the respawn button and wasting tickets on the pause menu because you can't play the game while flying around in a chopper passenger seat.

Parachutes change the dynamic and allow players to both save themselves from inept pilots and to stop relying on the terrible rope mechanic to be put down into the battlefield.

My main gripe is that they don't have choppers in the training area for players to mess around with and learn to fly properly. Players HAVE to join live servers with real players and engage in a trial by fire, that typically ends in a blackhawk full up at the beginning of the game crashing 100 meters outside of the spawn area, killing 12+ people because the person has no idea how to fly, the players can't leave the chopper because the rope isn't down because the pilot has no idea what the rope even is, then your team has no counter to the enemy team's choppers and cannot drop players onto objectives further out in the map or behind enemies because an inept pilot crashed your chopper and your team now has to wait 1/4 of the game for the chopper to respawn.

My last gripe, which is actually a big one as well is that some maps only have a single chopper or no transport choppers. Azaghor relies on your team to capture a specific objective in order for your team to get a helicopter, so one team has a chopper and the other has nothing which is a huge advantage with a skilled pilot. Azaghor already is relatively unbalanced, with the team on the East side of the map being severely disadvantaged due to the map's design. Once the Western team captures the point for the chopper and the Eastern team gets pushed back, it's a slow roll to a spawn camping hellscape that just makes you want to leave the server and find another that isn't playing that map - again, if the devs added a chopper on both teams, there would be a way for the players to leave their spawn and get to objectives that are further away to free up the spawn camping and get back into a more level playing field, but instead, the game just carries on into a spawncamp from the enemy team and everyone just spawns as a recon and snipers from inside the base. 

Frugis has the same problem, where whichever team captures G, gets a transport chopper. It's all well and good, but it means one side has a MASSIVE advantage over the other. A 12-seat transport chopper with guns that will not respawn until it's brought down which is very difficult on Frugis because of the map design and RPG mechanics with most being too low of damage or too slow. On a map like Frugis, two 8 seat little birds would be far better than a single blackhawk that gives one team a massive advantage.

There are a few maps where some of the vehicle choices don't make sense. Rather than transport choppers on Salhan for Infantry Conquest, you get two armed little birds, one on each time, rather than two passenger little birds, which would make moving around the map and keeping the game interesting easier. Instead, you just get two choppers that fly around the map basically doing nothing, maybe transporting 1-2 players the entire game while they get a few kills until they're blown up and 3-4 minutes later, the chopper spawns again. Having a passenger little bird/8 seat little bird would be preferable on this map, because many times both sides push the enemies back to the spawn and start spawn camping. Salhan is much more balanced, with multiple ways to sneak across the map on the ground, but I think the experience would be better and the round would be more fun with the ability to drop squads on far objectives and capture behind the enemy while they spawn camp.

Again, there's a lot of small nitpicks with some of the design choices. Some maps, such as Basra were changed/updated for seemingly no reason. New Basra is terrible compared to the old version. It seems rather than make new maps for people to play on, the devs insist on changing/completely overhauling maps that people like and making the old versions impossible to play. I sincerely wish they'd leave certain maps in rotation and just add the "new versions" as different maps.

Another point is the voting - at the end of each game, you vote on what you want to play. Rather than it going with what is most selected, it gives each map a percentage chance to be chosen. This is both a blessing and a curse - in some cases, the most overplayed maps like Wakistan, Frugis, etc are skipped for other maps and in other cases, the entire server could vote for a certain map, and then a map like Lonovo night with 2 votes would win out and everyone leaves the server because of it. I and many others would prefer another system where the "most selected" maps are only available every other game or two and "least selected" maps, were available every other game or two to balance the choices.

My last point would be for the devs to please stop listening to streamers and reddit communities for changes, as these groups are very small minorities of the playerbase who's playstyle/meta is not what most people who play the game want. They need to have polling on the main title screen of the game that allows players to vote on what they do/do not like for future/current changes and the devs should take the input, but never act on changes solely because players "ask for it". Devs know the design better than most players and some choices they've rolled back such as chopper XP, adding glint to 4x scopes and under, are regressive and progressive.

The games population has been steadily decreasing and sadly this is one of the best shooters available right now. If the devs could listen to more than just a few minority groups on changes and map design by allowing other players a voice via in-game polling, it could drastically help improve the game and help by deterring them from making decisions the community will overwhelmingly dislike.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 fucking minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Battle Bit is a great game, the graphics are comparable to Roblox, but the gameplay and voice chat and tangible environment is very enjoyable. Keep in mind this game was developed by 3 people if I'm right, but the point is the dev team is tiny and independent. They used to have a lot of public servers but after the initial hype the player count dipped a bit. So the dev team to cut costs cut a lot public servers. For the U.S. for example usually only has 4 public servers even during peak hours. This causes a huge issue during peak hours because the public servers are always flooded and there often no servers with any room from 6pm - 9pm. I want to say this is the perfect game but since its unplayable half the time when I have time it's not enjoyable anymore. They added custom private servers but this really didn't much to solve the issue. Private servers rarely are active unless it's the weekend, and when they are active they have toxic admins (TBG I'm callin you out). Admins will often kick you when the server is full so they can invite their friend. I really really wanted to leave a positive review for this game, but I can't. There's simply too many issues. 4/10 stars.

I do,but don't recommend. Buy at your own risk/on sale. Will update if issues get fixed in time. Steam REALLY needs a 'meh' or middle option because there's times I do say 'hell yes' to this game,and other times where I go 'hell no' to it.

MOST of the issues relate to the community,and few relate to the game itself or the mechanics.

Pros:
Weapon customization is pretty good. It's not Tarkov good. But it's good enough.
Classes
Big maps with big battles
Easy on performance,easy on the eyes,runs well.
Destructible enviroments

Cons
Sniper firing squads being too common on the big selling point(127-127 battles) and sniping being so laughably easy.
Ketamine SMG users this one is minor. You can generally get around this one fairly easy compared to the snipers being everywhere.
Weapon customizations don't mean much as you generally run the same attachements for most guns. It kind of sucks because there's clear BIS options for many guns.
Vehicles are fairly weak. Tanks don't last long.
C4 spam due to C4 being on every class.
Recon drone largely useless. It's more useful as a self destruct drone with mines or C4 attached.
Spotting is largely useless.
Not enough vehicle variety
Some of the support pack skins are largely phoned in(this is subjective and to taste)
Twitch drop skins are really cool,but no alternative way to earn them.

Onto the really bad.

Sniping isn't skillful. Play other classes until you get the rank required for the M200/L96(SV98 is also good),so that means play Medic,or Support and heal/resupply.  The community can whine,cry,stomp it's feet all it wants,but if sniping was underpowered,you wouldn't see so many snipers. You'd see the twitch ketamine fueled mobility abuse medics/assaults. 

Why do I say that? The M200 is a laser. Ranging? Not needed. Long suppressor? You can one shot easily,and every bolt can two shot. It's insanely easy to hit headshots even at 1km+ due to this. 

This means,in my opinion,the best servers are the ones that restrict the amount of snipers. This too,is an issue that's plagued many other games like Battlefield. However, Battlefield does not have snipers that have 1400ms velocity rifles.

What does this mean? There's an extremely low skill ceiling to sniping,especially once you unlock the M200/L96. While yes,the skill floor is slightly higher than the other classes,the ceiling remains much lower.

Maps fuel this problem by having so many areas that don't have adequate cover. And inb4 snipers come here crying that sniping was nerfed,DMRs got buffed and most weapons suck at range due to the attachment changes(barring other snipers,and 3ish shots from a DMR at range) snipers got away largely scott free,even factoring in the scope glint and shot trails. 

Glint does not matter. Use a 4X optic and you will not have glint problems. The sniper rifles have such good velocity(With the slowest being around 900-990ms if I recall) that you don't need a 40x optic. Vapor shot trails do not matter because if you're properly sniping,you're hitting and downing one or two targets and moving to reposition.

Now onto the SMG drop shot ketamine players.

You'll see those a lot. Not a whole lot you can do other than be ready to aim down. These are a lot more tolerable than getting plinked every time you walk out of cover/near windows. But if you learn how to aim down,these guys are pretty managable. It's when you get 30 of them at once it gets a bit crazy,but since you can get C4 on every class,start hucking C4 like it's going out of style. 


So what does this mean to you,oh prospective new player? Unlock smokes as fast as you can. If you're forced to traverse one of the many open lanes,throw smoke,and be ready to duck for cover to bandage because you will be doing that A LOT on the 127 servers.  And be ready to learn how the RPG works so  you can knock down any tall structures you find.

The vehicles GREATLY need help. You can break a tailrotor with around two to four shots from an APC. The APC makes a better mobile AA than trying to shoot it with other weapons because of this.  Miniguns feel like marshmellow shooters but machine guns on the tanks and guntrucks feel fine. 

Tanks,APCs are incredibly vulnerable to infantry due to EVERY class getting C4. Tanks are not like BF where they can get thermals,and reactive armor or so on. There's no vehicle customization unfourtantly. This is why you see tanks and APCs sitting at safe zones sniping.

Audio is inconsistantly goofy. Footsteps often are very loud,while vehicles are very quiet at times.

It's a solid 6.5-7/10 but the communtiy issues(Namely with this community being full of Great Value Brand Chris Kyle's) kind of hurt it. If you manage to scoop a server that is a bit stricter on keeping Recons/snipers in line,it's a blast. If you're not,just be prepared that the early grind sucks until you learn all their hideholes and be ready to swap to a DMR shoot them out of their campsites they will inevietably build when Engineers get tired of them and start lobbing rockets at them. Throw some more maps with better cover and routes,start restricting how many snipers you can have(or make other sniper weapons more appealing to make Recon actually use other weapons) and I think it's a pretty solid successor to the Battlefield idea.

I have read there's planned updates coming,so I'll update and review when they drop.

Embarking on my gaming journey since the early days of Battlefield 1942, I've witnessed the Battlefield series evolve, stumble, and sometimes soar. With a mix of anticipation and skepticism, I approached Battlebit Remastered, hoping for a return to the glory days of large map conquest and team strategy.

Yet, despite its promise, Battlebit Remastered falls into a familiar trap. It's a mishmash of familiar elements from other titles, offering a quick dopamine rush but lacking the staying power to keep players engaged over the long haul. The dwindling player count on Steam Charts speaks volumes, starting strong but now struggling to maintain traction.

Let's delve into the core issues plaguing the game:

Map Design: Rather than encouraging strategic play, maps often incentivize players to camp in obscure corners, racking up kills while neglecting objectives. It's less about skill and more about exploiting map flaws.

Vehicle Balance: Implementing vehicles in an infantry-centric game is tricky, and Battlebit Remastered fumbles here. Tanks dominate with impunity, sniping from afar while helicopters feel clunky and ineffective.

Player Movement: Dolphin diving and parkour mechanics undermine strategic engagements, favoring chaotic skirmishes over coordinated teamwork.

Movement Speed: Players zip around at breakneck speeds, detracting from the tactical depth the game could offer. Dialing back the pace could foster more thoughtful gameplay.

Destructible Environments: While impressive, destructible environments are excessive, often devolving matches into chaotic demolition derbies rather than strategic showdowns.

Weapon Balance: The arsenal suffers from imbalance, with certain weapons overshadowing others. The AUG, in particular, feels overpowered, disrupting the game's equilibrium.

Grenade Spam: Grenades are too abundant and wielded carelessly, disrupting the flow of gameplay with excessive explosions.

While Battlebit Remastered may find its audience, it's not the strategic conquest experience Battlefield fans yearn for. Instead, it feels like another run-of-the-mill shooter, lacking the depth and nuance of its predecessors. If you're seeking a robust strategy game, you may need to look elsewhere.

It's an absolute blast, for the most part and well worth your time. 

There's zero point in pretending you can't smell the stench of 'Battlefield' all over this, but that can't be a bad thing - especially given how badly EA are mishandling that entire franchise currently. Guns feel good, there's plenty to unlock and it takes good chunk of time to do so. Vehicles are fun, if sometimes a TINY bit unbalanced.

The maps are broadly great, with a few minor exceptions (Zalifbay, I'm talking about you - you absolute turd). The community are generally relaxed and amicable and there's almost always enough players online for you to jump into an enormous battle without delay. 

On the downside, I feel like the audio could use some work. Maybe it's the inevitable comparison to Battlefield that makes it more apparent, but the sound is a little flat on occasion. The directional audio doesn't always seem to tell the whole truth which can be a bit frustrating, however rare it may be. I've also encountered a couple of bugs, getting stuck in the spawn screen and the game locking up entirely. In fairness, this has only happened a couple of times in the 17hrs I've played. 

TLDR: Hundreds of blocky soldiers break blocky buildings and shoot each other, brain chemicals go brrrr. 8/10

This game is a true throwback to the golden age of gaming, reminiscent of the Xbox 360/PS3 era. One of the best things about it is that there are no micro-transactions to ruin your gaming experience. It's all play-to-win, and you don't need to spend a penny beyond purchasing the game. The game's combat, vehicle battles, and simple progression system are top-notch and the wide variety of maps will keep you playing for hours on end. The graphics are so simple that even your grandma's computer can handle the game. Trust me, this game is endlessly fun and you'll find yourself coming back to it time and time again.

Where is the game i felt in love with in July 2023? I'll tell you - it got completely destroyed by the incompetence of devs and their lack of idea how to run the game upon its successful release.
- Snipers, despite the nerf, are OP
- DMRs are even stronger - 2-shot kill
- Sound is trash, your teammate step are more audible than the enemy vehicle passing by
- The direction of sound is even worse
- The general 'camping' is big issue, where on every map you get shot from 100s of metres because of the kids camping in the back.
- The maps are trash, either super close combat where the SMGs obliterate you or wide open where you get shot from every direction
- Unnecessary changes from the devs which satisfy nobody - sudden nerfs of guns, grouping them into random categories, restricting the usage to classes, etc.

The game I truly loved back at the release has slowly turned into a position-based tactical shooting, where everybody digs into an elevated position (yes, windmills, towers, high building - each game there are many many people there) and just camp in the back waiting for an opponent.

Have I mentioned that vehicles do it too? Each and every game the tank is taken by some camper who decided to just stay on the rock at the back of the map and just ignore the team's call for push. 

Last, but not least, the BTR in undriveable because of the terrible driving mechanics.

Honestly, the game is a lot like Battlefield, its great if you're into a lot of try hards, and honestly this is what I observed when I played the game. It wasn't enough fun due to all of the try hards. If you're into Battlefield, this game i great, its the same thing but less graphics. But I didn't enjoy the style of the game.

tldr: game was good but now stinky because slow fix

the destruction is pretty cool but everything else falls short like wonky game play, poor balancing, and so on (and god forbid the air strafing with no learning curve in a CASUAL game)

if you're in for the voice chat function its usually desolate except for a 12 year old russian child cussing you out in hieroglyphs and no real incentive for teamwork or anything like that

its had its run and is still playable but nowhere near people's expectation as a "battlefield killer"

The game is awesome. Don't listen to other reviews where the critique the game for some random stuff. As a casual player who just plays for the fun and wants to experience the goofiness of the game i can say that it has A LOT OF potential. But as its usual with online multiplayer games the experience is ruined by tryhards who use all kind of movement exploits to make themselves harder to hit or straight up hack. I know that there will be people saying "if the game allows it why not" and i kinda agree with them. The 32v32 gamemode is super hard imo. There are people running around no-scoping you with snipers from across the map and other crazy stuff. I joined the party late in q4 2023 when the player base had started going on a decline. And even then there were some people who would use vc... wasnt that why the game was advertised by youtubers and alike. No one uses the vc as it was intended. There are mostly Russians who just curse at you or tryhards. Medics dont revive nor heal, support class players think they are unkillable and never drop ammo. You'd see squads full of snipers doing nothing. 
We cant blame the devs. Thats just how modern players are. Long gone are the days where we would explore a game for years on years and would have fun talking and playing. 
I personally dont recommend buying this game. Its unfixable. The devs cant make players play in a certain way. If you really want to buy the game get it on sale. Or just dont. Its a cool game thought its a lost cause.

This was hyped up so much before early access launch, and I think that's what makes this such a disappointing purchase to me. It feels so empty right now. As much as I love the dynamic destruction of the maps, everything else feels... Off. The shooting and the guns and what soldier customization there is, along with the gadgets and just how slow actually using them feels. Plus the maps have a lot of filler in between points, just a lot of running that I really didn't like about Battlefield 2042. (Also not being able to spawn on a point if it's contested feels kind of bad.)

Also, no shotguns, so that's -4 points from my score.

Ultimately, this is a 3/10 game. It can pull it back before launch if it improves how guns feel and how fast gadgets are equipped. Also if they add a Remington 870.

This game is quite something. 

As a fan of the "classic" Battlefield games, such as BF3 and BF4, I've been missing that simple yet fun kind of fps-game.
Battlebit reminds me of those times, as it plays very similarly, except that it has a unique flavor.

It takes some time to get used to the game, especially because of the brutal ttk, the lack of a minimap and the bunch of micro-mechanics that are hidden beneath the surface. However, once you get a couple of mates onto the game and you manage to play as a squad, this game just hooks you. 

I'm very excited where this game will be going in the future and I'll happily sink a couple more hours into it.

For its price it's a no brainer!

[h3]The better “Battlefield 3”[/h3]
Especially without the annoying "Battlelog" integration, or rather mandatory.
The game just does everything right.
Yes, graphically it cannot be compared with the top dog mentioned, BUT, it does everything else better than its idol.

[h3]It's not your fault, its mine[/h3]
I bought this title with overly romanticized thoughts of Battlefield 3.
"Battlebit" you are good enough - even more than that.
Life got in the way and I noticed it too late. So much has changed in these years.
From dudes and dudettes who are always online to those who are rarely online and usually have children around them, as is the case with me.

And to be honest, this kind of game is not for a 6-year-old. At least for now.
great game, it does take a while to get good but its fun to play either way

I enjoy playing the game , but I can't recommend a game which has inconsistent/buggy core features.
Ex:
Weapons not swapping (regardless of input)
Weapons randomly swapping (highly sensitive inputs)
Marking not working (despite making the sound indicator)
Spawning not functioning with no enemies around, or reviving (while working other times during reviving)
Spawn blocking not functioning when an ally is surrounded by enemies (resulting in spawn killing)
etc.

These are features that should be more tightly locked down and I can't understand how these issue got past testing.
I don't know another game that I've played that had this much problem with consistency on their main game features.

Update:
I'm not sure how the core mechanics got worse. It genuinely baffles me.

New Feature:
Anti-Grenade-Trophe has a 25% chance to not be placed. If you try to place it again, it will just appear. If you don't do that, it will function as though it isn't there.
Since you usually are in a rush setting it down, and a few seconds can end you, this is a really amazing feature.

Honest to god, what has happened to this game?  When this game first released people spoke to each other and it was fun.  Now, nobody speaks and you get killed by some cheater/exploiter every 20 seconds.  The DMR's are still the meta and will kill you in 2 hits regardless of your class, save the Support class, or your distance from them.  For the price, you get a decent game but my god the cheaters and exploiters are just everywhere.

Edit from here to below.

To clarify, the cheaters and exploiters are not just your simple "oh that guy killed me before I killed him he must be cheating".  When I say cheaters I mean people who, while faced away from your character, are somehow shooting you, people who pre-fire you around corners when you are prone in a bush, or even people who flick to you and instantly headshot you the second you see them run away from you out of a building.  I understand why the player count dropped.  If you don't get killed by a cheater then you encounter an exploiter who is using a broken mechanic to just wipe the floor with players.  The consistency of it all just makes the game not fun

Outstanding game which functions beautifully as a big team strategic shooter; it's basically battlefield but you could run it on a Blackberry. All the focus in development was on the moment to moment feeling of the game and they nailed it, but it does feel like it lacks something in terms of the diversity of gameplay.

I have two wishlist items, firstly to have the option for small team games. Currently I think the smallest game you can do it 32v32. I honestly would like the option for CoD style game modes with smaller teams as well as bigger grand strategy maps. Second, it would be great if you could play around with your loadout in the main game menu without having to actually join a game first.

My review of the game is that its "Meh" but steam only lets you vote positive or negative, which is so dumb. 

Yes - gunplay and potential fun
No - idiot community and developers.

Frist off, you don't loose 94% of your playerbase in the first four months of your early access period if the developers care about the state of gameplay; https://steamcharts.com/app/671860#All

Second;
-ENFORCE TEAMBALANCE AND LIMIT TEAMSWAPS!
-finding the people in a squad that you want to join is nearly impossible thanks to the ultra-basic squad & team management layout... its so basic you could almost say its non existent! You literally have to figure out what squad they are in by FINDING THEM ON THE MAP, ON TEAMS OF UP TO 127 PLAYERS, hovering over their icon ON THE MAP, then seeing if you can join the same squad WHEN YOUR DEAD. So fucking dumb.
- c4 & frags might as well be firecrackers vs infantry, they are so fucking useless!
- community is so window licking idiotic that it makes me feel like i'm playing the roblox version of battlefield.
99% of the time they won't revive fallen allies even in cover, they won't wait to be revived in cover, they just give-up and stare at a respawn timer like the morons they are. In my sixteen hours of gameplay I found one squad that wasn't trying to eat pudding with a straw, and holy shit was it glorious... just wish there were less idiots playing the game or a more straightforward way to join a squad that you know isn't going to just run in a straight line from a to b to c like fucking lemmings then bitch about "zomfg hax!" when they die to the same sniper twelve times because they have the mental capacity of a thumbtack.

other than the nearly 100% downs community, the game can be a ton of fun if you can get a squad to follow orders and use their mic once in a blue moon.


---edit---
Being *REQUIRED* to agree to an overzealous  "gotta protect the snowflakes by record your voice" agreement in order to use voice chat is fucking stupid. The possibility of being banned from a game via the developers RECORDING YOUR VOICE because some snowflake asshat can't handle hearing someone say "you stupid cunt" over the mic is so fucking gay that I don't even have the words...

I've been gaming since the early 90s, I've literally heard it all and MOVED ON, because they're just words. In this game I've heard plenty of people spamming the mic... or being annoying... all you have to do is just mute them and move on. 

They being dumb? mute em.
They being racist? mute em.
They spamming music? mute em.

You can literally solve half of your "oh no my virgin ears, I'm so offended" bullshit by clicking a few buttons, and ITS ALMOST MAGICAL how easy it is to do. The other half of the solution is to not be such an emotionally fragile little bitch, but thats on you, not me or the game.

Listen, I get that, financially speaking, a company wouldn't want to be held liable for what person A says to person B and then person B is all "boo hoo hoo my feelings, i'm such a fragile snowflake" and person A is like "well i don't give a shit those are your feelings and I have no control over them" then person B is all "well i'm going to try to sue the company since they aren't insulating me from reality with kittens and rainbows in a war game". But in reality this company is taking it WAAAAY too far with this "you must agree to be recorded anytime you open the mic channel"... I'm over here wondering about their datacenter costs for storing all the useless gigabytes of null-data when I accidentally hit the voice button when running around and all they hear is my heavy breathing.

------------
Now, Is the game itself fun? Mostly....  but then again, you have to engage with the community in order to enjoy it, and its an ocean of fucking idiots, as far as the eye can see.

It's... honestly pretty damn good. There's a lot of good to be said of BattleBit, the guns sound meaty, the destruction engine is killer, the customization is fun and unique enough. The VOIP and open comms help keep the community feeling alive and healthy. But that's honestly where my support ends. Balancing, movement, and gunplay feel inconsistent and unfun to play against.

Full disclosure. I'm a support main, always have been, always will be - Heavy in TF2, Gunner in DRG, Support in BF3/4/1, Machine Gunner and Automatic Rifleman in Squad; you name it - if it's got a belt I'll run it... and there in lies the problem. The balancing is beyond off putting for Support: just about every single gun outpaces and overshadows the Support's roster. SMGs, PDWs, Carbines outclass the all of TWO belt-fed LMGs, with the minimal recoil and higher ROF outclassing Support's weapons at medium to long ranges easily - which frankly should be occurring. The near instant TTK and rapid mobility of the opposing classes puts an impossibly slow class like Support at a massive disadvantage for speed for how much armor he's actually allotted, and for a game that relies on rapid near-run-and-gun gameplay across the other classes - it leaves players like me in the dust. Slow ADS speeds, abysmal recoil even when prone, useless bipods, agonizingly low damage at range and a max round count of a hundred leaves support feeling... milquetoast at worst and an uphill struggle at best. If I can't reliably lay down suppressive or enfilade fire, nor can I reliably run and gun with the LMGs and LSGs, why even play him? I like the game, I like to support Indie titles, but when playing feels like a chore, it doesn't make sense to play in the first place. I still recommend the game, don't get me wrong, but if you're a player like me, I'd take it with a grain of salt.

[b]Short version:[/b]
The gameplay would in theory be fun, the graphics aside most of the mechanics are decently polished, especially for such a small dev team. But since the last few weeks the proximity chat which was one of the most enjoyable parts of the game is just unused, straight up dead or full of idiots blasting music through tin can speakers challenging your ears to burst. At this point the mixture of dead community and annoyances like completely overpowered vehicles and the dead servers make it just unfun to continue.

[b]Long version:[/b]
Battlebit is a game by three people and the early sales numbers showed the amount of potential it had since it embraced a mixture of Battlefield-like gameplay and partial milsim-like realism(like the healing mechanics) with the addition of a proximity chat that produces some of the most memorable moments in gaming history.
There is just something intrinsically funny when you teammate who just ate a grenade, flies through the air while screaming from the top of his lungs like the iconic Wilhelm scream.

Sadly over the last months and seemingly especially the last weeks the voice chat seems to have completely died, being but an empty husk of what it was in the beginning. Either not a single person is using it or people are abusing your ears by playing incredibly tinny sounding and distorted music at stupid volumes forcing you to scramble and find the right F-key to mute the person amongst the action.

Gamplay trend wise these days it's mutated to a camp or rush fest. Also seemingly none of the original servers seem to be used, if you want to not be thrown in an empty server(which seems to happen literally every time you use normal matchmaking) you have to use the server browser and filter for player count and pick one of the few that are actually filled with players.

All in all:

+ Fun weapons(for the most part)
+ A unique blend of milsim and arcade like shooter mechanics
+ No micro transactions
+ Great potential

- Dead or spammed voicechat which really drags down the experience
- Finding servers is manual labor and at certain times not that easy
- Balancing issues with vehicles
- Some maps are pretty lackluster and since you are playing on non official servers many of the same maps get picked over 
   and over, meaning that it can get repetitive qickly.
- Only few gamemodes that are actually populated and fun

I could go on and on about more positive and negative aspects or talk about the graphics which are very much personal preference( I dont mind the looks but sometimes it can get a little dull). But all in all the game would be great, it just lacks community and a clear vision for what it wants to be.
I hope that the devs find a good middle ground and can save it before it all goes since the game has A LOT of potential

Edit:
A new bug has emerged where when you die you have a blackscreen even though the game still runs... it makes normal matches even more unplayable, also every Server seems to experience massive lag spikes every few minutes causing everyone to rubberband and not be able to play

Don't buy this game expecting a milsim nor something too similar to actual battlefield. The game is way more arcadey than the devs actually tell you in the steam page, with the meta being going around with an smg jumping and running.
The attachment system is also very broken, as the game has an rank system in which you get XP and levels up, unlocking new weapons and equipment, but what they don't tell you is that for attachments you need kills, for EACH weapon. So you need to spend hours upon hours just griding thousands of kills for any of the actually good attachments, again, for EACH weapon.
Also the damage system was broken after a few updates and playing the support class with heavy armor is impossible because now armor doesn't work that good and its way better to just go assault with light armor.  
Finally, theres a very clear cheater problem, mostly due to the fact that the devs are using easy anti-cheat which is a big ol joke when it comes to anti-cheating software, the nerds at reddit will say its false and that there is no cheating problem, again they are either lying, hackers themselves or just repeating what everyone else says. 
TLDR: This game tries being a milsim battlefield, ends up just being an arcade shooter with grindy mechanics, no worth the price.
