Off the top, this is the first game of the genre(s) that I've ever drilled into, so this review strictly concerns my experience of the game.

Nuts and bolts software stuff - Great for low-spec machines. I had to restart for it to run after installing on my low-spec lappy, but no issues after. Default visual settings required almost no tuning. On my PC, ran perfect after install, and zero issues ever. I don't run mods, so have had zero issues with Anti-Cheat beyond forgetting to update it. 

Gameplay - Hardcore fps pvp(one-shot kills, etc), plus huge maps are new to me. I die so much. Respawning is mostly painless and made playing feel like golf: "bah! I ****in' suck. Bottom five of standings.", yet I keep playing because occasionally surprising myself with great shots that are evidence of getting a lot better. In the case of Battle Bit, that's been busting through a wall with a hammer during a firefight, opps in the next room not hearing me with all of the other ruckus, notice their backs face a convenient wall, creep around that wall, hammer a hole, annihilate everyone without a shot a shot at me because it all happened in, like seconds. {Dopamine production skyrockets}

Development - The game is highly polished for something that's still in development and though changes always sting, I usually end up appreciating them so far and give the devs' decisions the doubt. Even the sniper rifles' medium scope nerf. I run and gun more now, and have incidentally got better at it. I know maps better for sniping it up too. Win/Win. Some will strongly disagree with me on this and that's fine.  

But yeah, I suck at this game, but still have 450+ hours in so far.

This is what you will be doing every minute you spend playing this game.  You're either walking or you are lying on the ground dead, easy prey to a person who has dedicated their entire life to their dream of becoming the greatest FPS player on Earth.

If you're among these contenders for "best FPS players in history," then happy hunting.  You *might* enjoy this game.  Not being on that list, I wouldn't know how this game is for such people.  What I do know is that the game is impossible to enjoy for any person not on that list.

Alternately, if you are sick and tired of video games being too darn fun, and just wish you could play a game that made you miserable, bored, and frustrated, this game will accomplish that task flawlessly.  If you think to yourself, "gee: I wish I could play a game where all I did was walk for two straight minutes and then lie on the ground for a while" this is it.  This is that game.  You've found it.

I can think of no other reason to play this game.

This game is a overhyped engineering miracle. They sell you good screenshots and 258 battles. But beyond that, the game is not as qualitable as it appears on first shot. 

it is overarcadicized FPS shooter which is hardcore trying to implement features from squad and battlefield that NOBODY uses AT ALL. 

It feels sad to downvote this, but unfortunately, cons overweight the pros.
Potential is wasted, and developers are creating nonsense content based on player responses which make zero sense in terms of game design. Such as designing a choice for tactical squads, default squads, tank squads or helicopter squads. None of these are used, nobody cares. score is pointless. vehicles are pointless. Voicechat is never, ever used. barricades are non existent, only i ever use them. 

FORGET teamwork, anything that focuses ingame on teamwork, is not for teamwork, but for reasons to benefit a individual players. Teams are useless. If the game had no teams, the game would play exactly the same. 

Incredibly selfish and self centered community

All people really focus on is KD ratio. Thats all that this game has to offer, that is the only and one functional part of the game that really matters. Claims that it does what battlefield doesnt are monumentally dramaticized. 

Sound design is probably a subject of change, but at this moment it is just ridiculously poor. Sounds are unpunchy, have blant atmosphere, and wont bring player into the scene. they dont create face of urgency and dont really create a faculty of a firefight for player.

Get prepared that in battlebit, lots of players will somehow just steer around corners like they see you there. They will navigate the enviroment just like they know you are at that precise spot. 
Getting shot with a low caliber SMG on 400 meters, even despite the game has quite intense recoil mechanics, is quite a norm now. DMRs are underpowered and so are sniper rifles for unambitious "game balance".

The "very positive" roundup of reviews are there due to a fact that this game bluntly challanges major AAA games like battlefield. But in the end of the day, it has to offer nothing but lack of content & downright useless, pointless features.

Go back to battlefield 3 and enjoy some serious sound design and actual firefights, instead of being pinpoint shot from half a kilometer even though you are in a position where you shouldnt be seen easily.

Battlebit has massive potential, but right now it is ridiculously underbaked and its a frustrating piece to play that will force you into run n gun for no vital reason.

The Effects of Conformity on a Society
What is the effect of conformity on a society? In the science fiction novel by Lois Lowry called The Giver, everyone lives in what is supposed to be a utopia but the sameness of it all makes living very bland and without choice or meaning.  The main character, Jonas, gets chosen to be The Receiver of Memory, which is a job where someone is given the memories of what life used to be like before the community switched to sameness. The Receiver helps the Council make important decisions that would need more life experience to decide on.  When Jonas is receiving the memories from the old receiver, also known as The Giver, he realizes how bland and meaningless conformity has made life in his society. Conformity is very restrictive because it prevents people from experiencing the ups and downs of being human and it removes their ability to make decisions for themselves.
Conformity prevents people from experiencing the ups and downs, or necessary life experiences, of being human. The first piece of evidence for this claim is when Jonas was receiving a memory of pain from The Giver, and the author wrote, ‘It was always provided in his everyday life for the bruises and wounds, for a mashed finger, a stomach ache, a skinned knee from a fall from a bike. There was always a daub of anesthetic ointment, or a pill; or in severe instances, an injection that brought complete and instantaneous deliverance’ (109). This quote connects to the claim because the author is explaining that Jonas doesn’t ever need to feel pain, which is one of the worst parts of human life. Without pain, people cant be human because its the pain and joy of life that gives people the perspective on things necessary for being a human. Another example from The Giver that supports the claim about conformity is when The Giver was giving Jonas a memory of sledding down a snowy hill, the book says, ‘“Comprehending all of those things as he sped downward, he was free to enjoy the breathless glee that overwhelmed him: the speed, the clear cold air, the total silence, the feeling of balance and excitement and peace”’ (103). This second piece of evidence explains how good Jonas felt while experiencing sledding, a very fun part of being human, and it just shows how little fun Jonas gets to experience while living conformantly. Having fun is necessary to living as a human because it is the main upside to being human and making unique decisions. Finally, the last example of how conformity prevents the ups and downs of being human is from when Jonas is receiving a very sad memory from the last receiver, the author says, ‘“Going closer, he watched them hack the tusks from a motionless elephant on the ground and haul them away, spattered with blood. He felt himself overwhelmed with a new perception of the color he knew as red”’ (126). This final quote shows Jonas learning what blood is and experiencing a different type of pain, this he will never feel and without it he can’t be fully human because he needs those experiences and feelings of pain and joy in order to make decisions.
Conformity removes people’s ability to make decisions for themselves. In the first piece of evidence from The Giver, The Giver is talking to Jonas and the book says, ‘“But they won’t want change. Life here is so orderly, so predictable- so painless. It’s what they’ve chosen”’ (130). This quote from The Giver shows that the choices of conformity have already been decided on and neither Jonas, nor anyone else, has a way to make the decision for themself. In this second example that connects with the claim, Jonas is thinking to himself about decisions, and the author writes, ‘Jonas had to stop and think it through. “If everything is the same, then there aren’t any choices! I want to wake up in the morning and decide things! A blue tunic, or a red one?”’ (123). This second quote explains how Jonas doesn’t have any choices and is just told what to do for everything in his life. In the final quote of this paragraph, Jonas is talking to The Giver, and the book says, ‘Jonas tells The Giver, “I liked the feeling of love…I wish we still had that”’ (127). This third example connects to the claim because Jonas is telling The Giver how he wishes that they still had love and he has no choice in whether or not he can love.
	Despite the good effects of conformity such as the removal of prejudice, pain, and suffering, by taking away people’s agency and their ability to experience the joys and suffering of human life, people’s lives are completely restricted. When Jonas learns about the pain of getting injured and the joy of sledding, he realizes that the ups of life greatly outweigh the bad parts. Jonas also realizes that he doesn’t get to make any real choices because The Council has made all of the decisions for him. In The Giver,  Lois Lowrey invites people to consider how these lessons may apply to their own lives and how everyone can try to push back against conformity in their lives.

"Do you remember when [i]Battlefield[/i] was actually good?"

That's the question asked at the core of [i]Battlebit[/i]'s game design.  Today, EA and Dice's [i]Battlefield[/i] is one of those bloated cultural behemoths that hasn't actually been enjoyable in over a decade, but which gamers nevertheless shill out an annual subscription cost to for the latest installment of bland, samey action to anesthetize the horrors of the 21st century.  For anyone under drinking age, that's all they'll ever remember [i]Battlefield[/i] being: the Marvel Movie of first-person shooters, a game that everybody has but nobody likes.

However, once upon a time, in the approximate six-year period between [i]Battlefield 2[/i] and [i]Battlefield Bad Company 2[/i], [i]Battlefield[/i] rocked.  It had excellent weapon variety that you could just unlock by playing the fun video game, instead of throwing dollar bills directly at the screen.  It had great map variety that could be scaled up and down to different sizes and game modes.  Later in [i]Battlefield[/i]'s golden period, it added groundbreaking destruction mechanics to those excellent and varied maps, allowing for dynamic maneuverability and strategic depth while not compromising its guns-blazing action.

[i]Battlebit[/i], produced by small 3rd-party devs SgtOkiDoki, Vilaskis, and TheLiquidHorse, takes a decidedly "if it ain't broke, don't fix it" attitude towards this brief sunspot in the fetid river of wastewater that is the contemporary AAA first-person-shooter.  It's [b]so[/b] derivative of [i]Battlefield: Bad Company 2[/i] that you might as well call it [i]Bad Company 3[/i], and that's a good thing.  The big innovations it brings to the table -- aside from its low-fi indie "[i]Roblox[/i] Chic" art style -- are massively-scaled lobbies bordering on "MMOFPS" territory and a very robust VOIP system including excellent integrated proximity chat that remains active while you bleed out.  This means that players on either team can (affectionately) trash talk across the lines at any time, which is in theory a recipe for extreme toxicity, but is in-practice (and with heavy, heavy moderation) a fun way of blowing off steam and shooting the breeze as you wait for a respawn.  My favorite players are the ones who actually roleplay out their deaths, going "oooogh, agh, ugh" with all of the pathos of an Oscar-winning actor for your benefit after you plug them.

In short, it's "Better [i]Battlefield[/i]."  If you're nostalgic for the old [i]Battlefield[/i] games, this is your new holy grail.  Have fun!

Pros:
+Visibility is ok
+Runs on old PCs too

Cons:
-Milsim mechanics
-No minimap
-No shotguns
-Snipers and flanks are an issue
-Model clipping can reveal your position
-Camping and hyper defensive gameplay is encouraged

A very bad aspect of this game is the combination of milsim mechanics and the lack of minimap. That’s because these make the game not only hostile to casual play, but also much less accessible than it could be. Regardless of server size, you will always get spotted by someone outside your FOV, and because there’s no minimap to show you the visual information of your teammates, you will get flanked a lot. As a result, you will get killed repeatedly, and be forced to face the cycle of spawn, walk a large distance, die, repeat. And since that is mentioned, walking large distances is the second worst part of the game, and vehicles don’t make the experience better at all. Since there is no minimap, you can assume you can drop from the vehicle right outside a point, which is usually where a fight should take place, but then you open the potential to get flanked, once again, because there isn’t a minimap. This paragraph is essentially pointing out the domino effect that is caused by these 2 features combined.

The agreed upon belief of the community is that this is a casual game, but that is purely based on the fact that a team has 32-127 members (on official servers), ignoring mechanics that encourage sweating such as: slow reloading (even when you drop your mag), manual healing, manual combining of mags and overall how much your decisions matter.
After an encounter with an enemy, if you win, you would need to apply bandages, reload, heal and possibly combine mags, 2-3 decisions that take time, which isn't casual.
When people thing "casual", they think "turning your brain off" or "having music in the background", which you can't really do in this game without getting stomped, because this isn't a reaction-based game, it's a decision-based game, and it's the aspect of the game I'm most mixed about.

Also, a lot of matches become a confusing mess, especially in the middle of the map, which is something a good amount of people choose to avoid by "going around" and flanking. Normally, flanking wouldn't be an issue if this game had a more reaction-based TTK, but this game has a TTK that is as close to 0 as it can be, and as a result, you won't escape dying to a flanker (in a part of the map you assumed was safe). So, never assume you're safe, even if you're in your team's territory.

Regarding TTK: It is inconsistent as heck. Some weapons are incredibly effective, but don’t get things twisted: a Vector can kill faster than a USP, even if the USP user is more skilled and only hits headshots. So, unfortunately, you have to figure out yourself which are the best weapons and attachments. And since we learn from mistakes, it’s gonna take a lot of painstaking deaths to become decent.

In FPS games, my ideal type of combat is the close quarters one, with a fairly long TTK. In this game most encounters will be mid-long range combat, with very short TTK. Your best bet at close range is using an SMG (luckily a lot of them are effective), but you won't be able to escape getting sniped easily, which is one of the worst aspects of the game (getting killed because someone decided to camp in the edge of the map or in 500m away). Even if you are underground, there are large enough areas for this to happen, and the movement won't save you from this. What can save you is, unfortunately, building mechanics... You can build short walls and cover, it's not as bad as Fortnite, but it's a mediocre mechanic nonetheless. If this game had shotguns, they wouldn’t be very useful, but they would probably infuriate the receiver in the few times they were used successfully. This would be seen as a reason not to add them (as it is the case, I assume) but the counterpoint I bring is that: Snipers are in the game, which are by far the worst types of weapons to play against, and in case you don’t know why: Sniper outranges everything, so if you know there’s a sniper somewhere, your best bet is that he won’t manage to hit you. This seems much less avoidable than getting killed from a shotgun, especially if you consider how open the maps in this game are. The biggest obstacle players have to face in order to get comfortable with the game is dealing with snipers, and even then it can still get annoying as heck. So, yeah, sniping is by far the worst part of the game...

Overall, this game is a mess. It’s a mix of casual match settings and milsim game mechanics. If you try to play the game casually, you will get flanked, and if you try to play it competitively, you will die to something that you couldn’t do something about, because of the large player amount, regardless of map/mode. And on top of every questionable design decision, the worst one is easily the existance of sniper rifles.

TL;DR: BattleBit needs a lot of maintenance to stay as good as it is now, but so long as that continues to be the case it will stand as the best indie competitor to large team shooters that has ever existed. Fun gameplay, well implemented mechanics, and an awesome community await you.

Nearly 100 hours into BattleBit, I feel confident saying that I love to hate this little gem of an FPS.

BattleBit fills the same void that Battlefield does, though in a much more charming and player-friendly way. While most of the functionality you would find in similar large-team online shooters is present, there's also a certain degree of indie game jank that, when not frustratingly inexcusable, is immensely fun and side-splittingly funny.

I think the thing that BattleBit needs more than anything right now is much more careful attention to balancing. In games like Battlefield, it never seems like a single meta has time to completely dominate the game from lobby to lobby. The emphasis on finding a soldier kit that works best for you individually is much more important.

Here, though, the game's development cycle has allowed for more time between changes that leads to a somewhat sloppy team-game experience. First it was 4x scopes on sniper rifles to mask glint, now its snipers tucking themselves away in imperceptible corners of the map geometry that the game's admittedly poor hit reg simply can't get around.

Obviously, all of this is subject to change in a game that is constantly underdevelopment, but for new players especially, I see this being a somewhat jarring experience that could scare them away. 

Outside of issues with balancing against game metas, maps are a mixed bag I feel is worth mentioning. It seems like game lobbies either have too much or not enough space for the action happening inside them. The large scale of game lobbies makes me understand why extra space needs to be available to players, but having to run obscene distances to make it to in-game objectives where there are actual things happening and not a bunch of squadmates huddling together on a roof is simply annoying.

Outside of things that I'm essentially nit-picking to find, BattleBit is insane fun. With the exception of some questionable hitreg, combat is snappy and diverse. The game's customization mechanics are well implemented and have great variety. While map design is questionable, there's a lot of variation between them. In general, everything I haven't complained about thus far is at least good, and often great.

The thing I think is most worth saying is how awesome this community is. Other shooters like CoD or Battlefield or team-based games like Overwatch (Bleh) and Counter-Strike are loaded with toxic personalities and actual hate speech. Is BattleBit totally devoid of that? No, but no online game can be. BattleBit's community, in spite of the kind of game it is and what kind of audience that tends to attract, is welcoming and fun and much more concerned with having a good time than running up your stats. To date, I have yet to hear someone go on a tirade over VOIP. What's much more common is hearing soundboards and people playing some of the most lit rock music I've ever heard as the team makes a charge onto a contested objective. It's great, and makes the gameplay feel more intense and fun by association.

So, buy BattleBit if you're tired of watching EA completely destroy the Battlefield franchise, don't want a 14 year old to call you a slur in Warzone, and actually give a hoot about the indie games industry and keeping fun gaming communities alive in the 2020's.

The gameplay is excessively fast-paced for my liking. The constant threat of being one-shot by snipers from any location and the unpredictable grenade attacks make it difficult to enjoy the game. There's a sense of frustration with instances of dying immediately upon spawning or before having a chance to retaliate. The overall chaos in the game is overwhelming, with the only positive aspect being the presence of voice chat and communication with both team and enemy players. I attempted to obtain a refund due to the lack of enjoyment, particularly disliking the night maps because of poor visibility and overly bright lights, which exacerbate the already challenging task of spotting enemies. You constantly got flanked as well with enemies shooting you in the back or from random directions. In general the game was just too overwhelming for my liking.

I used to like this game, it was really fun for a while. It was a low energy shoot-and-run-and-use-your-mic-to-tell-jokes sort of game, but it's become really clunky lately. The ping system, once used to show enemies to your teammates, is now so broken and weird to use. There's not really much community left. There's not really much else to do, other than get lost on poorly made maps and get your head blown off by someone across the map who you never saw coming. 

It's a shame, the gaming scene is crying out for a cool low effort game to sit back with that doesn't have some insane battle pass and has great customisation and this could've been it. This could've been so much more than what it is. 

Get this game if you want to try it out, but I personally doubt it'll be played much at the end of 2024 unless something drastic changes. But maybe that's okay, maybe everyone can learn something and move onto the next game. Maybe the industry will improve over time. Maybe my butt will stay juicy and ripe forever.

Feels bad.  Game sits on the cusp of a real fun time but is held back by a myriad of issues.  Armor system is poorly explained and ruins a lot of the fun.  Time to kill is inconsistent to say the least, and guns are absolutely mid.  I have had 5-8 long kill streaks using something one time, then the next I can't kill a single person.  Sure you can count this up to a "skill issue" but the time to kill on each gun varies every time you use it and not in a "the situation is different every time you use it so time to kill will always be slightly different" no in a "I have put 12 rounds into this man not hitting armor and he claps me with a bolt action rifle.  The game could be a lot of fun if there was more focus on making weapons more consistent and overhauling the armor system so you don't waste a magazine then get gangbanged by 4 Vectors that shoot faster than an MG42.  Overall can't recommend in its current state.

good, very satisfying game that is an excellent foundation for what is (hopefully) a long list of updates over the next few years. As of right now, the game is lacking a lot in content, but it is significantly better than it was on release, and with the devs planning to continue updating it, i can see it turning into a very good game in future.

The biggest issue right now is the fact it has a very dedicated player base (myself included) who absolutely dominate the leaderboards and it makes it fairly difficult for new players to enjoy the game. This "problem" is usually resolved temporarily during free weekends, streamer events, or other in game events that bring a lot of players back to try things out again, but for the most part, it's not the easiest game to enjoy casually unless you understand a lot of the games mechanics already. I don't tend to play the game super aggressively or use metas, but still manage to perform fairly well by utilising strategies and methods that other players don't typically realise is as powerful as it is.

Overall, i do recommend the game, especially for the price, but be prepared to not do well at first or get absolutely demolished by the higher level dedicated players.

Very fun game. It's got a lot of Battlefield's DNA with some simplified mechanics from Squad (bandages, construction, mags, etc.). UI could use a bit of work - the loadout menu in particular is pretty clunky - but the gunplay generally feels very good. If you've played any amount of BF4, you might be aware of that community's obsession with bad maps. That seems pretty prevalent here, too. If you were an Operation Locker fan, this game's bad maps are probably going to appeal to you. I personally prefer the larger maps with vehicles and all that (if only to pop tanks with tandem rockets).

If your heart aches for a decent Battlefield game in the vein of 3/4, I can easily recommend BattleBit.

Battlebit is a hella fun game. It has some annoying quirks but generally I think those quirks are good to have.

One things I HOPE is added is some optional server nerfs to the movement system, disable the ability to shoot during the prone, crouch and leaning animations could help without removing the parkour abilities of some super skillful players have achieved. The game feels like it’s meant to be played slowly and methodically, but the top players can fly across the map and tend to play the game call of duty style, die fast and kill faster, respawn without giving a crap about the ticket counter. The amount of times I’ve heard some scream “RUN A BLACK CAMO IS COMING” (the black camo is this hard to unlock or high rank camo, idk) is incredible, those moments are both terrifying and fucking amazing since the most experienced players genuinely control the game.

Engaging with this first-person shooter has undeniably become an unparalleled source of enjoyment, representing a zenith in my gaming endeavors over recent years. The game's minimalist graphics and streamlined mechanics harmoniously converge, culminating in a masterpiece that captivates through its simplicity while delivering an extraordinary level of engagement. This title serves as a compelling testament to the artistry inherent in game design, challenging the notion that sophistication is exclusively linked to complexity. Instead, it underscores the significance of meticulous orchestration of various elements to craft a truly memorable and immersive gaming experience. The strategic interplay of design elements within this game underscores a thoughtful balance, demonstrating how a well-executed synthesis of simplicity and depth can elevate interactive entertainment to an art form. In essence, it stands as a paradigm of excellence, inviting players into a world where refined design principles redefine the boundaries of gaming satisfaction.

I am an Apex player. The kinda of gamer that likes fast paced shooters. I come from the days of quake 2, and I am pleasantly surprised with this game. First of all, I have great hardware. Game plays flawlessly at 180 fps to 240 fps on max settings. I use frame capping software and know how to set up my system, but still impressive. You could run this and still have a playable experience on a potato.

On to the game itself. 

Very fun. A very fun war like chaos shooter. A+
It’s a great little fps game. You drop in and are on a war-like battlefield. You get to work together with your team to take down everyone else.

This game really needs a ranked mode, or some kind of leaderboard system at the very least. I initially recommended this game because it was sticking to the tried and true Battlefield formula, but now I think its time to try something new. Every time I launch this game nowadays, I start to wonder "what's even the point?" I've unlocked every weapon and gadget and now its like I have no reason to play the game anymore. An easy fix would be the addition of a ranked mode.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

This game is really over glorified over its respectable graphics and price point but the game itself is not good.

This game gets the spirit of Battlefield 3 and 4, and walks the line between arcade and mil-sim, its honestly quite amazing. 

Where they utterly drop the ball is with their Easy Anti-Cheat (EAC), it will crash your game and force your system to restart without any evidence as to why. You may play for 10 hours, or for 5 minutes, but at some point EAC will flip a switch and hard reset your PC. The community has some of their own fixes for EAC, addressing shortfalls in the system, but it is insufficient, nor should it be necessary. I was tolerating it occurring once a day, as the game is honestly that much fun that I didn't mind it. What was a final straw for me is that it made it necessary to use a restore point to regain functionality, as one forced restart caused an endless loop of restart-crash-restart.

Such a situation is unacceptable, and I therefore cannot recommend this game to anyone until that is fixed, be it EAC is fixed or another system is utilised instead. 

I want to recommend this game quite badly, especially for anyone who misses BF3 and BF4, there's a wide variety of game modes, maps, weapons, customisation, which simultaneously feel like their own while also being congruent with (and expanding upon) the Battlefield experience, its clear the developers are pouring themselves into this.  But in it's current state, I cannot recommend it.

I don't feel like the gameplay style that is shown in the trailer is really feasable within the game, at least on maps with 254 players. Do you want Call of Duty experience? Do you want military simulation? Do you want to revisit glory days of OG Battlefield?

Well, this game offers everything and nothing from above. Guns are inbalanced mess (you will headshot someone with sniper rifle, only to get 3 tapped with SMG from miles away). Vehicles like cars and roadbikes are clunky and randomly get stuck. Destruction is mess too, some walls are fully destructible, while others are not. Audio is extremely bad, so bad that when they changed it, most of the players quit the game. Skill gap is huge in this game as well, many times you get completely crushed and many times you'll crush enemy. Most of the games you will be running for 3 minutes to battle only to be sniped by someone from miles away and repeat this process. 

When the game clicks, which is like every 5-10 games, it is something magical, but with affromentioned problems, its too early to buy... WAIT UNTIL THEY FIX ALL THE ISSUES.

[b]Review has been moved off-Steam as it has gotten far too long (Links are below).[/b]
[url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/1zFN6DQd5ruTluPg7ZlKgnZvfnixi2zOucUcZEKVUOr0/edit?usp=sharing]Pros (5)[/url] / [url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/1UyhqCv9MSoia_XTApYMkriuj8VIBSjQ7ia7ALvx5SbE/edit?usp=sharing]Neutral (7)[/url]  / [url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/1haSHQ89WlkrpfADWZlw4k7mvs47sELG9QZjvCQ9dVR0/edit?usp=sharing]Cons (47)[/url]



[b]! ! ! UPDATE BASED RANT BELOW ! ! ![/b]
[i](If I care enough to waste the couple minutes of my life it takes me to type one out.)[/i]

[b]Update 2.2.4[/b]: [i]Capture Time[/i]:
Absolutely insane. 8 minutes for a solo capture? Are you serious?
I've had matches end faster than that.

On paper (In theory) the change seems fine, it promotes teamwork to capture objectives.

In reality, it just alienates solo players who used to sneak into the backlines, solo-capture an undefended objective, then either stay there until they died, taking as many opponents with them as possible, or raced off to another objective to repeat the same tactic.

Now, it's literally impossible to manage such a tactic solo, which typically means having friends on your squad follow you, because relying on randos in games like this (Any Co-Op), is a losing strategy.

I have not played in a while, so I don't know if that part of the update is actually as bad as it seems, but a 480S Solo Capture Time [b]((60 * 2) = 120 * 4 = 480)[/b] is absurd. I'd expect to be given 10K+ exp for such a massive waste of time with a very small degree of success.
You really think nobody is going to notice someone sitting on a cap for 8 minutes?
2 minutes was manageable. It could be tight under the right circumstances, but it was manageable.

[i]I was thinking of getting back into the game again seeing as I'm getting bored of the other game I was playing after dropping another 400 hours on it (Not on this account), saw that update and immediately had to rant about it a bit.[/i]

I'd gladly recommend this game. HOWEVER, read this.

I would like first to cover the good things;
The Progression feels nice.
The game runs surprisingly well.
No microtransactions.
Slight vatiety when it comes to customizability.
This game is NOT grindy, and it respects your time.
This game GREATLY rewards support roles, making kills not a primary, but more of a complementary way to gain EXP.

The bad things;
I don't know about other people, but from my perspective, I've had a ton of issues with inaccurate hirmarkers and or hitreg just now working in general. Since I had a lot of times when I hit someone 8 times, white hitmarker, basically I hit them 8 times and they still haven't died.
Bleeding shouldn't be in this game, honestly, trying to stop bleeding is more of a fkn chore than anything else. It doesn't add anything to the fight or after a fight.
BALANCING IS SO WHACK. I have no clue what the devs were thinking when balancing the weapons. First there was a massive issue with the vector, now, there's an even larger issue with the entire DMR category being busted as all hell.
Some weapons are obvisouly more OP than other guns. If your purpose is to just get kills, why use anything else other than a Groza? It MAY or CAN make other weapons redundant in general.
Some weapons have whack animations, the deagle for example has the goofiest recoil animation, and it just covers a major portion of your FOV.

[PERSONAL OPINION] Flashbangs shouldn't have those afterimages after the flash disappears. Instead of the afterimage, just prolong the flash period. It'd be less dissorienting.
[PERSONAL OPINION] No map is really good. At best, I can rank some at B tier. No map at A, and definitelly no map at S. I seriously have no clue who made these maps [Wakistan, for example], neither do I understand what thought procress they had when making them. A lot of them are too narrow, some have A LOT of angles to cover, basically making every single area a potential death trap. Visibility on some maps is non existant and et cetera. Some are way to open. And some can be a combination of all these negative characteristics.


The game is, however, AMAZING. Although, I've found my self losing my shit constantly. Probably an exclusive experience considering most of the people I play with or against are eastern europeans and they can be pretentious, a lot.

If you can ignore these issues, BUY THIS GAME. You'll still have a great time at the end of the day.

I honestly wasn't expecting to like this as much as I do.  I'm assuming that the devs got their start in Roblox based on the look and feel of this game, but that actually makes it kind of nostalgic if you used to play CoR or Phantom Forces. That said, this still very much holds up as its own "Modern Warfare" FPS. This game does everything you would expect out of an online Battlefield lobby and then some. You've got massive maps to go with massive player lobbies, vehicles, fully destructible buildings, players that take the game just seriously enough to be fun to play with, and little game play details, like having to zero scopes and keep track of your magazines, that make the game feel more like a real battlefield without making it feel less like a game.  On top of all of that, the game is $15 at full price, only like 3Gb in size, and does not need modern hardware to run. 
If you want a Battlefield game that, but don't want to give up 100+Gb of storage, or really just have any issues with the state of AAA games, this is the one to get.

Battlefield and Squad gameplay meets Roblox/Minecraft graphics.  There's some odd design choices here and there such as filling the screen with blue doritos to mark friendlies instead of having a simple minimap.  Very weird choice.   But overall the game is fairly good.

Edit: Devs throw stuff at the wall to see what sticks and don't know what they want the game to be.  It's a shame because the potential is evident otherwise

This is THE game if you want to relive those epic Battlefield Bad Company moments. Destructible environments, vehicles, squads, classes, tons of unlockables, weapon customization (both visually and mechanically), 127 vs 127 matches. It's pure mayhem and fuck me if it isn't something the gaming market needed after the MOBA and Battle Royale takeover. 

"Oh, but the hype is gone, game must be dead" no, it ain't. I've found full servers every part of the day I tried to play in my region (South America) during my one month with the game.

"It looks like Roblox" yeah whatever, the character models are a bit shitty but it also makes for very satisfying targets to shoot; it helps running the game on any potato you might have lying around as well.

This is the most fun online shooter I've played in quite some time. Give it a try, you won't be disappointed.

I've Player this game for 16 hrs now, what i can say is this game is amazing to play. Even when i started out i kept dying an didn't know what to do or where to go since I'm used to BF showing everything on the HUD. The simplified HUD makes it feel so much better since i don't have a million things on screen an can focus better, It's fun simply cause the game just feels like it has a lot of love put into it. The sounds and game play feel so intense but so calming. 1st FPS game i didn't rage at since the death chat is amazing an yelling for a medic every 5 mins is also hilarious. or the one dude running around blasting county music while we run into death. 10/10 would recommend.

Epic game, You know shits poppin off when you get rushed by literally over twenty player enemies up the stairwell and we all yelling smack at each other! Death mic is hilarious, "na stuff you we coming for yo ass!" or "save me mummy please wahhhh!" Epic fun blowing up tanks and C4 etc "Boom Brother!" Theres many shit team mates out there that wont help you "hahahah" so prepare to cry a bit, but theres normally a few legends that will help out now and then, Plus the rewards are huge, blowing up tanks with 4x dudes in it and running over to them bodies yelling "suck it tank fools"; theres nothing quite like it! This game is good and I recommend it. Game is well polished and tuned offering fast and satisfing gameplay, Think old school CoD meets Battlefield and Squad. In next part of my review I will list my complaints from perspective of a player who played on and off since launch and generaly enjoys the game while also providing constructive feedback. I give this feedback to you in order for you to understand and consider these before buying this game.

            Here are some complaints: Vehicles need physics overhaul and gameplay overhaul. In particular vehicles such as IFVs and Blackhawks need more features and buffs. Body armor feels useless except the exo armor, there is no reason to use medium, heavy or big vests and helmets. Weapons and classes are in much better state than during launch however  DMRs are overtuned and could use a nerf. Map design is for most part fine but maps like Azagor and Port are just pain. Long term progression got huge improvements but if you dont care about  weapon skins there is no reason to grind prestige levels. Guns feel ok but guns like SMGs, Snipers, Pistols ,DMRs as well as some ARs sound like wet farts. Weapon attachments could use expansion as well, Stocks, UGLs, Pistol grips and tactial devices like IR lasers and torches are still to be added as of writing of this review. these attachments could spice up the game and progresion a bit. Loadout presets are to be added as well.

BattleBit Remastered: A Blocky Battlefield!

Gameplay: BattleBit Remastered is a multiplayer first-person shooter that stands out in its genre. The game, though in early access, has shown potential for being a top-tier game.

Graphics: The game sports a unique blocky aesthetic, which adds to its charm. The simplicity of the graphics does not detract from the overall experience but adds a unique flavor to it.

Difficulty: BattleBit Remastered provides a challenging experience. With up to 254 players per server, the game ensures that the battles are always intense and engaging.

Humor: The game incorporates humor well. The destructible environments and the ensuing chaos often lead to amusing and memorable moments.

In conclusion, BattleBit Remastered is a thrilling multiplayer shooter that offers a unique and enjoyable gaming experience. It’s a game that stands out in its genre and is definitely worth a try.

The game is good, but needs a few more things eventually.



Here are my suggestions considering the way I like to play the game, and also what I've noticed would make classes feel a lot more substantial IMO:

1. An easier resupply would be nice instead of needing to manually press E by a box. I think if you stand over a box long enough, passively you should start resupplying instead of needing to take your attention away from the fight.

2. A slower resupply for gadgets would be very nice. Things like the drone are really resourceful and helpful in combat, but when it gets shot down or blows up utilizing the ability to bomb things with attached explosives.. a player needs to either wait till their next death, or forcefully re-spawn to get any further utility which also costs your team lives in the long run before you lose.

3. The Support class should be able to get the riot shield for more defensive cover, and potentially(if ever added), mortars. For one the class lacks severely in the utility department when it comes to how relevant their kit is in battle compared to something like the medic or scout, but while also applying the passive resupply and gadget resupply would be nice for making them much more useful to teammates.. playing battlefield 4, you could set up a mortar somewhere and then use it when you needed to pinch people in a hard to approach area, which was always super helpful when performing a retake on an objective.. so something like that getting added into the game would be awesome to use.

4. The riot shield should be able to be placed down for cover. Right now you cant really use it with anything besides maybe peaking a corner and backing up to gain information(which the drone does better at anyways), so having it be able to be placed down with durability would be quite nice. Also being able to shield bash would be a welcome change too.




Now that that's out of the way, here's some bugs/issues I've discovered while playing the game:


-The rappel rope from the helicopters are a bit weird to use. If you look down and hold forward you'll go down the rope, if you look up and go forward you'll go up the rope, and vice versa. This over-complicates the dropping system to leave the helicopter, so being able to simply hold forward to go up the rope and backward to go down would be really helpful in keeping it simple. 

-You can't mark vehicles very well or at all while within the drone.

-The turn speed of the drone decreasing with more weight might be a mechanic for keeping drone bombing more balanced, but I feel that the speed decrease does it just fine.. if anything, the turn speed is a minor inconvenience whilst trying to drone bomb but more-so just annoying to deal with while casually turning in general when either taking off or moving within the air. If it could be looked into more, maybe removing the turn speed change with weight would make the drone feel cleaner to use in these scenarios.

-The flashbang is a bit overwhelming, but that's not the problem. Sometimes the flash is really long and can be a bit extreme considering the pacing of the game and how much of a disadvantage you're put at(as well as the phantom freeze frame when your vision returns completely hindering your POV until it wears off), and sometimes it's just a flashlight of a blast(I've tested it with multiple scenarios whether it be directly looking at the blast, or just catching a glimpse at an angle from a distance, the difference in randomness is not much).

-The supply drop comes down quite slow and doesn't offer much that the support class already gives other than longer up-time and more uses. Keeping the ability to interact with the supply drop for instant resupply of specific gear would be very nice except with gadgets, if that change was added then instead of applying the same slow passive regen to gadgets that a support box could.. the ability for a person once per life and per supply drop to instantly get back their gadget would be decently balanced and also quite helpful in the regards of the utility to using points on a supply drop in the first place.

-Claymores are not very effective compared to Anti-Personnel mines. Instead of blunt black lines/tripwires, subtle red lasers might make them more effective in holding doors compared to mines, and though they would still be visible and could be countered.. they would still be more discreet and offer more potential to kill. 

-The repair tool has some issues when attempting to repair a vehicle like the helicopter due to it's hitbox. If you're sitting in a particular seat(such as the inside cab), even when directly looking at the ceiling or certain points inside.. the repair tool will fail to detect collision and wont repair. Sometimes it works but in a lot of cases, I find myself rotating to the outside seat on the edge to get a better angle at repairing.

-If the supports could resupply the mini-guns in the helicopter, that would be nice.




Finally, here's some ideas I have that might make the game interesting but would require some insight on balancing and also fluid utility:


1. Cameras: Being able to set a camera somewhere and have it auto-mark someone while you're on the other side of the wall would be nice for defending, but a side of this would make it break easily to explosions and also have a light shine on the model so people can more easily identify a camera(also removing any marks applied by the camera when it's destroyed). You could place a camera by throwing it at a target location to stick.

Also for more uniqueness to the gadget, you could make it similar to the drone in the regards of being able to access the camera from a screen.. but in the case you want to view the camera without pulling out your screen, you could dock the screen on a wall or the floor to stay active in combat while being able to still view the camera(and allow others to view it too). This would allow for some really nice plays where you could in real time see the position of an enemy for information to better hold an area.. or even detonate traps from the comfort of your defenses.


2. Revamping the building mechanic: I always find it interesting how a person can deploy cover using squad points.. but I find the system a bit in the way in some instances, and in a lot of cases simply spammed when bottlenecks are a problem. To give more utility to this unique aspect of the game, being able to tie this system to the tools would be very helpful in making them more prominent. I find players using explosives more often to deconstruct walls and fortifications more than the tools themselves, so adding a mechanic where players could use the tools in their loadout to create unique pre-defined defenses would make defending an objective that much more engaging.

For example: hammers and pickaxes could still do what they're meant to do breaking either in mass or in specific spots for angles, but pickaxes would be better suited and more used in scout or medic kits for constructing sniper-lookouts and tight-knit defenses, and hammers would be better for assault and support kits for creating strong and bulky sectors to suppress/block off, and approach enemies with better cover.

This in turn would simplify the building system to allow players to use construction more to their advantage in fights, instead of randomly building in an erratic manner in hopes to create defenses from a really awkward bottleneck or choke-point they're being suppressed at(while also keeping the squad point system much more relevant in the case the passive resupply is added).

Also, having a max cap of structures that just outright stops the whole squad from building is a bit momentum breaking in the case someone really likes the mechanic.. so reworking that for individual caps and to begin a decay for old structures over the cap would make it so the player can build as much as they want without overwhelming the map with too many random structures.

My feelings are a bit conflicted on Battlebit. While I do think that it improves on many aspects of the Battlefield series, it has just as many design decisions that do not address the core problem of the genre.

The addition of a server list as the first option is definitely a welcome feature that 2042 notably has absent. It is nice finding an actual server populated by people rather than pressing conquest and praying that half of the players aren’t bots. There aren’t even any bots that wander like headless chickens in Battlebit so I never have to feel good about myself getting a killstreak and get disappointed when all the names that flash up are fake. The blocky graphics make information easy to process in the face of a chaotic war. No micro transactions either beside a single skins DLC; always nice to take a page out of Deep Rock Galactic’s playbook. That’s about where the direct improvements end.

It gets a bit muddy when talking about everything else. Time to kill is incredibly fast. An assault rifle can kill someone pretty reliably even from 120 meters away and a sniper can kill from any distance given proper skill and positioning. This is great for maps where different types of weapons specialize in different areas. Tensatown for example has suburbs for the submachine gun players, many of the objectives and streets for the assault rifle, and open fields and tall rooftops for the marksman and sniper. The majority of the maps on the other hand have the objectives placed far apart with little variation in the landscape for cover and/or have the objectives themselves have an abundance of cover and vantage points. This leaves little incentive for close quarters encounters when I can just equip a long range weapon and wait for fodder to walk across a mile of nothing to get to my position. This makes the 64v64 and 32v32 mode far more enjoyable compared to 128v128.

Speaking of sniping, I feel like I never contribute anything to the team when I do it. Snipping is at its best when I get into a good flanking position and pick off a bunch of people without them spotting me. However, this usually takes time and patience to pull off which isn’t very practical in the end. Usually when sniping, the best targets to go for are the ones not moving much for easy headshots. Those targets are usually other snipers. This always leads to a cluster of snipers on both teams taking pot shots at each other while strafing and getting healed by the lone medic while everyone else is actually playing the game.

Many of these criticisms can also be applied to the Battlefield games. It’s just a shame that Battlebit’s only solution to this is add a bit of shake to the sniper.

I love the Battlefield series, specifically for its MIL-SIM-like gameplay loop, destructible environments, and selection of military vehicles to traverse the battlefield with. The last Battlefield title I played was Battlefield 1, but that was 6 years ago and the newer entries haven't intrigued me. These developers know what makes a good Battlefield game and have nailed it down with this game. 

Weapons, Accessories, and Camos are all obtained through a progression system, so NO micro-transactions in this game. They want to make squad communications a key focus, which is very welcomed, I believe that makes the game more fun. The maps come in varying size and setting, they all look great. So far, the foundation is pretty solid.

As of the time of this review, the game is still in early access, so things can and will change. I will make another review once the game leaves early access, but from what I'm playing, this game has a bright future. 

My only concern is the FaceIT anti-cheat that the developers have chosen to replace the current East Anti-Cheat with. From what I am hearing, FaceIT requires kernel-level access to a user's OS, which is EXTREME for a casual game like this. Not to mention it will prevent Linux users (like myself) from playing the game through Proton. I hope the developers keep that in mind.

UPDATE: The developers have made sure that their Anti-Cheat does not interfere with Linux players from playing multiplayer. BIG PROPS, THANK YOU.

the game is not bad but the problem is that in the current state that it is the time to kill is to long, the bullet speed/travel is to slow you need to aim a couple of meters in front of the target where they are going to move if you want to hit them and thats in close combat situations, there is a timer/delay in almost everything that you do when its a fast paced situation you can't just die and quickly go back to the action you need to wait atleast 10 seconds for the respawn timer, then you need to run to that area and by the way the maps are to big, there is no cover, no diversity in the terrain, buildings, walls and players, you have no idea if its a friendly or the enemy in front of you, you can't quickly go over to obstacles you have to jump over one wait a few seconds and then jump over the other, there is almost no good low profile colimators/1x scopes/sights, the guns do no damage and they are jumpy as hell, it's almost like the player isn't even holding the weapon it's not good at all, it reminds me of 0.13 Escape From Tarkov. To sum up guns feel horrible/gun play is horrible (alot of recoil, no damage, they are constantly changing values of the weapons instead of keeping it the way it is and maybe upgrading others that are bad and useless), timers/delays on almost everything that you do, no cover( the terrain is  flat the building are to generic, the destructibility is not bad but there is currently to much of it/ it's real easy to demolish the walls and the whole building, the player models are to generic looking (you can't distinguish a friendly from an enemy, they have the same player model). And that's bassically it i hope they fix thesse things because the game is not bad, it has a good foundation they just need to tweak a couple of things, add some things and fix some things and they have a pretty good game that actually rivals AAA Games that are 70$ and up.

Really do your research before buying,  if you allready own it

The game isn't a masterpiece like so many claim. It was good to see devs that cared about the game in an era of discarded barely functioning, should have been early access, releases, but it still died fast. Progression is a grind, and I find the game to be a little too campy. The map is fairly destructible which is fun, but it's still not any good in comparison to masterpiece it could have been with a well placed airstrike leveling the village and raking up a mountain of kills. There not much variation in gameplay vehicles are fun for a second, but there's not utility for your squad leader to call in, or anything really incentive wise calling for team play/coordination. This game really isn't that much fun, I hope it has a good future, but I'm simply not interested in it.

Some of the best, chaotic FPS gameplay.
Most parts of the map being destructible is amazing. Being in a skyscraper at night while a BTR and several people with RPGs slowly wittle away what little cover you have is certainly an experience. 
It's also very helpful. Don't wanna have to walk around a fence or find an exit through a building? Simple! Just C4 straight through it!.
The chaos of everything isn't just restricted to 127v127 maps, since most of the 32v32 servers I have joined are the same maps with most of it just sectioned off, but honestly it just makes everything feel like a meatgrinder and grenade spam simulator.
Will say, as a gun nerd, seeing a laser being mounted on the side of a pistol when it has a bottom rail RIGHT THERE, THAT WAS MODELED kinda hurts my soul, but function over form I guess, and I assume with the devs being fans of Johnathan from The Royal Armories, that they may fix this in an update.
Overall, it's a great game and I've enjoyed it extensively.

This game has lots of good going for it, but that being said there are some things that work against it. Large lobby games are very fun and hectic. You can decide weather you want to play in a casual squad or tactical giving you the ability to pick and choose your play depending on how you feel. My largest gripe with the game is it can become frustrating very fast. Poor spawn locations, or none optimized weapons lasering you from over 500 meters away. It can be hard to determine whats a skill gap and someone just utilizing the games jank factor for their benefit.

All said and done i do really enjoy this game, it scratches the same spot classic COD did for me as a kid. With a large variety in the maps and weapons its easy to swap up your play style and load out for your situation.

Honestly, I have put off writing a review for a while as I am one of the "quiet gamers," but this game is currently getting me through a tough period in my life which consists of a divorce and currently a deployment. I have not had a single bad game or quit out in all my hours of playing. You can role play, load and jump in and let your imagination take over. All weapons can be good weapons with the vast amount of play style you can adapt to over time as long as you learn the maps and proper flank routes lol, not just head into the good old meat grinder (middle of the map) all the time even if it is tempting. It reminds me a lot of the old Battlefield games like Bad Company I and II with the flow of combat and vehicles. To be under the $20.00 for this game is a steal for the amount of fun I have had and stress relief from whats going on personally. I will forever be grateful for this game.

Writing this immediately after rage-quitting from a 127 v 127 match.

At the start, during the free playtests it was fun - but not anymore. Now that people have had to shell out a whopping $15, they've decided to make this game their life's purpose, and spend hour after hour honing their skill and insta-killing anyone in sight.

But seriously, the players you'll often go against have surgical precision with their shots - often leaving you dead before you can even get a shot off or see them.

Additionally, the gunplay isn't enjoyable: seems everyone has the armor of a juggernaut while you have the armor of a peanut shell. If you're not a Medic class then you'll blow through your 5 bandages instantly (if you don't die, that is).

Spawns are a bit janky, making it not clear why you can or cannot spawn on a thing. Heck, teammates will not be in combat but you CAN'T spawn on them bc the game says they are - wtf? No!

Movement sucks. Hey, I know this is probably a skill issue on my part but everyone else can monkey around the map like they're playing Assassin's Creed while I struggle to hop a fence if I'm not tryna scale a mountain like a Skyrim horse. Additionally, enemy players look like they can slide and instantly go prone on a whim, while my character has to lay down slowly like a geriatric grandpa.

The server sizes are a bad idea. There's a reason most AAA titles don't go for larger than 32 v 32 battles - because it's ridiculously chaotic and unbalanced.
64 v 64 is okay but challenging, but 127 v 127... Holy moly that is awful. Can't go anywhere without dying instantly (as most gunbattles go)

In total, this game is unfun if you try to go for anything beyond a basic 32 v 32 shooter, and even then you'll probably get frustrated by the aimbot-iness of the enemy team.

Remember: YouTube videos only show the rare good moments, not every failure, bad moment, and death.

This game is an outrage! for 10 bucks you get a mediocre roblox-esque 1st person shooter that only exists to make you angry. I decided that I'd no longer play after getting sniped every 10 seconds in the 127v127. If you try to play the 32v32 there's no one left in the game about half way through because the losing side always leaves. Make sure to buy this game if you want to get mad for $15!

This game outdoes any other game like it and i am speaking from experience I have 134 hours and do not plan on stopping anytime soon. if you are looking for a super tactical experience this is not your game but it is still good to be in communication with team members/drivers/pilots. This game is a lot of fun with friends and the fact that you can spawn on them after being dead insures some good times. the gunplay and killsounds are superior to most iv seen the satisfaction of taking out four guys with a m249 or one single player across the map with you sniper is overwhelming the vehicles are extremely easy to start with and dropping guys off at the point in the middle of a ton of gunfire is sure to be an exhilarating experience. the last thing I would like to touch on is the matches weather its giant 127v127 games or the small 34v34 games is amazingly well done and the maps are well balanced between the teams. this is one of the games i have never wished they would add this or that my needs are always met. overall this game is so worth the forteen dollars!!

Do you like getting suspended and put under review whenever a few people or even a SINGLE guy decides to spam your account with the entire list of reports because you killed them a few times?
Do you enjoy experiencing constant errors on startup because EAC decided not to launch?
Do you love getting screwed over at random by netcode that can't seem to figure out if your shots actually hit or not?
And best of all, after all that are you a fan of getting banned by EAC with zero explanation and then gaslit by people refusing to believe the EAC implementation in this particular game is complete and utter broken garbage?

Well then this is the game is for you. You too can enjoy the intense experience of playing games that actually work while your appeal gets thrown in the trash and ignored despite containing proof of your innocence. You too can rest easy knowing you'll likely never get your money back and you'll never be able to play again even if you wanted to thanks to your very own hardware ban. 

In all seriousness Battlebit was the most fun I've had in a newer multiplayer game for a long time. It worked perfectly at first. Even the old playtests worked well. And then it all fell apart just like that. More cheaters started appearing, people discovered and starting abusing the hell out of the report option, and EAC is going rampant kicking and banning people while the devs are quietly switching to FACEIT probably as a way to avoid recognizing the problem and responsibility for it. It's a joke. They have an appeal system and apparently some people have had success with it, but nonetheless they won't tell you anything and you're expected to wait a whole month before you can be certain they threw your appeal in the trash. I've been waiting for 22 days at the time of this review and I'll update it if I'm unbanned so that others know you may not be completely screwed if EAC decides it's your turn. But either way I'm not gonna recommend a game, even a really fun one, that will just ban you at complete random. I think I've been more than patient by this point on holding off posting an angry review. I have thousands of combined hours in other games with EAC and none of them have ever been this awful with their implementations. And as if EAC wasn't invasive enough, now we're gonna get FACEIT. If they go through with that I'm not sure if I care whether or not I'm unbanned. I don't want that de facto malware on my PC. Maybe EAC did me a favor.

EDIT: It's nearly December. I was banned August 7th, and predictably I am still banned. Every single appeal has been ignored by EAC even though they would have the logs that clearly show my innocence. The mods on their Discord supposedly can't do anything, although several of them would have me unbanned if they could. EAC is a joke. Their one job is to get cheaters banned, and yet the game is still flooded with them while the ban wave wipes out a bunch of random people like me. Don't buy this game under the assumption that you'll actually be able to play it in the future. Eventually it'll be your turn.

EDIT: Mid January and I'm still banned of course. Only 4 and a half years to go until my ban lifts unless someone at EAC does their job and reviews my ban. But at this rate that'll never happen.

The game can be fun, you have to very selectively pick your maps and weapons. I had 'fun', sure, but there are better games out there that are much less of a struggle to play. I gave it a good try but it just felt too at odds with itself. It is however, one of those itch games. sadly.
The UI is eh. some bad, some good, some horrible. You'll get used to it.
The maps are okay, some are really really bad and encourage hiding on points to prevent spawns. You can only spawn at the base (safe area) if anyone is hiding on all points. It wouldn't be too bad if you could spawn near to the point and come back but unless a squadmate is there and "not under attack" you have to respawn all the way back at base and walk without getting sniped. 
Guns are unbalanced as all heck. Rifles are okay, but they are useless up close and useless at range. If you want to run and gun go for the smg, you can kill anyone with a rifle in a matter of milliseconds and bandage yourself right up. Want to snipe? Sure i guess, they give off massive trails and glints for EVERYONE. I've used sniper maybe twice and while satisfying, you're an easy easy target for anyone with aim. don't pick lmgs or any other weapon, they're garbage and will get you killed more than anything. Higher caliber bullets don't exist in this game, so if you start firing and they have a faster gun, you die before you can realize. Faster the fire rate better the gun, no matter how strong the bullets should be. Just go SMG.
Community seems really really closed off too. like worryingly so. New players are fodder. 
The last thing is kind of a feels thing. It feels zergy. You die instantly in a lot of cases, not being with the clump usually means death, you barely feel like you affect the game, there's no real "simulation" aspects that some might want. It just feels like a TDM game with capture points slapped on.

TL;DR [spoiler] The game is fun if you get to play it, but I don't think you're missing out if you skip it either [/spoiler] 

The game isn't ready yet in the current state. The gun play is fun, but that might be the only one that's going for it. Here's some of gripes that I have with the game at the time of writing

[hr][/hr] 
[h3] Shooting Range [/h3]
Shooting Range offers tutorials, but they are... pretty minimal. Of course it wouldn't matter much if you just want to hop in the game and shoot some stuff, but I feel like it's unfortunate that the tutorial isn't as extensive as the gameplay would be. The only stuff that's explained in tutorial are the stuff you have to look for, resource management, VOIP, etc. There has yet some important stuff like :
[olist]
    [*]Classes Explanation
The game doesn't explain what each of the classes' responsibilities are, weapons and gadgets available to each one of them, etc. Some of the weapons are even overlapping with each other (why would you use DMR as an Assault if you can have DMR with RPG with Engineer)

    [*]Squad Leader
The game doesn't explain much what you can do and what you should do as a squad leader, heck i don't think that many people knows that rally point is only available as a squad leader, [i]heck[/i], I don't think that many people even knows how to place them

    [*]Buildables
Yeah, the game doesn't explain how to place/build sandbags, barrier, covers, etc by spending some of the squad points. And yet, this feature could determine whether you could win the game or not. You'd have to [i]accidentally[/i] hold MMB or press O to be able to see this menu.
[/olist]

They say that the main usage of the Shooting Range is to test out guns and attachments combination, but even then, there's no easy way to switch out guns in this mode. You'd have to respawn, switch your weapon and mix some attachment, and redeploy back onto the field, only to find out that you're back at the starting place. The game also doesn't remember how you build your weapon in the normal server, so you always start with base weapon with no modifications.

[hr][/hr] 
[h3] Weapons, Attachments, Gadgets [/h3]
The game offers an abundant choice of weapons and attachments coming with them, and also gadgets that are exclusive to each of the classes, but here's some of my gripes with each one of them :

[olist]
    [*]Weapons
In most game, weapons obtainable in higher rank would be better compared to the weapons unlocked in early game, but sometime it doesn't seem to be the case in this game. Sometime a higher ranked weapon is easy to control, but the other time the recoil would make you miss all of your shots. I think this has to do more with how confusing the stat bar are. I wish there was a way to compare each one of the weapon from one to another.

This lowkey kills the purpose of unlocking a higher tier weapon. Of course, progression isn't an issue in this game (if you can find a playable server that is), but once you have a weapon that you're comfortable with, there's no real reason to play with other weapon.

    [*]Attachments
The game offers a lot of modification for your guns, from side rail, underbarrel rail, barrel, sights, etc. There's obviously stat changes for each one of the different attachments, but they also have the same problem i mentioned earlier with the weapons, higher tiered attachment isn't always better. Heck, some of the stat changes are negligible, you might as well just stick to the ones you're used to. 

Now for sights... the game doesn't even show you how it looks like when you're modifying your gun. So you better pray that it's usable when you spawn. 

I just wish each of the attachment comes with short explanation on what it does, just something like
[quote] Some sort of attachment, increases velocity but also the chance of you missing your shots [/quote]

[strike] Tell me what does S D N-6 762 do compared to V A M B-762[/strike] 

    [*]Gadgets
Some of the gadgets come with a short text to explain what they do, but some of it doesn't. Only a few weeks ago that i noticed that you can heal yourself and other people [i]with medic's gadget, not their bandage[/i], and also how the different RPGs has their own drops and confusing sights on how to shoot them. 
[/olist] 

[hr][/hr] 
[h3] QOL and some other stuff[/h3]
These are some of the infuriating stuff that I found when I played the game, that I have no other place to put : 

[list]
    [*]The game doesn't explain much about the available gamemode, to this day, If you ask me the difference between Conquest/Infantry conquest and Domination, I wouldn't know the difference. It'd be nice if the selection comes with a picture or a short explanation if you hover over them.
    [*]Speaking of game mode, some of it is just annoying/unwinnable. Capture the Flag is a mode where you steal the other team's flag and bring it back to your base. The exception is that you[i] also need [/i]your flag to be in your base to be able to get a point. And yes, the game doesn't explain it.
Invasion is a game mode where you capture a point to push your territory further and further, and most of the time, the attacking team will always win due to how long the time limit are. Of course the devs can revamp these mode to make it more balanced and more fun to play.
    [*]Switching sides is a problem in some mode, especially Invasion. I heard it's server side but when the player count becomes unbalanced, the game is just over and unfun at that point.
    [*]Server, or I guess, the player count is a problem. At least on weekdays in Asia side, the playable server is 1, you'd be lucky to get 2 server running with people with it.
[/list] 

After that long and winded explanation, I'd still recommend this game to someone else. I wanted this game to become better and I'm pretty sure it'll be when it reaches the full release. The devs got the core mechanic right and they just have to keep the player count running.

Battlefield, CoD and milsim combined

got the game cuz a lot of oldschool battlefield fans swear by this game. Having played for as long as I am willing, think they're smoking a very generous dose of copium. 
There is NO variety in what is viable. People use the same 5 guns. Seriously, I don't see much of any of the game's broad suite of weapons outside of the 2 carbines, 1 pdw, 1 sniper rifle, and 1 lmg everyone runs. Classes are more of a flavor choice, as they are very difficult to distinguish from each other, outside of just the recon class. Every other class has access to most of the weapon and gadget sandbox, with the differentiation coming from the one class specific gadget.
Support is comically worthless, with every weapon starting with 5 or more magazines and a TTK so fast that you can usually kill 4 or more guys per mag. Assault is just poor-man's engineer, so you will usually see just a mountain of medics (cuz they have self heals for days) and some engineers (cuz they have all the best explosives), with none of the assault class's dogwater chaff. Vehicles are useless for map traversal cuz you move at speeds which would put Sonic the Hedgehog to shame, and aside from that, they're so incredibly fragile that it is a death sentence to ride one. Tanks would be worthless as well, but to compensate for the inherent squishiness, they absurdly fast. I've seen the Abrams outrun a friggin atv. 

I assume a lotta people like the game so much just because it implements a lotta features bf fans have been begging for for years: helicopter rappelling, corpse dragging, combining/swapping mags... but like, the game is so fast and twitchy that you don't really care. the TTK is insane, so mag swapping or combining mags on the fly is WORTHLESS. along with that, all the weapon reload animations are so slow that when you die, its 100% of the time going to be when you chose to try and reload. seriously, it feels sometimes like there isn't a single reload animation in the game that is under 3.5-4 seconds. When you can die in 3-4 shots by a guy who just bullet-trained around the corner at mach speed, these animations standout as at odds with the design philosophy of the gunplay. You also generally don't give a heck about dragging your dead buddy around the corner to safety when you're trying hard not to get clipped instantly like him. And helicopter rappelling sounds cool, yeah, until you realize these choppers run on jet fuel and there's seemingly no limit to the amount of guys who can rappel on a line at once, so while your squads played smarter and beat back the enemy, 30 of their guys just whipped on their piece of string tied to a hyperspeed chopper out to your rear point and completely destroyed any sense of having to use tactics or being strategic to gain an edge. It feels more like an exploit than a feature. It adds further to the sense that this game is fundamentally torn between twitchy high speed shooter and traditional big team battle shooter. Choosing your packs and armor and other stuff and that having an effect on your speed and amount of throwables is cute, though. Again, darn shame these inclusions are kinda lost on a shooter that feels like you gotta be chugging Ritalin to keep up with.
The maps are dreadful. I cannot explain what it is about them, but there's very few with actual good flow. I don't have anything else to say. They're just bad.
Also, the progression is MISERABLE. It is such a grind to get to the most poop-tier stuff starting out. You have to be absolutely nose to the ground SNIFFIN like a DAWG and SWEATIN like a HOG for xp. the weekly challenges don't help, either, as they're usually such specific tasks that you have to have an iron will to commit to them, or they're just tedious "get fifty quadrillion-tillion points as (x) class"

All in all, I don't recommend this game for those out there trying to get a battlefield experience. It is clearly a game made with passion and a committed team, but it just doesn't stick the landing. there's just too much conflict between the game's many good-in-a-vacuum systems, and the TTK issues absolutely butcher it and take it from "awesome bf offshoot passion project" to "lightspeed twitch shooter, but with enormous maps." I really wanted to love this game. Ah well.
