You want to go for a tank squad? Sorry, but first, you'll need to be lucky to have a map which allows tank. Secondly, you'll have to be fast coz everyone can pick the tank, even normal squad. In which world does that make sense? And you can't buy a tank for your squad of course... and if the tank die, you'll need to wait for like 6 min to get another one.
- Infantry? Well, you might be able to have some fun at the beginning when you try to understand the game. But once you'll enter deeper in the game, you'll find that the binding are bugged. Don't try to go too fast if you want to swap weapon, medic kit, etc... sometimes it won't work, or pick something completely different. Animation are bugged as hell and you'll be blocked in the terrain / building often. Your character unable to walk on a little step forcing you to jump and thus making you vulnerable of course...
- Shooting 5 bullets on someone and not killing him with an AK47? yeah sometimes even 3 bullets in the head is not enough. You'll also encounter people exploiting, hiding in some spot where you can't touch them while being able to shoot you easily.

I could continue to enumerate things like that again and again... That's sad, really sad, cause the game has potential. But all these things make the game frustrating and raging.

Sad... better go for other games than this one...

I grew up on the old Battlefield games - BF2, 2142... BBR was fantastic on launch - a spiritual successor to classic Battlefield with massive servers and great gunplay.

The recent changes have really messed it up. Though the game doesn't have one-shot kills (except headshots) and gives you lots of tools to move in cover and concealment (loads of vehicles, smoke grenade launchers, etc.), the devs have decided to punish snipers for existing. Since rifles now draw a line in the air directly to the shooter, moving with your team, flanking, and providing mid-field spawns and overwatch is punished - your position is immediately revealed and everyone in a 100m radius shoots you. Meanwhile, camping at extreme ranges is encouraged. Shouldn't this be flipped? I feel like a grumpy old man pointing out that the Battlefield games that inspired BBR didn't do this - or even have scope glint - and snipers were balanced by careful movement and good map design. (BBR maps tend to be massive, wide-open sniper-fests connecting very dense urban areas, with little in-beetween.)

The recent sound design "overhaul" is also atrocious. Half of the time you feel like you're underwater, and enemy gunshots being louder than your teammates' really messes with your perception of the world around you.

Overall, I'm going to keep playing the game. This is because the community is generally positive (through no contribution of my own) and people actually use their mics. The gameplay is somewhat more fun than Squad and definitely faster-paced than ARMA. In fact, it's basically a Battlefield 4 reboot with a Minecraft engine. Oh, and most walls can be broken with a hammer or explosive, which is fun.

- The best weapon in the game is any belt-fed LMG with a red dot. They have minimum recoil and you can hold the trigger down indefinitely, with a moderate reload time. In fact, they kind of ruin the game; hence why I play with one. 
- Snipers are underpowered, as you need a direct face shot to kill or the helmet deflects the shot. If you hit helmet or body armor, your target escapes as you zoom out to chamber another round. Sniper battles are a battle of attrition that is won by who has the most bandages. Scopes >=5x have the shining light feature to grab people's attention. Scopes <5x have awful fish eye that makes using them suck.
- DMRs have a ton of kickback and are subject to the above scope issues and do even less damage. The only reason people use them is when snipers and DMRs are banned, because you can't disable DMRs as a class.
- SMGs and assault rifles are decent if you can handle the lack of ammo.
- Rocket launchers are maybe a bit too prevalent, as you can point them anywhere to blow up walls and people.
- Vehicles are pretty decent, but not as fun as Battlefield vehicles, even though they are modeled on the same thing. Viewing can be difficult.
- For infantry and vehicles, aiming down over a ledge or vehicle edge makes your reticle bounce all over the place. This includes drones, which can make spotting difficult.
- You can be revived any amount of times and restored to max HP, but every time you die, your bleedout time is cut in half. There SHOULD be an icon above your marker if you need a revive, because people with their volume off often walk right past a dead guy. People tend to waste the ticket if you try to pick them  up anyways.
- Spawning in on a teammate often gets you insta-killed by a hidden enemy.
- Dying often sends you through the wall or floor.
- Vaulting is nice unless you have to keep doing it to get up a straight slope or have to hump a wall until it will recognize that it is vaultable.

Every session, if I let myself bleed out all the way, I end up with a black screen. This persists into the menu and even if you somehow manage to respawn. The only solutions are to spawn and kill yourself or somehow close the game, even though you can't see other windows, either. This is a VERY annoying bug.

A seemingly related bug is that on anything larger than a 64v64 map, at any point in the battle, the game just freezes and does the black screen thing. Except, since you froze, the only thing you can do is restart your computer because you can't see other windows through the black. If you're lucky, you plug in another monitor and hit random buttons until the Task Manager moves to that screen and kill the game. This is very disruptive.

Other glitches include being able to shoot but not use any buttons besides movement buttons until respawn and my mic not working until I toggled the settings a bunch of times. People are a lot more responsive when they can hear you.
Love this game!
This game gives me PTSD.

Edited: This game has been on a downward spiral for the last 3 months.
Snipers have been nerfed into oblivion with multiple negative changes. I used to love sniping in this game and now it is completely unappealing. 
Sound audio was altered, and was horrendous. Their recent fix has made it even worse. Enemy gunfire sounds like it's right next to you, when they're 100m+ away. Makes you realize your own gunfire is a sure position giveaway.
Foot audio is absurdly loud, especially enemies now. I can hear people running/approaching too far away (some would appreciate this and abuse, however it can be disorienting)
Grapples don't work half the time, with the line stopping short and getting caught on invisible terrain.
Weekly challenges are made with unrealistic expections (200 kills with x weapon) (15 kills with a sledgehammer THAT DOESN'T REGISTER HALF THE TIME)
I took a break when invasion became the only game mode played. Now the game itself has become unenjoyable for the most part.

The graphics are a bit weird at first, but once you get over that, it's one of the best battlefield type games I've played. Basically lets you join different squad types depending on if you want milsim squad, vehicles, or just a bunch of lone wolf players. Depending on the character you play, you can also build sniper nests or FOBs, or if you prefer blowing stuff up, much of the environment is destructible. 

There's a decent amount of vehicles, and lots of weapons and customizations to get. The gunplay is great, and the server size is just massive at 127 vs 127. There's also lots of maps, some of which have night modes where everyone wears nightvision or thermals which can be hit or miss depending on if you like that or not. This said, it's easy to just leave the server whenever you feel like it, so it makes it easy to switch things up if you're not having fun in a game mode or map. There's also plenty of game modes like conquest and invasion, as well as some maps that are far more vehicle centric.

I once did a completely deranged rant of a review for halo infinite that was mostly just "I think locking cosmetics behind battle passes that make me wanna throw heavy things at fragile things after I paid for the battle pass is bad" and that still stands.

This doesn't do that to you. This feels like people who play video games made a video game, and it's good.

The gameplay itself is solid, shooting feels good, gunplay is good, feedback is good, yeah yeah yeah, but you knew that already, this is probably like your fifth positive review you've seen.

It's like a healthy mix between squad and old battlefield.

What I really want to draw your attention to is the lack of monitization and the price.  This is probably the best experience I've had with a battlefield game since bf1's beta. It's 15 dollars. You earn all your cosmetics and guns and customization through gameplay. And it's not even trying to sell you anything the entire time. I can go an entire game without having to think about how much better I would be doing if I just paid 5 dollars for the skin that gives me chameleon skin, followed by a apology a week later after they make their money off it, saying 'we didn't realize that the skin that blends in with everything would be game breaking, next one will only be in the battle pass'.

What you have here is a video game. Not a store that you paid 70 dollars to shop in.

This game will take you back to your early fps gaming days if you grew up in the 2000's. With charming graphics, intuitive gameplay and the absolute anarchy and of open mic game chat, there's a casual, no-frills approach that resonates throughout BattleBit Remastered, offering a welcome break from the complexity of modern titles and their "got ya" philosophy. Although the game is still in early access as of writing this review, BattleBit Remastered stands as a testament to the fact that greatness doesn't always require a polished, triple-A exterior. The game confidently laughs in the face of industry norms, proving that a passionate development team can deliver an exceptional fps experience without the need for excessive marketing or elaborate monetization. If you're looking for a nostalgic class based fps, I'm sure you'll enjoy this game.

 [*]Redundant squad changes that just obfuscate the squad system for no reason.

 [*]Only taking suggestions/feedback from their cesspool of a discord channel.
[/list]

"BattleBit," the indie shooter of 2023, has taken the gaming community by storm with its unexpected success. Developed by a small team of just three individuals, this game has raised the bar for indie shooters and established itself as a formidable competitor to industry giants like "Battlefield", despite its unconventional "Roblox" graphics.

While the graphics of "BattleBit" may seem simple at first glance, they provide the game with a unique visual identity. The clear lines and minimalist design contribute to a streamlined gaming environment that enhances the overall player experience. Character movements are smooth, and weapon details are surprisingly well-crafted, proving that graphics are not always the decisive factor for an immersive gaming experience. "After you played a while, your brain upgrades the graphics automatically"

The true strength of "BattleBit" lies in its innovative gameplay. The combination of fast gunfights, tactical thinking, and a variety of weapons creates a captivating gaming experience. The small development team has demonstrated that it's not just about quantity but about the quality and passion invested in the game's design.

The gaming community has enthusiastically embraced the title, appreciating the relative regular updates and the developers' commitment to player feedback. "BattleBit" has established itself as a serious contender among industry giants, showcasing that creative ideas and passionate execution are often just as crucial as a large budget.

A notable highlight is the extensive weapon customization that "BattleBit" offers. Players have the opportunity to customize their weapons down to the smallest detail, impacting not only the game's aesthetics but also providing tactical advantages. The "CamoGrind" – the pursuit of unique camouflage patterns and cosmetic upgrades – adds an additional layer to the game, motivating players to showcase their skills.

"BattleBit" exemplifies that indie games with limited resources can create exceptional gaming experiences. It is not just a game but a testament to the idea that innovation and fun gameplay are often more important than realistic graphics. Definitely a must-have for those seeking an intense shooter experience outside the mainstream, especially with the added joy of multiplayer mode and exciting weapon customizations.

Low attention span? Want to constantly be shooting? Well good news this is the fps game for you! So far I have enjoyed my experience, but I have two issues with the game. The first issue is I have had mild to moderate motion sickness from the head bobbing and I hope I can find a fix soon (I am aware of the slider in game). The other "issue" is that no one really uses proxy chat and that is just a big let down. Still, worth playing for the measly 10$ if you don't mind the childish exterior because on the inside it is a massively fun fps.

The player base now that the game isn't on sale is suddenly very different. The games are extremely sweaty and you die almost instantly upon peeking anywhere. Which leads me to my main complaint and question, WHY IS THE TTK SO FAST??? I honesty cant recommend this game anymore; the combination of the giant head hit-boxes and the .2  second TTK is just disgusting.  There is no chance to ever counter play/shoot  and it just leads to a skill-less game of who can shoot who in the back. Increase the ttk by 2x and the game would be much more casual and enjoyable.
If you miss Battlefield 3 or Battlefield 4 then is is the perfect game for you. Easily the most fun I've had with a first person shooter in years.

The review is not written by a person who plays games like BF for the first time, but by someone who has many thousands of hours in games of this genre. 

60 Hz servers in 2023
Even after the improved hit registration in patch 2.1.4 there is still a cringe: American servers with ping 112 register hits better (albeit with a delay) than European servers with ping 33.

Some 1d1ot in the dev team thought that each player, which be 250+ in one match can have 4-7 claymore mines. Having a bit of analysis and intelligence, you can imagine what problems this causes in the active gameplay.

Also, the game has a weapon modding system, which in fact does not exist. Seriously weapon mods are 95% useless. Because 95% of those mods give 1-2% advantage and take away 1-2% advantage (some take away more than they give xdd). You'll end up using 2 muzzle mods, 1 grip, and 2 sights on all weapons...

The game also uses an outdated recoil system for 10-15 years. The system when shooting takes your muzzle into the sky xd Seriously this system was relevant 15 years ago. It looks silly now... Also, with the development of macros, it is not safe in relation to the ecosystem of the game. Because any child of 8 years old can use free macros for shooting with 0 recoil.



Conclusion

Another game killed by cheaters because of a joke called EAC.

When the developers realize that EAC is a scam, a frank scam. You are being deceived, this hyped-up, hyped sh1t does not fight cheaters. They milk your wallet.
EAC should flag the cheater on all components of the pc. If a player cheats in one game then in any other game with EAC it should be auto ban. But EAC is a joke that siphons money from developers and is useless.

I'm having a really good time with this game, but it needs a lot of work.

Developers need to create a milsim or series of milsim game modes instead of having milsim squads in the same game mode as non milsim squads.

Explosions and particle effects need an upgrade. Even Roblox has better explosion effects.

Sound design needs an upgrade. None of the sound effects carry the weight or satisfaction they could, especially gunshots and explosions.

I feel like this game has the potential to be the best shooter of all time, but the developers need to keep their priorities in check if they want to keep their reputation.

In the quiet town of Eurmthy, where the sunsets painted the sky in hues of orange and pink, there existed a peculiar figure that once bore the name Adam Chan. A respected teacher in the local school, Adam was known for his gentle demeanor and passion for educating the young minds under his guidance. However, fate had a different plan for him, a plan veiled in the mysterious dust that lingered in the corners of the world.

One fateful evening, as Adam strolled through the forgotten alleys on his way home, he stumbled upon an ancient relic—an ethereal dust soul concealed in the shadows. Drawn by an inexplicable force, he reached out and touched the pulsating energy. In an instant, the soul merged with him, shrouding his being in a malevolent aura. The once warm eyes of Adam Chan turned into a haunting spectacle— one eye glowing with a menacing red hue, while the other emanated an eerie purple light.

The transformation was more than just physical; it twisted the core of his soul, warping Adam into a psychopathic entity that reveled in chaos. From that moment forward, he cast away his previous identity and embraced the name Dust Adam. The once beloved teacher became a harbinger of fear, wandering through the town's darkest corners with a copper rod as his chosen instrument of chaos.

The Blue Room, a mysterious space hidden from the prying eyes of the town's inhabitants, became Dust Adam's haunting playground. Within its walls, he engaged in sinister battles, his every move calculated and merciless. The echoes of his malevolent laughter resonated through the Blue Room, leaving a trail of apprehension in its wake.

Yet, amidst the shadows, Dust Adam found an unusual connection to Chan Her, a gifted piano player in the town. It was said that Dust Adam had the ability to manipulate time within the Blue Room, and whenever he entered its confines, the tempo of Chan Her's piano playing intensified, creating an otherworldly symphony that captivated those who dared to listen.

The townsfolk spoke in hushed whispers about the enigmatic figure that once was Adam Chan, now transformed into the malevolent force known as Dust Adam. Little did they know that his story was far from over, and the haunting melody of his existence echoed through the town, leaving a chilling legacy in its wake.

BattleBit Remastered is a game

Netcode, it feels smooth but it's behind in what it shows you. It's very obvious if you record yourself and count the hits you see hitting you vs the ones you hit an enemy with.

The characters hitbox is much larger than it seems so you get shot in the top of your head or arm when on your screen you're behind cover. 

The bandaging and bleeding gets very repetitive and annoying since you need to do it after basically every engagement.

Vehicles are underwhelming.

Weapon customization is really good but everything is just a semi or automatic rifle, it doesn't even have shotguns yet. Real magazine management is very cool to see and wish it was standard in games.

The game feels frustrating to play since there's so much potential to be battlefield but good and it's definitely better than the current battlefield games but has so many frustrating downsides right now.

If there are 127 people on one team, at least 15-25 of them will be snipers. If they are on your team they will always be useless, if they are on the enemy team they are always watching you and they will kill you in one shot.

Excessive explosives, did you play Battlefield? Do you remember Metro? Yeah, the worst map in the entire game made exclusively for lobbing explosives or sniping down massive hallways. That is what this game is, but all the time on almost every single map save like 3 perhaps. 

The game NEEDS to limit the amount of snipers allowed per squad and per team and explosives need to be dialed back a lot, not in damage, but in amount. A lot of battles end up nothing more than grenade and rpg fights while if you stick your head out for a second, don't worry, some dipshit is gonna nail you with a sniper rifle while you can't do anything with any gun you've picked.

This game suffers the same problems any large team based shooter has, it is too afraid to restrict the worst parts making the game insufferable to play through a lot of the time. There is NOTHING fun about being nailed by 1 of 20 fucking snipers on the other side who do nothing but sit in spawn or on a tower and snipe this also goes for the fact that almost every sniper is just some chud who can't actually hit anything, but decides they wanna be Elite Sniper and sit in base while you lose objectives everywhere.

The fun of 1 individual shouldn't ruin the fun of everyone else and yet it does. 

Snipers. Ruin. FPS Games. and so do excessive explosives. This is a SHOOTING GAME, not a grenade lobbing game. 

The devs need to stop being cowards and limit explosives and snipers.

Game is fun needs some balancing in certain areas, but nothing beats screaming "MEDIC" at the top of your lungs.

this game as potentail but there are things this game really needs to change. One is that this is a game that's trying to be a better battlefield. But just like battlefield this game has the most unrealistic recoil worst then battlefield 2042 where you can just hold down the trigger from over 200m out with basically any gun and kill anyone of course if your a new player you don't get this your weapon will have recoil like your guy has never shot a gun in his life. You can also shot through walls like your playing COD and kill anyone. The game has this armor you can get but not if your new so have fun shooting a player that's been playing this game for way longer because 80% of them will have this ridiculous armor. another thing i don't think we need in this game is the fact that if you have no armor you bleed. Which yes in real life if you got shot you would bleed but with being a new player and not having this armor almost everyone else has its really annoying. And finally the maps they are ok but nothing to be wowed over. Of course it does have its goods too like the amount of weapons in the game for a early access. And the fact that if a teammate is down and you cant really revive them at that spot you can drag there body to a safe place and revive them there. Another big thing is all the gun attachments that are in the game there is so many. If you feel like you could set on this game and grind it out go for it but if your looking for a game that's better then battlefield 2042 this is not it in my opinion.

If you want a better experience, get yourself a job, then get a decent PC and a copy of Battlefield 2042, you will have a far better gaming experience than this.

Dope game. It works out of the box, feels content-complete. Very responsive and snappy. For some, this game will be amazing, for others, it's nothing special. This game is the product of the state of the industry today. It's praised because it WORKS. Not because it's special.

-You pay $15.00 and get basically a full-featured battlefield game out the box, minus the graphical fidelity.

-You get a progression and leveling system that doesn't require a battlepass or separate purchase.

-The customization is awesome, and all of it is apart of the game. No buying skins or paywalls after the first purchase (though, there is one "supporter" pack that gives you skins... But that's WAY better than what any AAA game is doing now. I'm sure they'll add more "packs" as the game gets more popular though.. why wouldn't they?).

-Customization of controls is now AMAZING. This was one thing I wanted to see change, and now it has!

-Swapping weapons and switching stances can still feel a little slow, despite their efforts to buff sprint speed, healing, etc. Since last year they've made HUGE progress in fixing this though, and the game has felt better than ever before!

-Bleeding is annoying, but not as annoying as it used to be. Maybe when bleeding, you stay at 1% health instead of just dying from it.

-There needs to be a way to turn of screen shake entirely. Even with it OFF, you still get shakes. It doesn't bother me as much, but I know for some this will definitely cause motion sickness.

What other people are saying:

-Some people don't like the grind, but to be honest the grind present is so benign that I am surprised people complain compared to other waaay more grindy games. If you only play for an hour or less a day, then there's obviously no way you're going to progress significantly.. But that's with almost every game. Also, a lot of people will "main" a class instead of experimenting and changing classes based on the situation... Just try more stuff? You still unlock new attachments and cosmetics for guns if you keep to one class anyways, just like battlefield, so IDK why people are whining about it. You dont have to pay for a battlepass for progression, and to me that's a WIN.

-Some people don't like the voice monitoring to try tackling man-babies. IMO, I don't really have an issue with it anymore because literally every company and government is listening in. It shouldn't be that way, but it's not something that is gonna push me away from these devs. if you don't like that, 100% can relate, don't buy the game if that's the case, just know that SOMEONE is always listening at this point, and there's no stopping "Big Brother". If you're the type of person who likes using slurs, maybe this just isn't the game for you (and maybe you should rethink a couple things about yourself). Just sayin'.

-Some people don't like how fast paced the game can get and how good some players are. That's just the nature of ANY multiplayer game at this point, because almost everyone in the first world is online nowadays and competition is fiercer than ever before, especially because a lot of people already have FPS backgrounds. If you don't want to learn a game, that's fine, but don't expect a shooter to baby you into it- you gotta learn the game to be good at it... you can't just be good off the start.

All in all, this has become one of my FAVOURITE games of the decade, and I cannot wait to log on again to play more.

I am not the type of person to write reviews since I don't have the time to do so, but here I am writing a review for a game that I really enjoy. When I first heard of this game, I thought the following: "Oh no, another clone of a battlefield game." I didn't think too much of it because of how it looked and how the gameplay looked, but I was baffled by this game alone. It may be a blocky game, but I don't mind that at all, because I would rather play a blocky game than a game with realistic graphics that requires me to have a beefy PC to play. The gameplay core itself is a must to dive into. The combat alone is immersive enough to put hours and hours of gameplay into one sitting; the gunplay feels amazing!. The maps are just overly stunning, from the visuals of the scenery to the carnage of the players. With that being said, I do give Battlebit Remastered 10/10 on a lot of performances and will continue playing this game for hours to come.

I’ve been playing BattleBit Remastered for a few days and I have to say, it’s one of the most fun and addictive FPS games I’ve ever played. The game offers a massive multiplayer experience with up to 254 players per server, battling on huge maps with various vehicles and destructible environments. The game is inspired by the Battlefield series, but with a low-poly aesthetic that gives it a unique charm and personality.

The game has six classes to choose from, each with their own loadouts and roles. You can be a squad leader, an assault, a medic, a support, an engineer, or a recon. Each class has access to a variety of weapons and attachments that you can unlock and customize as you rank up. The game also has a proximity-based voice chat system that allows you to communicate with your teammates and enemies in real time.

The game is still in early access, but it’s already very polished and stable. The developers are very active and responsive, constantly updating the game with new features, bug fixes, and improvements. The game also has a very friendly and supportive community, with players from all over the world.

If you’re looking for a low-poly FPS game that offers a chaotic, team-oriented, and immersive gameplay, then BattleBit Remastered is the game for you. It’s a game that you can play for hours and never get bored, as every match is different and unpredictable. It’s a game that rewards skill, strategy, and teamwork, but also allows you to have fun and experiment. It’s a game that you won’t regret buying, as it’s well worth the price and will only get better with time.

I highly recommend BattleBit Remastered to anyone who loves FPS games, low-poly graphics, or just having a blast with friends and strangers. It’s a game that deserves more attention and recognition.

This game is a nice $15 novelty and not too much more than that past ~10 hours or so.  The game has a LOT of issues in it to recommend to a majority of people who are looking for a semi-long term game to play.  
First off, do expect to die a lot and often with no idea where you are being shot from.  People who are dead or prone are easily mistaken for each other.  Player visibilty is a significant problem that will come up in every match you play.
On top of this, everything comes with a side of jank.  Examples would be a lengthy prestige system with no extra unlocks to help you get back to the stuff you actually want, or the very unituitive weapon attachment and camo applying systems.  Most of the menus are also very clunky to navigate through, including spawn selection during a match.
Battlebit has many other issues that plague it. The game balance is horrid, the netcode is atrocious, and the vehicle gameplay is both uninteresting and unfun for both sides.
Hopefully this helps with setting expectations of what the game is.

The game has its good spots and then there are the things driving me nuts already for my own sanity. Little hard to see enemies it feels a bit like he who see's first kills first unless you cant shoot. I need a mini map I feel like the awareness of my surroundings and which direction I'm going in is lost. I do not even care if enemies come up on the map though it may help but more so for direction instead of constantly looking at map to figure out my location. Lots of playing time and memorizing maps would fix this but early on thoughts. Time to kill is way to fast that is one of the worst parts so far. Often I do not get much more then a glance of something and I drop dead. This leads me to think moving slow and camping wins out using sound which is pretty good. I spend most of my time putting on bandages which is boring after the first 20 "perhaps a quick pat to show I cared and a slow heal on its own". Around this stuff and getting used to the graphics its got a nice little feel. Some chatting which is better than most games going on even if its sly little remarks here or there but reminds you of the old style of bigger games when everyone could and would chat. Guns shoot pretty good compared to even way higher end games. Just goes to show the concept of aim is simple so leave it alone and stop trying to make it so creative. Does not feel like any SBMM I see people more lost than I am after a few hours of play time and those hardcore have not left the couch in months players. Once again a nice all around feel most games seem to be missing. Either way good little game something I will play a bit but not really a long term hanger for me personally. We'll see though maybe some of the better guns will tickle my pickle ;-).

After a lot more playing and getting a bit better... The SBMM is def a thing in here as I move up my lobbies get crazy  hard. Really one for one over and over. First day lots of odd ball people just standing around. Does not feel manipulated like other games but still there. Still hate no mini map hard to figure out orientation on the fly. Hit reg or servers are wierd. Some rounds feels like I'm melting others like it takes most of a mag with constant hit markers to drop a guy. Some rounds are lots of fun others are like why am I playing this game lol. Sometimes its the sbmm and other times its the hit reg while sometimes its the maps and modes. Not sure why we all want to get stuck at one junction for 30 minutes doing nothing in either direction but nading and hoping for kills. Flat maps are nice to take away from the snipers nipping at ya 24/7 from 1700 yards. Kinda annoying to drop from what feels like an aimbot headshot in some rounds constantly. Flat maps take away that sniper and make him able to only cover a smaller area instead of entire map from outside the objectives. Next update will be coming.

The game is worth a try but sadly it's being slowly killed by their own devs. I've bought this game at the release and was playing during playtests since early 2018 and i was holding a long time with this review.
On the release the game was something beautiful, battlefield but more fun and a little bit more realistic some said. And it was true. One of the things that were beautiful in this game was freedom, you could just take any class you wanted respawn wherever you wanted and just casually play the game. No rules. No stupid excluding weapons like in battlefield games with most servers. And most importantly every class had it's own purpose with their pros and cons. Unfortunately from update to update game had become worse and worse to the state where it's simply lost it's charm. Now when joining game you are asked on what squad would you like to join and that is restricted with rules like sniper squad or tank squad. Last sound update makes guns sound worse than most of the 2000 games. In one update the community servers were added and it was a good move but sadly some of them have strict rules and most of them awful moderators (those are also on official servers). And finally balancing in this game is just a joke and clearly devs aren't listening to the players who are constantly playing the game and have some hours and know what's happening in the game but instead to the people coming from the hype and free weekends. It's just sad to see a great game like this being slowly killed :(

It's alright but the variety is lackluster due to what gamemodes and maps being played in public servers being the most voted on maps. It's extremely rare to play anything but Conquest (which is arguably the worst game mode, especially compared to the superior Frontline) and a few maps all during the day. The lack of variety and relatively low speed at which you unlock new things (new guns most notably) make the game tedious at times. While new gun unlocks are slow, many of the weapons are not good and are vastly inferior to other weapons, making weapon choice stylistic over functional which kinda sucks. Class balance and class variety is also very bad, with most people just playing medic or engineer because medics are the only class that can heal and engineers get RPG's which are the best tool for getting kills and basically the only thing that can destroy vehicles and buildings without getting right next to them with C4. Often it's difficult to tell what can or can't be destroyed, and many destructible walls have non-destructible walls behind them. That being said there is quite a bit of fun to be had, it captures that peak Planetside 2 energy for me. 7/10

Edit: One year later and all the problems the game had at launch still exist and to an extent are exacerbated. There's more maps, only a few are every actually played, so map variety might as well not exist. There's more gamemodes, but the only mode anyone votes on is Conquest, so every other mode might as well not exist. There's more guns, only 3-4 guns are actually used because they are objectively better and, therefore, the variety might as well not exist. Vehicles and explosives are still BiS and point farms. The leveling is slightly faster and easier than before. They expanded the usage of bandages for the other classes making Medics less important and even obsolete in many regards as their healing is slower than using a bandage, and only rez allies faster at the cost of worse gadgets, and limited gear choices. Game population has died off quite a bit, but there are still a decent amount of individuals that still play. 6/10 It's close to being an amazing game, but lack of balancing and variety bogged it down into mediocrity that gets more and more draining as time goes on.

It's a nostalgia trip to the late '90s and early '00s, scratching that Battlefield itch that has been sorely missed since 2015/2016. At times ... this game looks like a grumpy mess waiting for a flush, but it plays damn near exactly how I want a modern war game to, making it a potential contender for the throne of favorite FPS in the large-scale, huge-map, fast-paced war game genre. It's really something special. They've nailed the mechanics and gunplay.

The initial progress might seem a tad slow, and the textures might be minimalistic, but once you adapt, the game reveals itself as a very competent war shooter. Because of the minimal graphical demands, stacking these matches with such high amounts of players and constant action doesn't seem to cause any meaningful slow down or performance problems. It's smooth! Which makes the chaos all the more frightening! 😈

If you've not played a Battlefield game (by DICE), then this might be one of the best entry points you can take at the time of writing this (2024). It's incredibly affordable by comparison. BattleBit Remastered encapsulates everything a hardcore FPS enthusiast dreams of – massive maps, colossal teams, drivable air, nautical, and land vehicles, upgradable weapons, an XP leveling system, team squads, and much more. It's a colossal masterpiece, and the fact that it's not crafted by a AAA studio is mind-blowing. Sure, it might not be the most graphically dazzling spectacle, but boy, does it play like a dream.

Chaos is the essence of war, and Battle Bit certainly gets this right. They've done a fine job with physics, bullet drop, class/weapon progression - and the maps are mostly great - it all contribute to an immersive experience. A few tweaks in some maps might be nice, but that's probably down to personal taste.

This was the first multiplay FPS game I've played since I was a kid that made me question who was on my team and who the enemy combatants were. I...I think I might be getting old? I'm 34 - so I'll just blame the minimal design choices throughout and chalk it up to that. It does get more obvious as time goes on (or something was improved via a patch - it is an early access game). It turns out there is a slightly green or red mark somewhere around their shoulder/neck area. One thing that hasn't improved, spotting anyone from a distance - it doesn't seem to be working as I'd expect. A bit finicky.

I've heard many complaints of hackers from other players, but I can't say I've had a single encounter that even made me question or consider if someone was cheating or using some sort or exploit or tool. It largely seems like a pretty fair playerbase - albeit some could use a lesson in microphone etiquette, but that's par for the course in any online FPS. 

With it still being Early Access, just in the few weeks I've played - a few UI changes and patches have come out. It seems regular progress is being made, balancing happens at a reasonable rate, and the devs are responsive to the community.

Still in Early Access, BattleBit Remastered constantly evolves. Regular UI changes and patches roll out, showcasing a responsive development team dedicated to refining the gaming experience. If you crave large-scale FPS battles, a robust XP progression system, fast and twitchy gunplay, and a touch of optional team strategy, BattleBit Remastered is a slam dunk, an easy win that demands your attention. Highly recommended for those who seek the thrill of war on an epic scale. I'll certainly be back for lots more.

[h1] Old school Battlefield [/h1]

BattleBit, a spiritual successor to the beloved Battlefield series, has emerged as a delightful surprise in the gaming landscape, proving that a game doesn't need a massive budget to deliver an engaging and fun experience. Here's a brief review highlighting some of the game's standout features.

First and foremost, BattleBit impresses with its great variety of maps and weapons. From dense urban environments to sprawling landscapes, each map is meticulously designed, offering diverse settings that keep the gameplay fresh and exciting. The attention to detail in the low-poly graphics adds a unique charm to the visuals, creating an aesthetic that is both nostalgic and refreshing.

The game boasts epic 127 vs. 127 battles, providing an exhilarating scale that captures the essence of large-scale warfare. The chaos on the battlefield is both intense and immersive, creating an environment where teamwork and strategy are crucial for success. The sheer scale of the battles adds a layer of realism and excitement rarely seen in games of this scale.

BattleBit wisely retains the traditional class system that Battlefield fans know and love. Players can choose roles that suit their playstyle, from the frontline assault to the more supportive roles like medic and engineer. This classic class system adds depth to the gameplay, encouraging team coordination and diverse strategies.

One standout feature that adds a unique touch to the experience is the death mic feature. Allowing players to communicate with their team even after they've been taken out adds a layer of strategy and camaraderie, making each life feel like a contribution to the overall battlefield effort.

The game's vehicle selection is another strong point, offering a good variety that complements the diverse maps. Whether it's roaring through the battlefield in a tank or providing air support with helicopters, the vehicles enhance the dynamic nature of the battles, allowing players to choose their preferred style of engagement.

BattleBit's rewarding system deserves praise, particularly for medics and support roles. The game recognizes the crucial contributions of these roles, incentivizing players to play supportively by providing meaningful rewards. This not only encourages a balanced and cooperative gameplay style but also ensures that every player feels valued in the overall success of their team.

Perhaps most impressively, BattleBit stands as a shining example that you don't need millions to make a fun and engaging game. The passion and dedication of the development team shine through in every aspect of the game, creating an experience that captures the essence of classic large-scale shooters without the need for a blockbuster budget.

In conclusion, BattleBit is a low-poly masterpiece that successfully channels the spirit of the Battlefield series. With its great variety of maps, massive battles, traditional class system, innovative death mic feature, diverse vehicle selection, and a rewarding system that values teamwork, BattleBit proves that a game can be both budget-friendly and immensely enjoyable. It stands as a testament to the idea that a dedicated team with a clear vision can create a gaming experience that rivals industry giants.

This game feels like a spiritual successor to Battlefield 3/4 way more than Battlefield 2042 ever could, with some small, milsim-like twists to it. Complete with more level destruction than modern BF titles can achieve too. 

The graphics seem very silly at first, but the devs who made this made the graphics like that intentionally, so that even potato PCs could experience this AAA-like FPS title. The animations are so smooth as well that, you barely notice the graphics and blocky character models, given enough time. 

This game is also very cheap. Even when not on sale, it is 1/4th or even less than the price of your average AAA game. It's worth a try, in the least. So what are you waiting for? It's not a huge financial loss even if you don't like this game.

The game was amazing when it came out. Although he class balance was not the best, Each class was unique and with different play styles possible depending on your gun loadout.

I came back to see what the update was, also being back in the mood for a PVP game of quality. As someone who played every class depending on the need or my feeling, I don't see the point of playing anything other then rpg man or heavy armor man. as the best guns are smg's or DMR's even as a sniper and rpg man and heavy armor man have DMR's. 

Sniping is compleatly relegated to using the gun with the most damage since now even with a silencer all snipers emit a smoke trail from the bullet to you. so  no point in even trying to sneak a kill in tall grass with a enemy squad next to you since they will trace the smoke back to you. also no point in using switching barrel attachment for damage or for stealth since they removed the damage upgrade and again silencers are pointless. If you want to stealth, you just use a DMR with a silencer. the second DMR is guarantied a kill after 2-3 body hits while the first 2 snipers can be survived with a helmet making them 2 shots at worst. Since other classes have DMR and armour, why would you pick the sniper class?

Assault is also completely pointless since all assaulth rifle have awfull accuracy compared to SMGs, LMGs and DMRs. when they should be the most accurate. In fact when i first played the game there were only 2 dmr and the others in the class where assault rifles but where moved to dmr which is cross class. Assault also does not get anything special to carry like heavy ammo pouches or a RPG.

As for the RPG, the fragmentation rpg is completely useless against infantry and the HEAT and Tandem, both focused AT rounds will take out Infantry with in their blast radius, as well as do considerable environment damage and damage vehicles. 

I see no point in playing this game anymore. most servers don't have heavy vehicles to vary game play, Night time is rules by people who mess with their light settings since Night Vision wont work on any scope and scopes with night vision are horrible. Players also have glowing lights on their outfit which can be payed to win removed.

As for helicopters, the controls are arcady as heck. I can brake dead in the sky and move in all 6 direction like I was some ufo, meaning people with RPG stand no chance at actually hitting you since there is no velocity attached to the heli movement and therefor they cant predict the path you will take. Ground vehicles also have this weird behavior where reversing does not in fact reverse the steering directions. Although all vehicles have "weak points" I have hit helis dead on the body with the AT sabot round of a tank, resulting in minimal damage, while unloading a whole APC cannon magazine on a heli also does minimal damage. but a good hit from a rpg on a heli will result in critical damage as well as concentrated infantry fire.

honestly, I don't know what the devs are doing but they are killing the game. Devs if you see this, SMG's should not be accurate at longer range then ARs, LMGs should be accurate and hard hitting but not as accurate as AR's with out bipods and only heavy Snipers should emit a smoke trail.

It is really not hard even the british armory stated the same. it's like standard in every game where guns are in classes

The last time I enjoyed a team shooter was Battlefield Bad Company 2 and this one reminds me a lot of those days. The graphics are amusing, and the stuff that matters is all there. They really nailed the feel of a lot of the weapons, the map design is pretty good and the destructibility is a literal blast. 

The community also has largely been pretty good, from the guys role playing their silly block men super seriously when calling for medics to actual cooperative team info it has been pretty good. And the options to mute and report people being so simple is the best I've seen in a game. You just press f1 to mute and shift f1 to report, so if someone is being bothersome it doesn't even interrupt your flow to mute them and forget they're even there.

Bought this on a whim during a sale thinking if I had a few hours of fun it would be worth the cost, and it has easily delivered. Plus the install size is so small that I can just keep it installed for whenever I feel like playing a shooter! Highly recommend.

I've got almost 40hrs into this bad boy and it's easily one of- if not my most favorite game right now. Something about less-is-more, functional simplicity, blah blah blah you get where I'm going with this. Basically everything that made BF:BC2 thru BF4 great is all wrapped up into this spicy Minecraft-looking game. Most of the players seem to utilize teamwork a lot of the time (whether that's due to XP rewards or just camaraderie is yet to be determined) and I haven't encountered too many screechy chirrens despite this game looking... how it looks. I have a ton of fun playing even when my friends aren't online, and that's a pretty big deal to me since a lot of other games I enjoy seem to require a full party of cooperative friends to get anything done- but not this one! I sincerely wish this project the best and I hope it continues to grow, because so far it's been a great experience and time-killer.

Original review:

Surprisingly fun. For a small team, this game is great and I've got my moneys worth out of it. The fact that 90% of negative reviews are from salty children complaining about 'sweats' shows that there is little to hate here. 

Pro's
Great community 
Destructible environments
Great gun-play
Great sound design 
Great progression, never felt OP for being a higher level
Performance is excellent. 

Cons
Load in is too long- reduce it to 30 seconds 
Some of the maps are just ass
Vehicle handling could be better

8/10

Fall damage is inconsistent, I can die off like a 3 feet drop and like survive a 5 feet drop somewhere else. I can barely tell an ally apart from an enemy when zooming in as the marker vanishes. You can spawn on a teammate to instantly die under gunfire or something. Audio confuses the crap outta me, enemy and ally footsteps sound the same. You can't tell where any shots are landing. You can't throw a grenade when you're out of ammo as the dumb reload mechanic makes sure it finishes reloading first before it throws. The scroll mechanic for weapons and equipment sucks, you can pull out something that has 0 ammo and it's just not very intuitive. healing is a hassle as you have to hold down 3 and bleeding makes no sense. You can start bleeding at over 60 hp or something and you need to bandage. I don't want to have to ever scroll onto bandages. Dragging players to safety is also a hassle as you have to press f to begin dragging em. The helicopter sensitivity and the mounted cannons and guns on vehicles are so low that it's a pain. I mean I get that motorized cannons would take more time but yeah. Also why do you even have to wind up the mini guns on the helicopter? It's irritating as crap to hear the sound of the spinning guns and in real life, you don't need to wind it up to begin shooting. It just shoots and later begins spinning. Basically, game play can be very frustrating for a beginner and if you're not a try hard, you ain't getting many kills cause the veteran players will either snipe you out of nowhere and gun velocity makes no sense. You can basically get sniped with a pistol and while the game is progression based in which you unlock scopes. attachments, equipment, and guns based off kills and game roles, it takes a long time. I'm almost 50 hours in, and I've only hit like rank 120 in which the max is 200, and you can prestige back to rank 1 to unlock more content like a clan. How does a beginner compare against veterans who've all unlocked like the highest range scopes so they can see you and kill you while you can't see them or even figure out where they are. The vehicles acts as bouncy balls and can literally fly when you move across a terrain. Basically, if you easily frustrated don't play this game. I just play out of boredom and pass time. I like the game, but these are my issues with the game so far that I can think of.

While not outright terrible, the game falls short of greatness, primarily due to its lackluster graphics, underwhelming HUD, and less-than-appealing UI design. These elements collectively detract from the overall experience. At times, the gameplay can veer towards monotony, failing to captivate as effectively as its predecessor, Battlefield 4, a timeless classic that remains leagues ahead in quality. Despite its drawbacks, the game shows promising potential, notably in its support for over 200 players per match in its largest mode, offering a thrilling, expansive battlefield. However, it's evident that significant improvements are needed, particularly in refining the graphics, enhancing the HUD, and revamping the UI. These enhancements could substantially elevate the gaming experience. For those seeking a vast-scale battlefield experience, this game does deliver some enjoyable moments. However, it's recommended with the expectation of future updates addressing the current shortcomings in graphics and interface. Ultimately, while it's not yet a standout, with necessary refinements, it could become a compelling choice for enthusiasts seeking large-scale engagements.

I've enjoyed the game so far. I like how the maps and the teams are of a larger scale. Enjoy working/speaking with my team to complete objectives.

Fast paced if you want it to be. Good gunplay, allowing you to chose the weapon that fits your playstyle. There isn't, at the moment, a lot of meta guns and most have some benefit with a negative you have to compensate for. Voice chat is implemented well and how you plan to play with a squad is up to you. Personally I just like to jump in and shoot stuff. No SBMM so you'll either be dominated or will dominate, but the larger player games have enough room that you can play to your strengths.

The game feels amazing and the graphics may look goofy if you haven't played it but they have a lot of advantages over "classic" graphics (visual clarity and game performance). The game is still in early access so the devs are testing tons of changes all the time some of which can be more or less popular.

The VOIP adds a layer of fun to the game and one the biggest strength is you can really play it in the way you want. Want to be a maniac that always goes in with an SMG and C4, the game has that. Want to sit 1km from everyone else in a sniper nest, go ahead. The experience is what you make it to be.

If you enjoyed Battlefield 3, 4, bad company, bad company 2, etc., this game is for you.

Low poly, high action, huge player-count battlefield with vehicles, a rediculous amount of weapons, and player/weapon customization.   

Just an excellent shooter, and a breath of fresh air among the other corporate shooter slop we have today. 

I'd have payed AAA price for this instead of the new COD.

It's a great re-imagination of Battlefield 4. It's a BF game that we all wanted but at a way lower price. I would like to see more progression with in-classes. Instead of based off of ones rank. That's my only grip with in the game. I also love that the devs ask for our feed back at the end of each game about the map. Feels like they care about us and the game as the whole.

Fun run and gun battlefield. I like the movement, the destructible enviro, easily destroyable vehicles fun to drive. It's play to win progression and fairly grindy. Snipers have a lot of extra mechanics (glint, bullet trail) even mid range scopes have glint so if you like long range prepare for the entire map to see you fairly easily. Audio is being worked on currently. Its not perfect but pretty fun. Definitely don't expect it to be super tactical -- you can respawn on any squadmate fairly quick and a majority of the game will run and gun. There's probably one comms squad to every fifteen regular squads. I quite like the gunplay.

It is a breath of fresh air to play a game without microtransactions. Just a simple kill and level progession system that is rewarding enough. Gun balance has also made the game more varied.

BattleBit Remastered is an exhilarating gaming experience that redefines the meaning of fun when playing with friends. The game seamlessly combines a captivating and immersive gameplay with a vibrant multiplayer component that keeps you hooked for hours on end. The developers have truly nailed the balance between accessibility and complexity, making it enjoyable for both casual and hardcore gamers alike. The intricate mechanics add an extra layer of excitement, providing players with a deep and rewarding gaming experience. The team-based dynamics enhance the cooperative aspect of the game, fostering a sense of camaraderie among players. The graphics and sound design are top-notch, contributing to the overall immersive atmosphere of BattleBit Remastered. Whether you're strategizing with your team, engaging in intense firefights, or exploring the intricacies of the game's world, every moment feels like a thrilling adventure. With regular updates and a dedicated development team, BattleBit Remastered is not just a game; it's a continuously evolving and exciting journey that you and your friends won't want to miss out on.

Conclusions: 

1. Would I recommend? Yes, definitely.
2. For full price? No, wait for sales or something.

I really enjoyed playing the game, but then the lead dev released questionable update after update that nerfed recon pretty hard but added enemy pings. They were unwanted but not terribly game breaking.
Then they had the bright idea to completely rework the audio:
[quote=SgtOkiDoki] "To improve on this, sounds were prioritized from important to non important. For example, an enemy gun shot that is firing towards player has much more priority than an enemy gun shot that is not firing towards the player. And enemy gun fire has more priority overall than friendly ones.  [/quote]
Now for anyone who has ever played an FPS, you will understand why this type of sound update is so terrible. It's complete and utter garbage. 

I hope the game turns back around and reverses the terrible changes as well as the devs start actually working on issues that have been plaguing the game for a long time instead of these horrible game play, balancing, and cosmetic updates. 
This game had all the workings of a great battlefield style shooter but with the way they have been going, I would definitely recommend skipping this game.

Okay I don’t leave reviews often OR do I typically like FPS games BUT HERE WE ARE

This has by far been one of the best games I’ve played on steam in ages. A few friends forced me to download it and I do not regret it. Sure, maybe I don’t have a ton of hours in it, but I also don’t have a ton of free time either. Yet this game has been worth every minute. In seconds, I was in a match in a team with my friends. I picked up the controls pretty quickly and had a blast for the following hour. 

This is one of those games where you and your small group of friends are perched upon a hill constantly being mowed down and revived by your medic in the heat of battle trying to call out the various snipers zeroed in on our position just to look up and see a helicopter blow your entire squad to bits - and it’s so much fun. 

I highly recommend this game for anyone who likes a game you can either quickly pop in and pop a few shots off or spend hours grinding out the best weapon.

I'd like to start off. I love playing the game at it's core. Who doesn't want an old school Battlefield Bad Company 2 game nowadays. The reason I'm downvoting, is because the community sucks. I've yet to find any game where people actually talk, and communicate. Conquests boil down to both teams doing these massive swinging blobs that are constantly chasing each other.

Fuck Snipers. No really, if you main the sniper class you need to go touch grass. I sure do love when some random dude is sitting almost across the map, and one taps me when I'm driving my truck to the actual fight! SMGs need a nerf, run and gun is the way to play.

So yeah, if you have like six friends who play regularly get the game, otherwise this is just a shittier squad in every way.

This is what AAA fps shooters should aspire to be. Gun play is on par with any other game on the market and weapons in the game are all reasonably balanced. Each class has its own pros and cons and suit different styles of play. Where this game really shines  the scale. 127 v 127 is amazing and is where most of your time spent playing this game will be spent. Vehicles  combat in this game is also good. I wish there was a "meh" option, because this game is roughly it. Take the parts of battlefield 4 that made it arguably the best FPS game of all time and remove them. What you get is battlebit remastered. The massive matches are obviously cool and the roblox graphics are fun and easy on the pc. The balancing and gameplay features that were included are just terrible though. Instead of just healing like one did in all of the most beloved battlefield games, instead they use an even more cumbersome bandage system than battlefield 5 (which was a universally hated feature). Vehicles feel terrible to play both in and against as they decided to borrow from BF hardline with small arms damaging lighter vehicles (because that was certainly a feature people liked) and for some god forsaken reason the ammo of heavier vehicles is limited and requires  refill at spawn rather frequently (instead of just using the BF1 system of slowly refilling over time to avoid spamming). SMGs can easily beam people much farther than any AR can (don't really think that is reasonable) and any optic beyond like 2x magnification may as well come with a 30 pound weight to try and keep your gun from climbing to heaven (because no one enjoyed tap firing in bf4 actually being viable, I guess). Camping is absurdly powerful compared to actually pushing anything because the mass of fire becomes absurd near any objective and footsteps are about 4-5x louder than a plane breaking the sound barrier about 30 feet from you. Players are often actually pretty garbage as I came in with no experience playing shooters of this style beyond battlefield (which I played on console) and within a couple hours was working a 2-3 K/D in basically every match. Even then you won't be doing much shooting unless you have some really dedicated vehicle players or junker down hard on a contested point because the objectives are literally several minutes of running away from each other on bascially all maps. The spawn system is wayyyyyyy to cautious with what it considers as a teammate "in combat". In a game where bullets are constantly flying everywhere, if someone so much as shoots the building your teammate is in you best believe you will have to walk for 3 minutes before you can meet up with them because you will not be spawning on them. Reload times are straight criminal, you can literally step away from your keyboard and go grab a drink before an AR has reloaded, and you may as well just die and respawn instead of reloading an LMG. Damage numbers feel like a lie, although it may just be bad connections for some players, but I have had several incidents of hitting 6+ AR shots (which supposedly do 30+ dmg) on someone and getting quite literally beamed to 0 health by an SMG with them still standing. That or the headshot bonus is just wacky because if you get a headshot the entire gunfight may as well have not happened... you just automatically win. Engineer feels useless about 99% of the time because vehicles are best used at super long range and most can be damaged easier with a rifle than a rocket, but they are powerful when healing a friendly vehicle. Medic is just spamming 3 to revive people then 5 and right click basically the whole game (because I guess the system of throwing health on the ground was bad somehow, again a stupid decision to make healing both active and very tedious). The slow speed of all actions from combining mags and reloading to simply ADSing makes gameplay tedious overall compared to something like BF4, and don't get me started on how you cannot shoot or dive under when swimming making you an absolute sitting duck for no reason at all. I came in thinking the game was supposed to be the battlefield killer that did it all right, but instead I found out that it was a combination of all the factors from the last few battlefield games that made them worse than their predecessors. The end of the day this game is little more than a cheap ripoff of BF4 from people who clearly didn't realize what made that game so great. It sucks that we have to play it instead of battlefield because those games haven't been good for a while now and this game gets players, but it really is maybe half (on its best day) of the experience that a good battlefield game is. It does the massive online FPS part well, but on a micro level fails consistently and on almost every front compared to what it could be. If it was just roblox BF4 the game would genuinely be better than what it is now because every difference it has from that game frankly makes it feels worse. If you come in more open than I did with just expecting its own game then its decent and if the price is like $8 or lower I would say snag it up, but if you wanted something to play instead of battlefield like me then this game just isn't it.

It's a pretty solid game, but I do have a few gripes that would improve the player experience by a ton.
1. The fact that your camera rag-dolls with your body on death is incredibly annoying. It also allows for your camera to slip below the map, allowing you to see through walls and tell your teammates impossible information. 
2. Fix the vaulting mechanics. You should only vault while moving INTO a vaultable object. If you are crouching behind a barrier and hit space to stand up to peek, you will instead vault completely over the barrier, killing you 9 times out of 10. It's also very slow. Vaulting over a small object while running should not slow your momentum to a crawl, it should scale with your speed. 
3. Give some sort of indicator that your microphone is transmitting. Simple as. 

It's a solid game, and I expect there are many more changes to come. I would definitely recommend.

Honestly in my opinion fails as a military shooter. It provides very little variety in the gameplay to keep you coming back, especially if you're a newcomer (y'know, the kinds of people you WANT coming back). 

Gameplay is basic FPS military shooter stuff, with "military shooter" basically just meaning the entire game is walking around until you see someone, and either lasering them down immediately or getting lasered down yourself. There's almost no indication that you take damage (minimal screen shake and absolutely zero red filter or anything like that), and to be honest getting kills doesn't even feel satisfying. Like what, am I supposed to be satisfied that I won what boils down to a wild west showdown with less tension? Because I don't. 

Keeping you coming back seems to just be weapon unlocks, which can take waaaaaaay too long sometimes. You're basically only given 2 primaries at the beginning of the game (M4A1 and UMP iirc), both of which feel pretty similar to one another. If you wanted to try being a shotgunner or a sniper, sucks for you buddy, you gotta play the game with weapons you don't like first. Short-sighted in my opinion, and killed my motivation to play the game after I played with both of the guns. 

Customizability is way too much where it doesn't need to be, and not nearly enough where it should be. You're given mountains of gun addons that usually don't end up changing much other than sights and lasers/torches, but then for player customization you're given, like, 7 different uniforms. Really? That's it? Barely any customization from therein either. I know you don't wanna add like some nonsense cosmetics that do nothing but bring you out of the experience, but come on man, you can't even give yourself a pair of gloves? Is that really that odd of a request? Speaking of, the fact that you need to play for a good few hours just for the privilege of putting a bit of camo on your gun also makes zero sense. 

Aside from the gameplay, its visuals scream early access. For models this is fine, modelling is hard work and prioritizing working on gameplay is totally justified at this stage in the game's life, but...could you really not have even put a font on any of the menus? Something other than calibri or whatever you used? It makes the game feel just dead and personality-less. It doesn't even say "military shooter" to me, you could put its menus in almost any game if you changed the text and images and it would feel just as appropriate. Just a little bit of font decoration can go a long way in making the UI feel alive. Obviously, again, early access, but I can't help but feel that something like that would take a minimal amount of time considering it could help the game find its stylistic footing later on.

People have said this game looks like a Roblox game put on to Steam, and I have to agree. But you also need to recognize that there are Roblox games doing similar things that, in my opinion, they do considerably better than this game does. Just take the game Blackhawk Rescue Mission 5; just like BattleBit, it's a realistic-style military shooter game with lots of weapon customization and giant lobbies with tons of players. However, for one, the game has far more variety in what you can do, especially with its incredibly fun co-op open world mode. I'd love to see something like that added into the game, though who can tell if anything like that is planned.

All and all, if you like strictly large-lobbied PvP gameplay and nothing else, this game does that and does it...decently, but I can't help but feel there's better ways to get that fix. If you want anything other than that, you're SOL here bud. Definitely good for a certain audience, but I feel that audience is far too niche at the moment.

Wow

I thought the days of Playing games like BF2/3/4 where over, a relic of the past. But no! See it's got the simple layout and tight game play of BF2 2005, while adding some of the best that BF3/4 had to offer with ZERO of the EA/Dice nonsense. It's fun, intense, surprisingly polished and generally bug free, all that and it can run on a toaster powered by 2 hamsters on wheels. I played the night away and only had 1 bug?!? In what universe in modern gaming is that a thing? I'm running between cars dodging a storm of bullets while a helicopter crashes a few dozen feet away, right then I launch a rocket right into the side of a building I'm headed for to then immediately get rolled by 6 enemies who where just passing that way. Didn't drop below 144hz, the physics didn't wig out, the players didn't suddenly drop ping and fly across the damn map. Blown away by the devs efforts and ability to make this happen.

It's the sleeper build of shooters! Base level late 90s Honda Civic on hubcaps and rusted quarter fenders on the outside, Built K Series on boost and hondata on the inside. If you're a fan of large team based objective shooters this is an easy buy.

Once you get past the minecraft/roblox graphics, it's an amazing game. The gameplay is where it shines. It has all the standard features of a AAA game when it comes to upgrades but with an added feel of movement realism found in the battlefield series which feels nice. The buildings are hilariously empty rooms but it's more of a charm without the added stuff. 

Biggest reason I can recommend this game is because it runs so solid. No hiccups ever. I have enough hours into this game and I can say I've never crashed once. Rarely have connection/netcode issues if any. It's like all the angry BF fans voiced their concerns to this small dev team and they made good effort to address all of them. It's just a simple game you buy and play. No DLCs or season pass bullshit. It's nostalgic in a sense of when games were fun to play.

BALLER

[h2][b] Dr.Danio's Review [/b][/h2]

The game is a large-scale, team-oriented game and it mixed 'Battlefield' gameplay and destruction with a 'Roblox'-like block-style visuals. This unique combination results in a game that is both visually distinctive and engaging in its gameplay.

It's fast-paced and fun, providing an adrenaline rush and chaos that is hard to match. This makes it an excellent choice for gamers looking to enjoy quick, action-packed sessions.

However, the game is not without its flaws (of course) which can sometimes detract from the overall experience. One of the issues is the [b] hitbox detection [/b]. There are moments when hits that seem accurate don't register, leading to some annoying situations

Another point is [b] physics and environment [/b]. Built on the Unity, and featuring a box-like environment and graphics, the game occasionally falls prey to glitches and bugs. Players exploit to access unexpected areas and kill from unknown places.

The community is a mixed. While many players are fun and humorous, there's an element of toxicity and saltiness. This is a common issue but worth noting for those sensitive to such environments.

Progression offers a decent array of weapons and equipment to unlock on certain ranks. However, the grind required to unlock specific attachments and weapons can be a bit tedious. Players may find themselves spending hours to acquire a particular attachment, especially getting a lot of kills with certain weapon to get a certain attachment, which can be a bit discouraging.

In summary, this is game with a lot of potentials. It's fun, fast-paced, and offers a unique visual style. However, it's hampered by technical issues like hitbox detection, bugs, and a progression system that feels overly grindy. Despite these drawbacks, it remains a solid choice for those looking for an enjoyable way to pass the time, especially for fans of the shooter genre.

Such a wonderful game with compatibility with many different types of computers from the potatoes to the high tech. For its blocky format, the visuals can be quite incredible. The gameplay is very fun and not repetitive (sometimes). It is a little hard to pick up and can be a bit overwhelming as there is much going on at the same time, but once you get used to it it's a breeze. While I wanted to like this game and i really gave it a shot, It was not what I expected and I was not aware of many of the games setbacks when I purchased.

I am sure this game is fun for people that have been playing for quite a while but it is completely disadvantageous toward new players. I do not have the time to put into this game to rank up enough to be able to use a lot of the weapons and their mods. Without those, beginner players are just easy pickings for more experienced users with far superior weapons and all of their upgrades. There is no place to even practice offline so learning the maps and potential vantage points/areas to avoid, practicing weapon/vehicle usage, are nonexistent.

The ranking system and game modes were not described in the game description and the limitation on weapons, upgrades and lack of practice courses has a profound impact on the play-ability of the game, putting new players at a serious disadvantage in multiple different ways.

I started playing PC games back in 2012, starting with Battlefield 3 and moving onto Battlefield 4 as the battlefield series was my favorite gun play and game play with vehicles making every match chaotic.

Battlebit feels like the gun play of battlefield 3/4, maps have an incredible amount of destruction thinking back to the days of Bad Company 2, as well as giant map changing events similar to the "leveloutions" in Battlefield 4.

If you have ever played a multiplayer Battlefield 3/4 match, you will feel right at home.

Some of the grass is the same color as player models, Snipers are a constant issue (either the glint, glint removal, damage changes, range changes, spotting, etc. too many patches), RPG Hitboxes are iffy sometimes, maps can have looong walks to get back into the action, and Night maps can be a nightmare sometimes.

I still love this game.

Much Fun. Its has all the fun of the Battle Field games, and the cost of OG Minecraft. 
10/10 would play again.
A good Battlefield inspired shooter

You like Battlefield but mourn that it was never actually meaningfully finetuned after BF1? You like Battlefield but 2042 is just ... something else? This game here is a pretty good contender. The only downside to me are the graphics, but I quickly forgot about that.

The game has awesome maps, which you feel were designed by people actually playing this stye of game a lot. They seem based on the makers' own gaming experience and seem to draw inspiration from a wide range of shooter games, such as Insurgency, CoD and, of course, Battlefield.

The game also meaningfully improves classic BF systems, such as the Squad system, by offering differing types of squads for different playstyles.

And above all, the pace this game has is excellent. It's just ever so more slower than previous BF titles for it to remain casual but a *bit* more tactical, rewarding.

I really like this game. It also has a large player base. I can only recommend it.

I've played [i]Battlebit Remastered[/i] for about four hours and I've seen more destruction than I've seen in [i]Battlefield 2042[/i] after 150 hours.

While this game does look amazing and awesome game-play wise, there is one simple thing that completely stopped me from playing the game. No it's not some stupid thing like me complaining about the graphics.

The reason is I LITERALLY CAN'T. There's a multitude of bugs that pop up when you try to launch the game. That being the f*cking anti-cheat EAC not launching and that stops the game from starting in the first place. 

You are also required to download some weird stuff called "Microsoft Visual C++ Redistributable" and guess what if you don't have this stuff? YOU CANT PLAY. These two bugs, if you could call them that, are so frustrating because even when I seeked out the few videos on ways to fix these thing, IT STILL DIDN'T LAUNCH. And that f*cking sucks because I really wanted to play this game.


EDIT: Downloaded the game again after a few months and now it's fixed.

I must say something aloud, cause I am getting tired of it. Players can abuse their language (especially russians) with telling you "idi na ch**" using voice chat - no action from admin.

To comment: Of course I tested it myself, I got banned when I only wrote in chat. Previously I were testing this (e.g. saying inappropriate things all the time on voice chat) never lead to anything.
