I really should like this game, but I just don't. The only concrete thing I can think of is the maps. They're way too big, with not enough cover. 1 km between points (in 1 map) in a Battlefield inspired game is a bit excessive. And most of the fights seem to occur in open space with no cover (as opposed to the objectives). In a more milsims-type game, this would be fine, but it doesn't work for this style of gameplay in my opinion.

Ultimately, it's just not for me. It's better than 2142, or MWII/III, but it's no BF4 or Squad.

Battlebit is a wonderfully deep yet easy to enjoy experience that hasn't been managed since Battlefield 4. The scale of this game is kept within bearable levels because of the lack of 8k textures and 5 billion polygon character models. I am rarely overwhelmed by a noisy UI and chaotic visuals. I like to play while listening to the Mechwarrior 2 sound track, taking my ass back to my teenage years so that I can immerse myself into the experience. 

When you buy Battlebit you are buying a full product. This is another trait that lead me to purchase this game. I am so exhausted by loot boxes and random rewards in my games. I am sick of popups and timers for content. I just want to hopin and play and have fun. BBit does just that.

I wrote this review earlier on than i should have, but i still stand by some of the criticisms within. HOWEVER, considering the low price of the game and the consistent updates the game gets, i do believe it is worth your purchase, despite its flaws. Here is my original review:

(old review, i no longer agree with some of what i said)
Battlebit certainly has its fair share of good qualities, for example, the weapon customization and ease of menu navigation. but i feel that the negatives outweigh the positives, even if just for me. In no particular order, here are a few of my issues : 

1)how the fuck did i die- the killscreen is not very easily read and is somewhat confusing. 

2) where am i supposed to go? most of the maps are entropic clusterfucks that dont have consistent pushes and pulls from either side, rather, the match ends up as a homogenous mix of players, often leading to me spawning in, and then dying instantly, even on the larger maps. 

3) the maps- most of them have entirely too much empty space, like, Golmud Railway from Bf4 levels of empty space, interrupted by the occasional densely covered mosh pit.  

4) the balance- why can i be lazer-beamed down by an smg at 100 meters? Why are snipers less than useless? Why does bleeding exist, other than to annoy me?

I have other issues with the game, but there are also things i really do like about the game. However, i think battlebit has some crucial steps to take before it is truly great.

in case you wanted to know a rough concept of the state battlefield should have been in by now, i highly suggest this game. it just takes that original formula in a direction that makes way more sense than whatever Dice/EA is trying to do right now with Battlefield.

Edit: changed to "do not recommend."

i liked battlebit because it started out as a more hardcore arcade version of battlefield with more grounded elements. it felt like we were finally getting a game that maintained that middle-ground between arcade and milsim.

now theres a lot more visual clutter to hold the player's hand and balancing has mostly favored a very niche meta run-and-gun playstyle. it takes players away from the overwhelming amount of grounded and tactical features that make up a majority of the game's content and marketing.

this game needs to cook for a while. battlebit is having a bit of an identity crisis at the moment and thats understandable because the game is in early access. i still feel as if the devs are taking the game in the wrong direction due to a very loud minority of people gaslighting concerns and feedback on discord (which has seemingly become the dev's main source for feedback). they are not making choices necessary that would benefit the game's overall balance and unique identity, such as getting a better anticheat, restricting movement exploits, and properly balancing certain classes/weapons to be less versatile rather than nerfing other non-meta classes out of shear spite.

Battle bit has been an insanely fun game. From sitting in a helicopter as its in a fight, to a massive battle on the ground, Battle bit is worth your money and is very fun to play with or without friends.

It's a pretty good game. The massive bonus is that the graphics and the engine allow it to be run on a potato. My computer is not quite potato but more like fancy French fries but for the most part, I'm still using GeForce Now for more intense titles. It's been a while since I was able to run a 254 player game without my computer dying under strain. 

The graphics may also be a negative who like eye candy, so your mileage may vary. It's essentially stripped down Battlefield of old. The fact that three people made it happen is impressive. 

However, this game has a lot of sweat. If you're a sweatlord - that's fine but sometimes it's really frustrating to be stacked, especially when the game of Frontline gets clanstacked. SMG enjoyers are annoying, snipers are annoying and despite the apparent stability of the game, one cannot help but wonder whether hitboxes and damage system needs additional refinement. Devs seem to be aping stuff with skins, kind of missing the point in my opinion. The report system seems to be weird and it does seem like clans seem to cooperate on simply reporting people they don't like, regardless whether they have violated the TOS or not. Encountered higher than average amount of weirdos. Could use some differentiation in stuff like Remote Weapon Systems (both Russian TIGR and HMMWV have an option of that in the game but it's just a simple blocky cube with a gun). 

TL:DR: It's for you if you like Battlefield and/or Minecraft, don't mind some simplicity, like to be covered in sweat and don't mind weirdos.

I was on a crazy killing spree in this one building, splattering dude's brains across the walls, while I jolted from room to room, floor to floor, body to body as my lust for death never sated. Until I was ultimately ended by a stray soul. Fearing what would happen if I was allowed to revived, this individual dragged my bloodied up body to the top floor, hidden and tucked in a room far from my comrades. I begged and pleaded for the man to not leave me there. I shouted, I screamed, I yelped to him not to leave me within the confines of my fractured body. But my pleads fell on silent ears and passing bullets whizzing by, as if I was just another corpse. A simple number, just to be added to the counts of others, destined just to be that.

I had high hopes believing the phrase "this is what Battlefield should be". But it is not "what Battlefield should be". It's mostly what "Battlefield shouldn't be".

My first 15-minute experience was: I got killed a dozen of times out of nowhere, I was on server with people who obviously played the game for way longer than me, I experienced a bug that didn't allow me to switch gadgets, the game didn't help me perform my role properly, the game didn't explain how my role works, the game didn't allow me to change my loadout pre-game, the game had good UI but awful UX that didn't help me achieve what I needed to do.

I was hoping I could find a revived Battlefield. I was wrong, and now I am more keen to return to BF4, where things were obviously thought through and more ballanced.

Update2*** A couple more updates in and the devs are definitely addressing some of the glaring issues of gameplay. My only 2 critiques with the gun mechanics are that the rockets are unbelievably slow. I feel like you might be able to outrun them, it's that noticeable. The second being that when your magazine runs dry, it won't prompt a reload. You'll just stay empty until you press R. Kind of dumb considering there isn't anything else I'd be doing with the thing. Grenades need to be a touch more damaging as well. Game still runs amazing, player base for the most part is really fun, and the maps and content keep coming. These devs actually listen to the feedback. Meaningful anti-cheat needs to be top priority IMO. And the spawn system needs improvement. A LOT of instant death scenarios currently..

After 20 hours played I can say it's a great feeling FPS that is doing a better job at being a battlefield game than 2042 can hope for. I hope EA and DICE are taking notes and applying them to the next Battlefield project because this game shows that there is NO excuse for a studio of that size to produce something of lesser quality than a 3 person team. 

Having said all that, this game is not without it's faults. That is to be expected since it's such a small team and it's still in early access. They aren't game breaking problems by any stretch of the imagination so keep that in mind.

There is kind of a fun game buried in here but the most glaring issue is the map design. Some of these are among the worst large scale FPS maps I've played and I'm saying that with 3k hours in planetside haha. The visual design is so plain that, at shallow angles, doorways aren't even visible. Healing is cumbersome, even after the universal healing patch. Most of the arsenal is fun but there is a bit of cheese, not really any more than what usually permeates these kind of games though. The movement is cool but totally antithetical to what they're trying to have this game be so it clashes with the map design. This game is sold as some kind of milsim roleplay game but everyone moves like a TF2 scout. Don't get me wrong, the game is way better for it but it creates odd interactions. Regardless, the shooting feels very nice. It has the tried and true ADS-centric gunplay that works very well. Talking to dead enemy players is also something I wish more games did but isn't exactly a "killer feature" to carry the entire game (edit: nobody talks anymore). Basically, this game has a really nice player controller but everything around it detracts from the experience.
After a few hours playing it is fcking addictive, I really recommend it!
Fun game, once you get past the learning curve.

While battlebit is fun and great for having only 3 devs, its very over hyped. Main issue is visibility, the lack of foliage or any real environment . There's almost no point to sniping because every gun is a laser beam, and snipers have a hilariously bad glare. The sound design is terrible. The actual graphics arent the issue, its just the level design. There's no rubble or mortar pits, barely any foliage, its just too clean. You can headglitch the top of any hill because there's no grass. This game does a lot of great things, but they're all being talked about already so i want to share what I myself haven't heard people say. I really want to like this game but its constantly being compared to battlefield, and its just not that good. Prox chat is amazing, death mic, map voting, all that is a major improvement to battlefield but it doesn't make up for the total lack of atmosphere. There's nothing going on, and people play it totally different. Tune into a battlebit stream, theyre probably doing that R6 siege shit where they spam crouch while leaning random ways. The game could be so much better but in its current state its just not as fun or satisfying as the games its being compared to. ( its still obviously better than bf5 or 2042 to be clear) Its really funny people are offended by my opinion, especially considering the majority of the things i complained about have been improved. WEIRD. Almost like i was right or something.

I would love the game, for the same reasons as everyone else, but there is a glitch. On pretty much every steam game I play volume doesn't work initially and I have to change the output device in audio settings. But Battle Bit doesn't let me do that, it says that "hands free ag audio" is the only output device, when I KNOW my headphones (HD.458BT) do. One time it worked, but my microphone didn't work (I couldn't talk).

This is early access, but enough of the game is here to be worth your while.

Comparing this game to Battlefield is inevitable, but there are some key differences:
-Purely class-based, no heroes.
-Walls and most buildings are destructable.
-Some maps are absolutely massive.
-More freedom with attachments.
-'Realism' mechanics for reloading and health.
-Most notable: 127 vs 127.

The 127 v 127 matches are absolute chaos. While it feels like you don't contribute much to a match's outcome in Battlefield, this game exacerbates the feeling. You'll encounter many 'fronts' where you can barely peek without getting gunned down or grenaded by someone.

I won't get into too much detail because A: i'm lazy, and B: this game being in early access means many details are subject to change over time. 

-If you're a Battlefield fan and 2042 disappointed you, this game can help scratch that itch.
-If you're an FPS fan, but haven't played big multiplayer shooters like Battlefield, I recommend this game just for the experience of how chaotic the matches get. 

People who are more into smaller FPS matches where individual players have much more sway on the match will likely not enjoy this game as much. There are 32 vs 32 servers, but they are very sweaty.
it is a well polished game with a large player base and zero micro transactions all things in game could be unlocked by playing

What a solid release.  Not only does this game knock it out of the park with gameplay, it helps to highlight everywhere were triple-A titles (and the journalists reviewing them) miss what makes a game enjoyable.  It's not about better animated sweat.  Good netcode, good gameplay, a completely working party system, decent default settings for things like motion blur.  These things all add up and it amazes me that some of the small things are not a standard in the games industry.

Update: Continued development on the title is also putting AAA titles to shame, with meaningful balance changes to weapons and maps, new content, and improved features.

Update 2: Sad to say the updates have started causing issues.  Continuous updates mostly a good thing, until a large untrialed update goes in and isn't backed out rapidly.  The changes to the soundscape in the game have made it frustrating to play.  Buggy, weird, and a loss of the atmosphere of large battles.  It feels genuinely unpleasant to play at the moment.

It is a fun game with everything you need in a FPS and more, destructible buildings are great. The only downside currently is there is't really a way to select which game mode you are playing which is sometimes frustrating if you want to play a certain one.

A classic formula in great form. That's Battle bit in a nutshell. Building on Battlefield's formula, this game offers a accessible in fun large scale warfare experience with tons of great maps, weapons and features.
The large scale shooter genre has evolved a lot and this game cheery picks the best features for a wholesome experience that I'd recommend any day.
The only thing that I think they can improve :
1. Modes like invasion need more dynamic game play changes. They feel too stale and slow
2. Greater accessibility on warfare vehicles and gadgets to use against them. Items like Stinger and Javelin RPGs as well as smaller warfare vehicles open up a greater opportunity for new maps and modes

Player input interpretations, an essay:

When standing/crouching before a mantleable ledge and pressing jump, but [b]no other inputs[/b] whatsoever:

Cyberpunk 2077: Ah yes, the player wants to mantle and land [b]on top of[/b] the ledge.

BattleBit Remastered: Ah yes, the player wants to jump [b]over[/b] the obstacle. There's a 7-floor drop on the other side that is totally fatal? Yes, over.

I really want to understand why this game takes itself more serious than some of those claimed "Triple A" games that have nearly the same point, but with downspeaking reviews (We all know, what I mean)

Just consider; This game costs 8 bucks (due wintersale), you launch the game, do a quickplay, and leave whenever you want or have to, no saving, no long "Are you sure", or "But are you really sure" messages that annoy the player as he may have to just leave.

Graphic wise, simple, yet astonishing in detail, you should only experience lag, if you're still running on a potato, if you can play minecraft with mods or other similiar games, you should be able to play this.

The only lack I see as off now, are some achievements to spice things up a little bit, like "Sergeant - Reached Rank so n' so", or "Kill 5 enemies in a single life" or just simple stuff like "Revive 3 people in a single life".

These minor additions would fill the game fully up, join, play, leave, no annoying registration, no annoying 20.000.000th gamelauncher no one wants, simple to understand.

I was almost ready to recommend it but then I got a server-wide message that said "Huntsman was banned for racism/harassment". Apparently, this is one of those games. This happened on an official server so I suppose poor guy was banned not just on this server but in the game entirely. This gets even more stupid since you can completely disable voice and text chat and be safe from "racism/harassment". If you don't want to do that, you can mute people as they speak with hotkeys. You don't even need to open a menu to do that, just press a button to immediately mute the one who is currently talking. But still... European gamedev at its finest.

Now to the game itself. It feels like (because it is) a cheap clone of BF4. By cheap I mean asset quality. Not bad, just low pricey. The gunplay is the same, the game mechanics are pretty much the same, even the maps resemble BF4 maps or copy their parts. You run through a location and you know exactly where you are and where you should go because [i]you've already been there[/i]. And it is not a bad thing at all: EA cannot make a game as good as BF4 anymore so other people take up the initiative. But the best thing is that the [i]feeiling[/i] is the same. Chaotic dynamic mess with a bit of teamplay, squads of random people, annoying snipers in bushes, grenade spam at chokepoints etc. It feels good to be back. But there are some new mechanics: for example, the enemy who just killed you can hear you in voicechat for a brief period. Pure gamer rage with some occasional gamer words really adds to this feeling. There are bugs and glitches here and there but since it is Early Access I wouldn't mind much. So if you can control yourself and don't mind the morality police then buy it.

Finally, a positive experience after a long wait. The 127vs127 format shines on medium-sized maps, but the overly large ones turn the game into a tedious Walking Simulator. I tend to quit on encountering vast landscapes. Nevertheless, communication has improved; the game encourages interaction with teammates, a departure from my usual silent gaming persona.

Graphically, it's akin to Roblox, with decent options even at max settings. The weapon variety is fair, with the promise of more additions. The dragging ability for medics is a thoughtful touch. The array of vehicles, including tanks, armored cars, and 4-wheel bikes, adds to the gameplay.

The sound is passable, but some music and an announcer could elevate the excitement. Patience is warranted, as the game is still in its infancy.

The player base is robust, ensuring quick match findings even for 127vs127, and I encountered zero lag in my 5 hours of play. While I experienced one crash, I anticipate future updates will address such issues.

This concludes my initial review; further updates will follow as I delve deeper into the game.

Solidly good, well featured despite being early access. 

Gunplay and customization are satisfying and theres a large roster of weapons and equipment, loads of forward grips, scopes canted sights barrel attachments makes for an interesting experience trying out setups for different guns. Theres also character customization but ive not looked into it as I personally still dont like the minecraft/roblox looking character models because it feels mismatched to the realistically modeled weapons/vehicles/environments but thats a nitpick if im honest and is a non-factor while im playing.

Maps are pretty varied and large and ive enjoyed most of them, the day and night options are neat addition keeping things a fresh. Game modes are fun and i find that im partial to invasion as it lessens the impact my incompetence has on my team by not letting me suck down a truckload of tickets while i flail about on my keyboard trying to walk in a straight line.

TTK is really fast so minor mistakes or lack of awareness can end you really quick and its easy to get stuck into a loop of live die repeat if youre careless but I still have fun regardless. 

Performance is excellent in fact I would say that the minimum spec is actually quite overkill. Out of curiosity I tried to get it running on my 2014 HP Steam with a Celeron N3060 and its HD 400 igpu and it was nearly playable. The N3060 was just a bit too slow to really make it feasible, given that the minimum suggested cpu(i5-2310) is about 5 times faster overall than the N3060 i would say you could run this on almost anything. 

This is the first PvP shooter ive really played any amount since playing halo 3 and Bad Company 2 on the 360 and while im severely out of practice I'm having a good time.

I don't know if it just me, but when everything is low poly, and pixelated, everything just blends together. having a hard time seeing the enemies, or actually even my teammates. I just try to get to a point, or an advantage point, then get sniped from gods know where. and that is the entire match.

Now, I see how the game is like a "better" Battlefield, and how Battlefield was back in the "old" days. but I would personally still boot up Battlefield 4 instead.

The game is okay, but there are a ton of small things that make it quite frustrating and disappointing.

- Lack of talking players + moderated voice chat
The main reason I wanted to play was the global voice chat, but out of the 5 or so matches I played, I encountered only 3 or so people that actually responded to me. 
There seems to be a strong incentive to not talk because the first thing you see when you launch the game is a message that voice chat is recorded and moderated and that disruptive behaviour is disallowed.

- There is no tutorial
The UI isn't explained, the classes aren't explained, the menu isn't explained. You are expected to go in blind and "figure shit out on your own"

- The UI is horrible.
You don't see your health nor your exact ammo
You also cannot edit your loadout in the main menu, only in-game.
The video settings menu is filled with useless stuff like HUD colors, while missing most of the actually useful video settings.

- View bobbing is PERMANENTLY on

- Gunplay is not very enjoyable.
The game is insanely sluggish. Get hit? bandage that takes 5 seconds to use. Reloading? needs to be done after every kill or 2 and takes like 3 seconds. Switch to anything? Slow switching animations for you, fam. 
You only have 5 mags which all have separate ammo, you usually need over half a mag to kill an enemy, and if you run out, you are basically fucked unless you have someone with an ammo box or you again take like 5 seconds to reorganize your mags while camping somewhere

Fairly good game, but still held back by its glaring limitations

- - -

Gunplay is good, netcode is extremely inconsistent. Takes half a magazine to kill an enemy, but it feels you get downed in 1-2 hits abruptly. Sometimes shots don't even register, sometimes it feels like they just phase through enemies. Occasional connection issues (shot denied due to packet loss, sometimes losing connection and disconnecting from a server).

That said, it has a lot of good going for it -

257 players is outright amazing, and the fact that it all works smoothly without many bugs is further credit to the streamlined, quality development that this game has received. (BF games generally have a dump truck's worth of problems on release)

Combined arms gameplay that exceeds Battlefield in scale and chaos.

Sound is very lackluster, it doesn't have the cinematic, all consuming feel of a BF title like 1.

Graphics are absolute trash, it looks terrible and I don't mean that it's just a "low poly" thing. Compared to games like Polygon it still looks like shit. Characters are literally minecraft tier and when youre inside a building there is NO depth perception at all because nothing has textures and its just sheer simple colors on walls. Disorientating.

It doesn't feel satisfying shooting enemies or blowing up vehicles. Just lacks the punch and crunch of BF games (because of the low poly aesthetic). Sounds and graphics definitely bring this up. Nothing feels intense or brutal (probably what they were going for)

Definitely a monumental achievement for 3 developers, but I wouldn't play this over any BF games (probably not even 2042).

I've been playing Online Games since LAN Duke Nukem, LAN AOE,Battle.NET SC and WC 2 Tides of Darkness, Delta Force in mid 90s. Lets not forget the AOL Online Game Services in 1995-1999  (SHOUT OUT TO ALL MY MAGESTORM G'S! The first REAL MMO PVP/FPS by far). 

    This game... When It comes to raw PVP/FPS energy, this game is it. It is simple yet a masterpiece! The very moment you figure this game out, its got you by the b*lls. The comments about not being able to get guns in the beginning and so on are pure trash. Go to COD and pay to win if you want that ish. It took me 25 min to get the hang of this game and I'm in love. It is what "WE" as gamers missed in the PVP/FPS world. Graphics are great but this game is proof that game play is number 1. This game is so good I will be gifting it to 5 RANDOM people for XMAS. I guarantee that if the developers pitch this to console it will be number 1. The magnitude and scale of this game is fantastic. The possibilities are endless if the devs stay on this path plus listen to the community for input/ideas. Point blank, if you L-O-V-E FPS games, get this. You will not be disappointed. My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is

This combines elements from some of the greatest shooters. Whilst aesthetically simple, you're immersed in a complex game with epic non-stop strategic game play. With bullet velocity/drop and hitmarkers, you feel the satisfaction of your Chris Kyle IQ. I was unsure at first if I could get into this style of game, but now I'm worried i can't get out.

This game has potential but I cannot recommend it just yet. it violates the most basic requirements for a good shooter: good gunplay and rendering the view accurately to the body. Far too many people cheese the fact that you can't see them but they can see you because the camera is not viewing at the characters eyes nor looking down the actual barrel. Appears to be slightly higher. A good test of this is to watch enemies shooting at you or your team from behind a barrier. Can't see their gun but getting hit? Yep. Dumb. Guns don't register hits even though you can clearly see the tracer reaching it's mark. Concept is cool but it's pure chaos. Nothing feels "good". Everything feels "sloppy". Needs more time in the oven.

A BIG portion of this game is its fluidity of the gameplay. Doesn't matter how you like to play the game will reward you and you can master your style and have a lot of fun.

A very BIG PLUS is the community, game uses all voice chat & death mic which can enhance the immersion and full of the game. Hell just listening to the players softly saying they don't fell their legs after stomp a landmine is hilarious. Community is what makes this game great, its always joy to listen to it at least if you don't have mic or don't want to speak. Community is just great at its current stage and ppl are usually joking, per my time I didn't personally experience any major toxicity in the game (except few individuals, but such ppl get banned very fast).

In regards of cheating, I didn't experience any if so not much. PPL really want to have just fun rather than cheating, and if you die its 99% your own fault rather than somebody is using an AIM bot.

Overall a great and positive experience.

##############################
@UPDATE #1:
##############################
I like this game however I need to leave a negative review after the latest patches 2.2.2 & 2.2.3.

The reason is the latest mode and its map designs. Even thou I still have fun its hard on current patch. Mostly is because a slight average < 51% of total players always chooses the new Invasion mode, the mode its self wouldn't be a problem but the way how its design around the maps is just terrible. You are locked into a small size of the map and until all points are not taken you are unable to progress it further. This may not sound serious but it opens a BIG problem, that problem is Camping and Sniping.

A big portion of this game is its fluidity of the gameplay, the new mode however takes it away as most of the players are just camping and sniping, so there is less action, less play styles available - thus less fun. Imagine this repeats game after game after game every day of the Current Invasion mode from its release. This is becoming frustrating rather than fun.

A lot of ppl like this new mode and that's why is chosen, however its oversatured and you can see ppl frustration.

As mentioned I like this game, but at the current time I am leaving a negative review, this may change, if the new mode is adjusted or at least limited so we can go and play as well other game modes....

##############################
@UPDATE #2:
##############################
Played on the new patch 2.2.4 for several hours and looks like the negatives of the new mode were mostly redeemed. New patch tuned some aspect of the time necessary to capture points. even thou it didn't completely solve the problems with the layouts of the maps for the mode, the game-play moves much more faster so camping and sniping even if still there is not so more prominent. Also the mode it self is as well less prominent during the modes choosing phase. This is good as you are not getting frustrated all the time.

I am changing my review back to positive!

Yes. If you like massive multiplayer FPS battles like BattleField, this is it. It may not have the fanciest graphics or AAA stamp on it but its very fun and detailed. Every action you do in this game like shooting, crouching, aiming while crouching, etc has feedback so it feels like the game is responding to you not just other players and interactable objects.

Its very light too. I play the game using R5 5600G without discrete GPU at 720p, medium settings. I was able to get 60 FPS flat with no stuttering.

If you bought the game, i recommend lowering screen shake in the settings because the default value is too much for me.

AMAZING GAME! What else can I say? Great mechanics and the updates are just making it better every time. It's a hard game ad requires a different set of skills from your standard COD style arcade game. Battlebit relys on the gamer to understand the battlefield an make appropriate decisions. The wrong decisions result in a quick death for you and your squad. The gunplay in this game is amazing too, with a more tactical approach to the modern FPS shooter. So don't hesitate to play this game, its wild and way too much fun if you can make it past the learning curb.

The games graphics are simple, appealing to the eye and easy to run on an average gaming PC at High or so. The servers with 120vs120 games run well in terms of ping and frames as well. 

Very good gun play and mechanics, driving the vehicle that could be worked on a little would be the Humvee...

Audio sounds great in the game whenever you get hits and when shots are fired; VOIP is what really sells the game. 

Worth every price.

BattleBit Remastered, a massively multiplayer online first-person shooter, emerges as a testament to the prowess of indie game development. Crafted by the talented trio of SgtOkiDoki, Vilaskis, and TheLiquidHorse, and exclusively available on Microsoft Windows through the Steam distribution platform, this game brings a fresh and exhilarating experience to the gaming community. With its unique blend of engaging gameplay, stunning visuals, and a dedicated team behind its creation, BattleBit Remastered has carved its niche in the competitive world of online shooters.

One of the standout features of BattleBit Remastered is the meticulous attention to detail in its design and gameplay mechanics. The collaborative efforts of the three indie developers have resulted in a game that not only meets but exceeds expectations. From the intricately designed maps to the fluidity of controls, every aspect of the game reflects the commitment to quality. The attention to detail is not only evident in the game's aesthetics but also in its balance and pacing, creating an immersive and enjoyable experience for players.

The multiplayer aspect of BattleBit Remastered is a defining element that sets it apart from other first-person shooters. The game's massive online battles bring together players from around the world, fostering a vibrant and competitive community. The seamless integration of multiplayer modes enhances the overall replayability, ensuring that no two matches are ever the same. The collaborative and competitive nature of these multiplayer battles adds a social dimension to the game, encouraging players to strategize and communicate effectively to secure victory.

Visually, BattleBit Remastered stands out as a testament to the capabilities of indie developers. The graphics are not only impressive but also contribute to the overall immersive experience. The attention to realistic details, dynamic lighting, and vibrant environments showcase the dedication of the development team to deliver a visually stunning product. As players traverse through the diverse landscapes, from urban cityscapes to expansive natural terrains, they are treated to a visual feast that enhances the overall enjoyment of the game.

Moreover, the continuous support and updates provided by the developers demonstrate their commitment to the longevity and improvement of BattleBit Remastered. Regular patches, bug fixes, and additional content keep the gaming experience fresh and engaging. This level of dedication to post-launch support ensures that players can look forward to a game that evolves and grows over time, maintaining its relevance in the ever-changing landscape of online gaming.

In conclusion, BattleBit Remastered is a shining example of what indie game development can achieve. With its trio of talented developers, engaging gameplay, stunning visuals, and a commitment to ongoing improvement, the game has rightfully earned its place among the top-tier online first-person shooters. As a testament to the creativity and dedication of indie developers, BattleBit Remastered stands tall, inviting players into a world where skill, strategy, and camaraderie converge for an unforgettable gaming experience.

I'd recommend this game if you have a dedicated friend group willing to get stuck in. or are a social butterfly who can find a clan. Otherwise alone New players face some issues that may make the game feel horrible.

Progression is slow and gun attachments are only unlocked via kills with your weapon. you will be facing experienced players with superior weapons. who have no qualms of using explosives when you're trying to get the attachment that makes your gun better.

Weekly EXP challenges don't feel worth the effort and are beyond frustrating for all involved. 

Complicated mechanics and hidden QoL features hidden away or poorly explained.

If these aren't deal-breakers to you (Or get fixed later) Then enjoy the unique flare of this indie revival of massive multiplayer shooters.

i think we all have fond memories of xbox 360/ps3 era shooters that were focused on fun, teamwork, and encouragement to make friends and communicate. 

this is like a time machine to that, this game is a blast - and it reminds me of what it feels like to play a fun shooter again

personally, i love playing the medic class - people are almost always talking (or roleplaying), and it makes it very fun to go around and keep my comrades alive. the amount of times i've saved someone and they go "TELL MY WIFE I LOVE THEM" is hilarious

it's not the most in depth gunplay but it feels great and doesn't have any artificial things to make it harder to aim (like valorant, cs, etc.)

also, as i age - my eyes aren't what they used to be, my reflexes aren't as fast, and i don't have as much time to game. 

that's where my appreciation for its simple visual language, team-focused gameplay, and casual nature comes from - it's everything i want a shooter to be at my age. i don't have time to practice or dedicate my life to a game. so this game's simplicity and play-ability is really nice. 

not every game needs to be some hyper-competitive esport

overall a 9/10 - with one point dinged off for the slow progression, other than that, this is a masterpiece

great game, easy to pick up, so far all 10 hours have been online and i have noticed non(or unnoticeable minimal) lag/cheating, love this game

One of the best battlefield-esk casual shooters in the past 5 years easy. This game and its team have outshined most AAA developers in the genre, especially considering the price point. Battlebit has classic Bad Company 2 like destruction, fun and easy to learn gunplay, constantly entertaining VOIP, large amount of content, regular updates introducing more content, developers who regularly listen to player feedback, and so much more.

This game is made by 3 devs and its just as good if not better than AAA titles. It has a BF3 kind of feel to it where you can really do some goofy stuff if you want while also being a solid shooter. The devs have super regular updates that add new content, balance weapons, and fix issues- but at the same time they also listen to community feedback. Theres been updates adding or changing features in order to take the game in the direction that they wanted but were unpopular with the community, and they generally reach a medium where most people are happy. While its not perfect, its extremely solid/pretty well balanced and fun to play.

I've only played one and a half hours so far with BattleBit and all I can say is that I'm actually impressed with it's gameplay.

Looking at the game and judging it on graphics alone will leave you heading over to a game like Battlefield 2042 for the worst gaming experience in the 2000's UNTIL 2042, unlike BattleBit which has some proper gameplay mechanics and an actual FUNCTIONING game.

But BattleBit is this weird love child of Roblox, Squad, and Battlefield, it also plays just as good as all three games ((so long as you count ONLY Battlefields' Bad Companies, 3, 4, Hardline and One in your list - because besting 2042 in 2023 can be done with a GBC cartridge like Wario World 3, hell I guarantee you that you can best Battlefield 2042 with an Etch and Sketch. I'd have to say BattleBit OUTPERFORMS Battlefield if I included EA's 2042.))

In all seriousness though, this is a game apparently designed by three individuals and so far these three have proven that, yes.

AAA Companies are absolutely useless compared to what a dedicate group of individuals in an indie company can do and that yes

A small group of individuals can make a game that, albeit early access with a few bugs here and there, can easily out perform a AAA company on release if given the right amount of appropriate representation BY it's player base, which they've rightfully earned through these three individuals and their dedication to their game.

If you're an honest Battlefield fan, and if I could show my PS3 and Xbox 360 play time for Battlefield 4 in this review to prove that I am, I'm expressing with actual honesty that this game is worth checking out. It may not hold up graphically wise, but I honestly couldn't give two cents less about graphics when the gameplay is so functionally there, it's undeniable to be a good time.

a AAA company can only beg and plead to produce a game like this, and with the developers focusing on LONG TERM funding over SHORT TERM funding, this is a game that has the potential to do what AAA companies want to dream about being able to do.

Actually make money off their titles.

I really like this game. I'd even say it has something really special going for it but the "Early Access" in its title is very appropriate. This game feels very unpolished at its current state and the 3 updates I've been around for have changed it some for the better and more for the not-so-good. I really think this is a case of the developers not truly knowing what they want to do with it however credit where credit is due it is a small team and they have potential. Take a chance with the game if you want but be warned it can be frustrating.

A big part is thanks to the lovely community and server staff - but the game is set up to be well moderated  and its very appreciated. You can feel the reactionaries try and suck out the fun and it to just pour back in once they're banned swiftly. The modern community features holding refined robloxian Bad Company gameplay is so peak and keeps pulling be back.

Originally had this as a positive review, but with the most recent updates the devs seem to be going out of their way to screw it up. What used to be pretty good sound in the game (proximity with footsteps, guns firing, bullets whizzing past, etc.) is now "everything sounds the exact same at a muffled volume regardless of proximity...EXCEPT for when you get shot, then you'll hear that gun go off at 200% volume the moment the bullet hits you".

Additionally, they keep changing the ping system, and the current iteration is the worst it's been. After a miss on their initial rework, they actually had it pretty good in one of the more recent patches (they re-added something close to the old ping system and also had a tracking ping that followed enemies for a few seconds). Now, they've made pinging pointless since everything obscures it, so your teammates can only see the ping when they can already see the pinged enemy.

It's a shame to see this game going downhill, because I assume these updates are all intended to make it better. Unfortunately, they keep sorely missing the mark.

Alright so it finished the dev hell that was it's release window and all i can say is. 

Not that good.

It tries to play off that it's the new battlefield/cod but not made by those stingy triple a devs that don't have our feeling at heart (Amen to that sentiment). But then it looks at what they did to keep player retention up and said you know what? Lets do that.

Let me start off with the pro's of this game

Large battles- They can be fun and hectic but i can often lose myself in them and lose the front line but i will address that later, for this point the big battles are fun.

And that is it for the pros, short list i know but i have good reason for not liking the rest of what this game offers.
Cons time, i know that it may seem hypocritical to place a pro and a con in that is the same but

Cons
Large player count- This has fostered some of the worse indifference to battle i have ever seen. Due to the sheer quantity of people i see most players insta gibbing themselves for a quicker respawn leading to the front line resembling a wet spaghetti noodle then a front line.
Battlefield has better front-lines in most regards. BFV you can see them all around basically and the movement options made it so once the front was established you need co-ordination to push through it.

COD though has some pretty bad front-lines in terms of movement. It's too hard to grasp what point is safe and what is teeming with enemy life. Either way both games have their ups and downs for that but i give cod some slack because 32v32 is actually pretty new for COD and with the gameplay they have, it makes sense that ground war isn't really ironed out

The problem with this game and the front lines is that the MOVEMENT is the biggest issue. We have too much speed. Heck the vehicles feel even worse. Why does a soldier in like 60-70 pounds of kit (More or less depending on class) run like usane bolt if he took a hit of meth and cocaine. Just insanity with that speed

With that speed everything is way too fast. Like Extremely too fast. Which brings me to my next CON

META guns- They exist everywhere but oh dear god do they exist here. If you thought this game could escape the inevitable of developing the "META" you were wrong as all heck and then some. Because the meta in this game appears to be a mix of "SMG,RPG,Some flavor of bolt action" 

I say flavor of bolt action because they are all pretty much the same.  SMG's your going to see either a p90 or kriss vector, and rpg's just because destruction mechanics are a thing so it's extremely common to see players just volley fire rockets into a structure to get enemies out of it because that is the effective strat.

Teamwork-The teamwork is non existent that is a problem due to both the movement speed and player counts. The player count contributes due to 127 v 127 who cares about one person in a push of 30 people. that is one small speck of dust basically compared to the bigger group.

Players rarely if ever talk tactically only in a casual sense. Nothing wrong with that it's just that i would like to hear about the enemy pushing my right and not how your mom just got her new sugar daddy and you got to eat pizza tonight

Lack of vehicle usability-So basically this stems from the "META" as it were. Due to so many players have AT enemy vehicles are basically cannon fodder waiting to die a painful death. The use of them being relegated to either, Anti air (helicopters can be annoying) or AP (Anti personnel) But in terms of AP your just sitting in a corner sniping hoping to get a kill or two. Nothing more nothing less. But if you try to support a push you can expect about 67 rockets flying right at you ready to detonate your tender rear.

Anyways thems my gripes don't know why everyone is praising this game like it's the second coming of battlefield 1. But you know what they say. Everything ends and i don't see enough good in this game to warrant most people coming back once they you know. Beat it. 

It lacks much in cosmetic fun (I know right but maybe i want to unlock some funky gun skins or something) The maps are kinda bland and generic and lack anything to help defenders or anything like that. The game pawns that off on us by using a terrible building system that uses Sandbags made out of plastic iv bags and hesco barriers made instead of sand wood and string. It's now made out of Sand Termite infested wood and a piece of rope that was hit by a sword for 30 minutes.

All the defense structures are so incredibly weak that they might as well just be used as decorations instead of defenses.

Anyways game is not that great in terms of trying to match triple a dev games. but you know, they wanted to look good to the people so they got some youtubers and did an ad campaign after a near death launch of them doing "playtests" (no joke it was getting pretty bad with those play test times)  and what we got was a game that feels soulless, has nothing that truly defines it (block game is taken by like three things can't define it self by that). All in all if i am being honest. It doesn't play like any of the three games it takes stuff from.

Okay rant over TLDR 
4/10 Nothing to define itself by and what it does have is too fast and aggressive for any meaningful gameplay. Oh and also you can bandage things that you reasonably shouldn't be able to but oh well "Arcade".

Edit 1:  As the gods fortold. This game fell off man. Maybe pick an identity and stick with it don't try to be every tactical game at once.

One hell of a game for such a small dev team. Its my number one "mindless shooter" game, and I have a great time sitting back and casually playing. My only real complaint is that there isn't much of a tutorial for all the game mechanics, and you just have to learn by slugging though a few matches as cannon fodder. If you play with friends, this part goes by much faster.

Most of the negative reviews are expecting AAA polish out of an indie studio, or they wish they were playing a different game (and hate this one because it isn't the game they're trying to play).

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

EDIT: New audio update is WAY better than on it's initial release, so this is now a positive review again.

On launch the gun and class balance were pretty wonky, but the devs have made steady and solid changes to address it, and each class feels a lot more meaningful and important to the overall match. Gunplay is really satisfying, they feel great to shoot, (used to) sound pretty good, and the level of customization allows you to really fine-tune the stats to fit your playstyle. Recon especially has felt really good lately with the addition of sniper bullet trails and smaller scope glint cones.

Progression is another highlight for me too, as--besides the supporter pack, which I do own--everything is included with the base game, and you get unlocks by just playing the game. Like a gun? Use it, get kills, and you'll unlock attachments and skins for it. Want to use a locked gun? Just play the game and level up, and you'll unlock the gun you want soon enough. Progression is pretty quick, even if you're not playing constantly, especially compared to how it was on release.

Maps were another things that started out on release as something pretty mid, but got better and better with every new map and map remake. They all feel fairly balanced and facilitate fun battles and the destructible structures allow for pretty unique situations to play out from match to match. 

Have to mention the voice chat as well, of course, as it really adds a level of comradery and humor to the game, and, if you have friends or willing teammates, lets you communicate pretty effectively and coordinate with those nearby. Muting people is quick and easy (a single button press) if anyone is mike spamming too much, blasting obnoxious music, or just being too annoying for your taste.

Overall, a good semi-casual game that still has a pretty high skill ceiling for those who are willing/able to devote the time to it.

After sinking my teeth into this game for a good bit. I feel like I can finally write about it.

First and foremost, is Battebit Remastered still worth playing months after launch? Absolutely.
I cannot describe how impactful it is for an indie game to able to have this much of a presence in an area dominated by AAA titles like multiplayer FPS as this. If you care about the quality of the games you play, as well as the respect you deserve as a consumer of said games, PLEASE, vote with your wallet and support Battlebit, even as a statement is good enough. There are a lot of things that are done right in this game that big studios can decide to do, but didn't. Battlebit is a cheap game in price and no way in its offering. It's definitely one of the must-play games of 2023, and you should not take that lightly.

With its focus on large-scale lobbies and providing a lot of tools for players to play around with, each match in Battlebit rarely feels the same. Vehicles and map destruction can provide a lot of dynamism in match progression and prevent stalemate. Even on more linear maps like Wakistan, flanks can still happen a lot, and the losing team can always maneuver around and take the lead. Or if you just want to goof around in an ATV and some C4's, there's nobody stopping you.

The highly praised feature of the VOIP and hot mic is also an undeniable charm of this game. Being able to verbally ask for ammo and scream out for medic, as well as directly speak to the enemies nearby are some things you can't do often in games nowadays. And it feels surprisingly more immersive than spamming voice line commands in any AAA games.

Battlebit's unwavering commitment to its ridiculously large lobby can also create issues, however. For instance, I can't expect myself to stay alive long enough to contribute much to the team like in Battlefield games. Mainly because the player count is so high that, frankly, I run out of bullets to kill all of the enemies in one spot. Which sucks, because in my heart I really want Battlebit to emphasize teamplay and contribution to match victory more than just personal K/D ratio.

But all and all, Battlebit Remastered is definitely worth the price in every conceivable way. The focus on the chaotic nature of online multiplayer lobbies is something we gamers sorely needs in an age where server browsers and community-focused atmospheres are rare, while matchmaking systems are handled by algorithms that make you feel like you're not good enough. Please support games such as Battlebit to tell other game companies that we want games to be fun again.

Let me start off by saying that if you want a chaotic shooter with low downtime and specific roles, the current version of Battle Bit Remastered fills that role well. Most people who buy this will get their money's worth out of it. However, there are some things which you should note before you buy this game:

-Devs listen primarily to a small portion of their playerbase on their Discord server. Obviously, this presents issues for the casual players, and results and a lot of less popular changes being pushed through (super visible sniper trails, poor sound changes, invasion mode changes, class loadout changes). In addition, they frequently hold change votes on their Discord, which negatively affects the entire playerbase who get represented by a couple hundred people at most.
-Balance. Most classes are balanced. Most. Support and Recon sit behind all the others in their usefulness, while Engineer and Medic sit at the top with their speed and utility. Assault sits in the middle, but isn't anything special.
-Sweats. For a Roblox looking game, you would be surprised at how many people abuse the crap out of movement to gain that edge over others.
-Voice chat. This one only became an issue today, but the sound changes have made the game frustrating. If you get shot, you get stuck inside a tin can, and if you die you get put inside a trash can with the lid closed. No more trash talk, friendly banter, or compliments to the guy who killed you. Hopefully this gets fixed soon, as otherwise voice chat is one of the best parts of this game, because you don't get restricted by anything.
-Prestiging. There is basically no point to prestiging in this game right now. The only real thing that you get is the ability to use (you still have to get enough kills to unlock) specific skins. And when you prestige, you lose access to all your guns, though fortunately not the attachments.

Edited 12/17/2023.  I don't think I can recommend this game anymore.  The dev has implemented many decisions that are objectively terrible and ruining the game.  Like all good battlefield-genre games I think its time has come to an end, albeit much sooner than others of that brand name. 

Here are some recommendations to the dev if you want to make this game a success again:

1) Stop remaking maps.  They're fine the way they were.  If you don't like them, make new ones and add them to the pool instead of replacing the good maps.  New Basra for example is now just a copy of many of the others (flat, no incentive to use navy vehicles, wide open with no choke points).

2) You should notice how the player-count dropped off when you started forcing every game to play Invasion mode because you force matches of that mode instead of letting people vote to play it.  The large drop off of Conquest, Domination, and Frontline matches directly coincides with the drop off of player count.  They're not playing your new mode that you want to promote so hard, they're leaving the game entirely.

3) Snipers were fine.  When you leave nerfing decisions to vote and no one of the five classes have a majority of players using it, every vote will result in majority wanting to nerf that class.  This will repeat until they're all terrible.

4) The new sound system is objectively terrible.  Everything sounds like it's at the bottom of a well.  Even stubbing your toe makes your player deaf.  Why doesn't your own gunfire effect your player's hearing?  Why do terrain-injuries affect they player's hearing?  Inconsistent, poorly thought out and executed, and not needed whatsoever.  This is one thing the AAA studios get right over this game, testing new patches on test servers first and thinking through if they're needed at all.

5) The new class system is just plain bad.  I get what you're going for, but this isn't the right way nor even the right game to need this.  You want the sweaties to embrace this new class system but don't realize this game is mostly a bunch of casuals just having fun.  This new system will be at best ignored by experienced players and scare off new players.

The game was great at the start but as the updates go on and tweaks are made, it strays further from what made the release date fun. While yes some tweaks needed to be made such as the leaning and nerfing of the SMGs (Still not enough) the META is still SMG spam and light armor for COD levels of movement, armor also means nothing in the face of SMG engagements, only countered by long range snipers.

And speaking of snipers, snipers got nerfed bad, adding in Battlefields notorious scope glint for 6x or higher and bullet trail meaning they'll get picked out fast by everyone unless you're way out there in the back. While more so the DMR's are safe and unaffected by these nerfs, forcing snipers into a playstyle they don't want to take part in.

Then there is the QOL, head bobbing while neat, is not for everyone, there needs to be a setting to turn this off for the users or server wide, like the flashbang effect being a blackened screen compared to a white screen.
Character customization needs to be more streamlined and expanded upon with a viability to actually having armor on vs having none. Especially for classes that you'd expect to be better armored, such as the support, assault, or engineer class having better bullet/ explosive protection.

BattleBit Remastered is pretty great, and that is completely because of how good it feels. The game makes sense and its easy to pick up even if your not getting a lot of kills, which new players wont LoL.  Thought the graphics couldn't claim to be anything but disappointing but still charming in their own way, the game-play makes up for it. It feels like any well done and complete FPS battlefield shooter. I do hope they will refine their pixel art to be a little more finite in detail specifically around plants. The fact that this was created by a 3-man team is incredible, bravo to them. 
My personal complaint is that I am Red/Green colorblind and there is no good way to help me identify the enemy. I have played with the settings currently available making enemy triangles bigger but its still not enough. I definitely feel I am at a disadvantage because of this. There is also the issue with tick-rate, or refresh-rate, call it whatever you want, but that is a FPS issue and no one has fixed this to the satisfaction of the end-users. It's still extremely frustrating when I am using the Kriss Vector (Fastest Fire-rate) sub-machine gun and I hit the enemy first yet they still win the fight somehow? That infuriates me and makes me want to log out.

They nerfed the damage of pretty much every weapon to the point where nothing one shot headshots anymore, even most DMRs and sniper rifles, the true Battlefield experience.

tl;dr 5/10 early beta/alpha was an ez 9/10 if not 10/10 game, sad to see it be this way.

I have played the game enough to have a fair idea about it. It is an okay game, but unfortunately, it is not a battlefield-like game as advertised, at least from the conquest gamemode standpoint. People take a couple of direct 30 mm shots to die, and if it is not direct, then forget about it. The tank's main cannon, or coax hardly kills anything. Now I know that it is a game, so it doesn't have to be realistic, but it is so bullshit that it is gene-altering. There is a chance my future child is going to hate me for playing this game and tell me, "Dada, why yoo do dis to me?" if he/she/it can be called a human at this point. I am scarred forever, and my only wish is that mutations are somatic instead of germinal, so at least my kids will be free from the consequences. Vehicle physics makes you think it is some sort of parody of Battlefield. Unfortunately, I am unable to jump on the bandwagon and recommend it like everyone else, as I see that even the bandwagon is suffering from the physics of this game. I cannot recommend a game with this kind of vehicular gameplay, as your shots barely do any damage to the infantry. Your muzzle velocity and accuracy are so bad and random that it's laughable that you are driving a modern vehicle, not to mention the RNG that comes with it. Since I bought the game expecting at least "okay" vehicle gameplay, I am beyond disappointed, as I could have improved vehicle physics just by opening CMD and bashing my pen*s against the keyboard. It feels like shooting cotton balls at the enemy and driving bumper cars, and it is one of the worst of its kind I have ever seen. Even Unreal Tournament 2004 had better vehicle physics, and that game is now almost 20 years old. Hell even Big Rigs: Over the Road Racing was ahead of its time compared to this. It is only somewhat good if I am going to ignore vehicles, but even then, if you are wishing to play a game with no vehicles, I would recommend CS2, R6...

I like about 80% of this game but the other 20% is just Frustrating and im talking about the sniper class/Recon and sniper rifles and DMR. Now i would like to say i understand how Hard it is to balance Sniper in games like this i know you don't want everyone choosing the Sniper class and every one and the mother trying to oneshot kill from across the map ive played games where that is a prevalent issue but when it come to sniping mechanics of the game its now WORSE then every FPS out there, you now have 4 Means of detecting Sniper rending the class practically useless. 1st you got the noise, this game has Great audio and clearly hear the direction of foot steps and shots being fired and i understand this mechanic but you had to go out of you way to increase the noise detection up to 2000+ M for sniper rifles. now i would understand this if this was for specific rifles but there are some sniper rifles that use the same rounds as Assault Rifles and LMGs but they are not magically louder. 2nd you have Hit detection i have no complaints with this one i understand fully why this is in the game. 3rd you have the Glint Which makes NO FREAKING SENSE and for this one ill just link this Article https://armament.com/articles/glint-in-military-history/#:~:text=ARDs%20use%20a%20unique%20geometry,without%20depending%20upon%20individual%20action. Now im gland you reduce the Glint view to those only in your scope sight line when your sighted in i would be happier if it was removed all together but at least your on par with COD and BF. BUT ALL OF THAT WORK THE FIX THE GLINT IN THE GAME FROM SCOPES IS NEGATED WITH THE 4th ISSUE, FREAKING BULLET TRAILS WTF. i though the glint in the beginning of this game was bad but you had to be kind of paying attention to look out for Sniper BUT NOW ITS ALL GONE. any 5 yearold can follow a line its taught in most elementary schools. there is no point any more using the Sniper class any more unless you play it like COD or BF Run and gun and go for those quick scopes. theres no point in trying to be a overwatch sniper covering you squad as the cap a point or set a bomb or defend a target. there no point in sneaking behind enemy lines and take out player that are bottle necking a area of the map because as soon as you fire EVERY KNOW WHERE YOU ARE WITH THE BULLET TRAIL. Now i am not saying the developers are shit they are fantastic and they have made a wonderful blend of arcade shooter/milsim but i think the the sniper class and sniper class in any game has to go in one of 2 ways either Arcade style of sniping or Milsim Sniping there is no in between, you either make all the other classes happy and make Sniper lives hell or you make snipers happy and all other classes suffer the pain of good snipers, and i do think that once you make this decision the game will improve because it will become a core mechanic. People will have to Improvise, adapt, and overcome and formulate strategy on how to deal or use snipers going forward into the future of the game no more back and forth of making sniper good bad good bad good bad because it annoying. but all this beside sniping you should get the game for every thing else

127 hours of being frustrated and trying hard to have fun with the game, but ultimately failing. TL;DR: It's decent when it works, but it often doesn't. Extremely poor hit-reg, map design is all over the place with poor combat legibility and flow, easily camped spawn points on near every map, poorly placed spawns and spawn mechanics overall, poor weapon and attachment balance, poorly thought out progression, poorly thought out mil-sim mechanics that make the game incredibly clunky, super low TTK with no room for skill expression, doesn't make good on its promise of destructible environments, and a poorly functioning anti-cheat that barely works

The Good:
-It's fun when you actually get to have fun. It plays exactly like Battlefield, and that experience is something I dearly missed, but I'm not finding it here consistently contrary to what others claim. 

Drags down the experience: (all taken from 32v32 non-vehicle modes, all servers played on less than 35 ping):
-There's no tutorial. If you wanted any explanation of anything, you'll figure it out after you die. 
-Advertises destructible environments and levolution, and half-heartedly delivers. Not every building is fully destructible, but all the stairs are, so you'll constantly fight enemies that'll hold a building, blow up the stairs to prevent anyone from flanking or killing them, and they'll sit there having an uncontestable advantage for the rest of the game.
-No spawn protection when spawning on an ally who isn't in a "safe" zone. Did you want to wait five seconds before spawning on an ally right before he gets shot and killed, only for you to immediately die as well to wait another five seconds? Sounds fun right? Better get used to it. Additionally a LOT of maps have spawns that simply have no protection for you. You'll spawn in, and within 5 seconds of exiting "spawn" you can get shot and killed because the enemy has a clear sight line to where you exit from. 
-Spawning in general needs work. The actual spawn areas for all the maps and modes are placed seemingly at random, seemingly without understanding where the objective is, how players can get to it, or what natural advantageous terrain is around that can be used by both teams. A lot of maps on Rush will spawn you in the middle of nowhere, or in an open area with no cover right in the line of fire of the enemy, leading you to die frequently, constantly, and frustratingly. Additionally the spawn mechanic itself will frequently bug out, and just drop you wherever it feels like, rather than the spawn you clicked, or the teammate you clicked. 
-Having allies block your line of sight cause they're sitting right on top of you is annoying as hell. Gotta figure out how to fade people out while you're ADSing when they're too close to you. 
-Maps vary wildly between having way too much playable area, leading to you constantly dying to someone 200 meters away with a sniper rifle that no one can contest because there's only one way up and it's a ladder that someone else is watching, or too restrictive with its own playable area, leading to having only one way to assault an objective that everyone spams with explosives. Especially on Rush, the playable zone will often always have areas that aren't part of the enemy spawn, but you can't get to it because it's restricted, while said area has enemies in it that shoot at the rest of the map without repercussion. Or it'll be the flipside, where the enemy will push right up to your spawn zone and shoot you as you're coming out, and there's nothing you can do about it. 
-Speaking of, explosive spam is a thing, no matter the map or mode. 
-Tries way too hard to be "mil-sim" but fundamentally lacks any of the realism or decent implementation in order to be mil-sim, leaving all of the implemented features to feel clunky, and out of place. Bleeding is a poorly done mechanic that simply serves to screw you out of an engagement, or become an immediate death sentence by forcing you to cower in cover and wait to bandage yourself and then heal IF you're playing the Medic class. There's no health regeneration. Armor serves no purpose at all other than to be frustrating to play against, because you will shoot someone directly in the face with your red-dot planted perfectly on their nostrils, and the game will tell you you hit their armor. You will be cheated out of multiple kills, constantly, frequently, frustratingly, because the game says you hit their armor and did nothing else at all. The game plays best as a blocky arcade reboot of a Battlefield-esque type shooter, and all these added mechanics do nothing for the game and its strengths, and simply drag it down. 
-Hit-reg is very poor at all stages of the game. Again, you will lose fights because the game cannot keep up. This will happen constantly, frequently, and frustratingly. Nothing's more frustrating than shooting someone in the back, only for them to whip around and kill you because the rest of your mag disappeared. If you haven't noticed it, it's cause you're choosing not to look. 
-A lot of people are cheating. It's not super blatant like a 360 spinning one tap monster, but when you've played around 4000 hours of Battlefield, it's pretty obvious. A lot of people are toggling walling to watch for flanks, to prefire, or to line up instant headshots to win fights. There's a very clear difference between people who are actually good at the game (who you will encounter a lot, and it'll feel like they're cheating at first, but they're not.), and people who are actually cheating. It's very clear the EAC isn't working well, and hopefully overtime their anti-cheat gets better.
-SMGs dominate every stage of the game, because they're the best at practically all ranges. Add onto that using one increases your move speed, and you're constantly left in situations where the other guy simply jerks their mouse around while reloading to look like Neo from the Matrix before they flip around and kill you. It just gets old after a while. Its frustrating to play against because there's literally nothing you can do except have perfect tracking, but even then it won't work because of the hit-reg and depending on your weapon, slow bullet velocity. 
-Audio doesn't work, everything is just LOUD. Footstep audio is sometimes helpful, and other times very unhelpful. It's hard to distinguish where the enemy is, whether they're above or below or beyond a wall, etc. etc. vs. what's a friendly footstep, and it's not really well done.
-Kill-cam is completely worthless. Instead of giving you any information at all, it just zooms in on your legs. Battlefield 3 came out 12 years ago, and it actually gave you useful information with its kill cam. Zooming in on my dead legs is worthless. 
-Progression is still slow and awful. Now you level up faster, which is a nice added boon, but because the attachments are still given to you based on kills with a gun, rather than maybe points you can use like in Planetside, it leads to everyone sticking to the starter weapons because why would you bust out some new gun that might not even work at the 280 kill mark, when the M4 has ALWAYS worked? 
-Weapon and attachment balance are incredibly poor. Starter guns are too strong with their near 0 recoil and fast fire-rates, while later weapons often make you choose strengths vs. weaknesses without actually giving you a significant enough strength to make up for said weaknesses. Weapon attachment choice is 100% meaningless, because none of the options significantly impact a weapon outside of Vertical Grips and Tactical barrels. It's really hard to justify using anything other than a Vertical Grip, with its -0.20+ vertical recoil, when every other option either INCREASES your overall recoil (why?) or give you paltry -0.05 changes. 
-TTK is too fast and you will often simply just die within a split second without being able to meaningfully retaliate, and it just gets stale when you have to wait to respawn as well.
