I might be getting off the train.  I am just not having much fun anymore. 

It's not one thing, but a consistent stream of decisions and foundations that have become too much for me to enjoy what can be a really great experience.,  And the works and mentality of the devs should be something praised for trying to replicate the experience of older BF titles and FPS experiences without resorting to microtransactions and other features of modern gaming, save one. 

But I can't get over the graphics, they look awful.  I grew up on the SNES, you can make low poly game look good, and this is not that.  Everything looks drab and blend into each other, simply ugly brown or yellow to look at.  But worse than that everything you need from your eyes to play is handicapped from the how the game looks.  Friend/foe identification, whether the opponent is dead or prone, and depth perception make acquisition in this game a chore, and putting glow sticks on people's heads do not fix that.

As soon as I played this game, i knew the movement meta was going to be trouble. Leaning, going to prone, and strafing simply do not slow down the player or adversely affect aiming nearly enough, As soon as veterans picked up on the meta, this game does not look much different than the twitchiest COD shooter, and I hate it.  Those not able to keep up are reduced to camping, so now you can't move or be beamed by snipers only to be smashed by twitchers if you push in.

This game does have one problem of modern gaming, the live service/early access model.  But not in the same way as season passes or gimmicks, but that weird decision making that flips the meta and ideas are there.  
Now I was at first optimistic that maps I did not like were getting reworks, I felt I was being heard.  But I have found every reworked map to be worse than the previous, full of clutter and confusing pathing that made traversal and flanking a nightmare, at least for me.  Just as I feel comfortable with a map, it is gone.
I love the idea of changing less used guns and equipment before adding new ones, but I feel rather than making every gun and playstyle fun to play, it feels like a complete reset of my brain, too much to learn and adjust to, and to save time I resort to use just one method of play or just folllow the meta and not bother with the rest.  This hurts when that one playstyle is drastically affected by the update, causing yet more frustration.  
But the updates change so much so fast. Pinging goes from fine in one update to gone in another to overpowered in the next, same with sniping, DMR's, explosives, bandages, medics, assault class, and I'm like Stop!  Let me and the community adjust to one and grow and make small changes and test things before you wildly change the meta, I can't keep up.

I could say more (vehicles?!?, game pop, cheating/banning) but I have bashed enough,  and even the end I still have much respect for the devs refusal to go the way of EA and Activision, but these things are too much for me right now.  Maybe I will change the review later...

Fantastic game especially for the price.

The Good:
-Good gun play
-Decent sounds
-Huge lobbies
-Destruction
-Local VOIP which makes some situations so much funnier

To improve:
-Quick join will sometimes stick you in a lobby with a queue of 80 people and you are either stuck waiting forever to load or ALT F4. Quick join should either not put you into a queue (ideally) or give you an option to back out of it.
-No way to edit loadouts or view gun stats in the home menu without going to gun range or in game.
-No description of game mode, some game modes are not clear and there's no easy way to see a description of the game mode (Would be good to place on the ESC screen)
-Would like to see small XP rewards for unlocking attachments on guns to help promote trying different guns and leveling them.
-No way to view stats of friends, would also be interesting to see challenges pop up between friends, maybe a weekly thing of who can get the furthest headshot, or most revives in a game, something for fun competition between friends weekly.

A wonderful love letter to the battle field franchise.

Battlebit is game made by a small team of devs who were inspired by EA's battlefield series, and not only does it succeed in being a spiritual successor in light of battlefield's incredibly shaky recent history, it might even be superior in many ways.

If the graphics don't deter you, then what you have here is an incredibly tight, well made shooter with tons of content. Battlebit boasts around 20 maps, has tons of different guns with various attachments you can apply to your heart's content, along with character customization, gadgets all spread across 5 different classes.
Every class has a solid purpose in the game, from healing, scouting, destruction, ammo supply etc. and every weapon despite the simple graphics is modeled and detailed excellently. 

The community is pretty entertaining, often screaming for help when on the ground incapacitated, cracking jokes and doing light roleplay. Sweats are usually rare, typically ignored and you don't even really have to have a mic to effectively play the game. Due to the large scale battles you can play at your own pace without people getting frustrated at you, battles are typically incredibly chaotic.

My only gripes are the lack of shotguns, no planned jets or other vehicles really aside from ground vehicles, helicopters and boats.  Lastly the progression takes a LONG time, once you have a gun you like expect to spend a good 5-10 hours unlocking everything for it. Hundreds of kills are needed to unlock scopes, barrels, stocks, and other attachments for any given weapon and some weapons absolutely SUCK without proper attachments.

9.5/10 game is honestly a breath of fresh air and most of the negative reviews recently are botted due to there being a free weekend for the game. Enjoy it and don't worry about your KD too much initially unless you are playing smaller lobbies I guess.

The sound spread of all snipers has been increased to 2000 meters.
Sniper rifles now leave a bullet trail that lasts for 3 seconds.
The sound of a sniper's bullet whizzing past is now distinct from other weapons.
The glint angle of sniper's long-range scopes has been heavily reduced.

I love the new mechanics for the sniper. The fact that the bullet has a different sound than a normal assault rifle allows you to realize when a sniper has you in his sights. I also like that snipers leave a trail when they shoot since it It gives the enemy a way to locate you without revealing your exact position at every moment, making you have to change position to stay hidden. The fact that snipers are now making more noise finally gives meaning to using a silencer. They just need to eliminate the glint or lower it to the minimum. so that the sniper class is fun to use without being op. If they finally do it the game would have at least 2 Classes to play with because the only one that works the way it has to work at this moment is the assault one. Don't get me started on the support class xd....


...I'll try to play again and see if the update really improves anything. Or if playing sniper is still so ridiculously frustrating and pointless....

I cant recommend this game simply because of the devs. The game at its core is really fun, even better with friends. Plus you can give yourself a battlefield bad company color scheme! so id be lying if i said i wasnt having fun and the game wasnt good. However, the devs are their own worst enemy at this point. Im aware the team is just 3 guys who came together to make this game. But seriously, when a large amount of the community says they dont like something, the devs double down and ignore then complaints. The biggest issues at the time of writing this are snipers, instead of actually balancing the class they choose to try and make the class as unappealing as humanly possible. within the span of a couple months snipers have received around 4 major nerfs. Making them practically useless, one of those nerfs was, get this, nerfing snipers for staying in the back line. Yknow, the literal only thing snipers excel at??? and that seems to be a pattern, instead of actually balancing things. the devs try to strangle playstyles to force players into another role. It happened with medic, before medic was the only class to heal others. They were invaluable to the team, they could revive faster, and heal others. As the time went by however, theres not really a reason to play medic besides faster revive times. All classes can heal themselves, all can revive, only thing missing is seeing bleeding teammates. And now theyre doing it with sniper. strangling the class to try and force a playstyle instead of giving us that agency to choose. And beleive me, this is just the tip of it, i can write a novel about how the devs have ruined the playstyles or ruined things in this game.

Now another issue ive seen, is the 3D pinging system. We went from static pinging to a 3D system, and normally that would be a  nice change. But the way they did it is just atrocious, not to mention, last i played you couldnt ping while aiming down sights. if you saw someone you wanted to mark, youd have to stop aiming, open the clunky ping menu, and then ping the person. and honest to god, ive seen fat mexican kids run faster than this pinging system in HS. and brother was 300 pounds. On top of that, this ties into what i was talking about before. The devs being their own worst enemy. You see, they cant make up their minds for the world. for example, sniper, in the midst of all those major and heavy hitting nerfs, they buffed a single aspect of sniper. and thats the ping. it lasts a little bit longer than other classes. Keep in mind, this was the same update they removed pinging while ADS. So you cant watch a group of enemies with your scope and ping them (youd be spotted by the braindead glint system) like you could before. Instead if you see a group in the distance that you wanted to mark, youd have to stop aiming, open the menu (you cant move the menu mind you, youre stuck looking at a single point) and hope that you were both, on someone when you selected ping, and that the enemies didnt run past your focal point. Again, they say one thing and do another.  

As it stands, i really cant recommend this game. not until the devs make up their minds, start listening to feedback, and quit forcing playstyles for no real reason. If it werent for the devs screwing up over every little thing, then the game would literally be perfect. But we arent in a perfect world sadly

I like playing as a sniper. Every patch the devs seem to add increasingly stupid ways to make sniper rifles worse. For a while, glint coming off your scope whenever you were looking down it was like a bright sun to other players. Latest patch makes that glint be visible in a smaller cone, so that's a slight buff. The trade off? Now your bullets leave a stupidly obvious trail that immediately gives away your position anyway every time you take a shot, as if your sniper bullets were goddamn jet propelled. The change to glint is pointless when now people don't even need to turn around to see your glint, they just look at the smoke trail that only snipers produce and can immediately start moving erratically or get to cover.

You took your time getting into position to cover a point for your teammates, so enemies attempting to take it or defend it have a harder time? Too bad, now if you take a single shot everyone around the area will know where your shot came from so they can avoid you and you have to reposition all over again. After killing just 1 out of 127 players on the enemy team. Unless they're stupid of course and do nothing about it, but balancing around people who can't handle getting one-shot because they were standing still or moving predictably in the open is never a good idea. Sniper has plenty of counter play but I guess the devs got bullied back in high school by sniper players.

The game is otherwise pretty good. But I'll come back to it when the devs actually know how to properly balance a sniper without making it a chore to play. I wouldn't be surprised if the devs add a permanent 3d spot on Recon players so they are constantly visible to enemies at all times the way things have been going.

A $15 game that is more Battlefield than what Battlefield has been for the past for years.
    • Classes and team identity? Check
    • Good selection of vehicles, weapons, loadouts and tools? Check
    • Big open maps? Check

Plain and simple: I love it. It is a mixture of BF2 and BF3, but with added gameplay mechanic to it that make it pretty fun to play. For example, the proximity chat is useful and sometimes hillarious. The destruction is a major plus, especially since I run as an Engie. I love destroying peeps hiding behind walls, destroying cover with RPGs and C4. The gunplay is pretty good too with DMGs, ARs, Carbiines, DMRs with many attachments that add to the progression. Love the grappling hook system similar to what BF2had, it should have been like that in 2042. It has a Server Browser in which I use every time I play. Like you said, doesn't take too much effort to run the game, so it's easy on my CPU and GPU.

It's still not perfect.
CONS: I dislike that they allow adding C4 and Mines on Drones to get 4-5 multi kills. Also Suicide C4 vests is wow, why devs?, thankfully I hardly get killed by that cheese. Not a fan of having so many modes, I just stick to Domination and Conquest and its variations. While I like the self-heal with bandages mechanic, I don't like fact how easy you can bleed which in turn slows down the fight for non-medic classes. Maybe reduce that a bit, another thing is sniper spam sometimes, but learning the map helps avoid them.

Compared to BF?..So I've had too many hours in BF4, BC2, BF3 servers are dead. BF1 gunplay has weird and casual mechanics and no way I'm going back to BFV; much less with BF2042. All in all, it's the best shooter out there for me right now.

It's like Battlefield 4, Squad, and Insurgency had a beautiful baby. Seriously addicting game. It has so many nice quality of life features that show the developers have actually played video games in their lives before. Lots of little things that just feel so nice to have. Super refreshing.

I like the destructible environments, the large servers, vehicle variety. 

BUT this game commits my largest pet peeve as an MG player: the light machine guns do just as much damage as an smg, some smgs do more!! Coming from Hell let loose, squad, where machine gun classes are actually dangerous, this game infuriates me on that. It gives NOBODY incentive to play that class or role. The common argument is "yeah well big magazines make them more dangerous". It doesn't matter if it has the same TTK as an SMG, MGs are meant to be used to wipe out groups, and this is impossible when they have the longest TTK in the game. This makes this game just another game where the weapon choice is either: sniper, or really fast smg dude, nothing else actually matters, and it shows if you spectate a game.

The game has no sense of teamwork beyond medics, anyone could easily solo a group of they have an smg. It brings the best of battlefield to the table and I love that. But it also brings my least favorite aspect of COD and BF too.

If it was not for that, I would have given a thumbs up.

I definitely have problems with the game. Some major, some minor. Let me go over all of them:

- Maps are a mixed bag of really bad, ok and kind of good. This is more opinionated but I really do not like most maps. Would like to see more city, tropic themed or inhabited beach-side towns. Too much washed out/autumn aesthetics.

- Game modes are just average. It's constantly domination, conquest, frontline (kind of), invasion (cause it's new) and never ctf and stuff. Part of it is the community, the other part is the modes being just typical fps modes. Doubt there is a way to fix this but it does get boring after awhile.

- At a certain range, environment objects like grass and shrubbery do not render at all. This means players with far sights like snipers will see you and kill you. Sure snipers contribute practically nothing, but they are a massive nuisance and kill the vibe. The nerfs to snipers did not affect the rifles, so most people switch to those instead. So long-range/snipers are still a pain to deal with.

- Bullet drop is barely a problem. Most weapons can kill you from a far distance which does at times feel bs. Getting killed by a sub-machine gun from sniper range makes sniping a pain so it sort of balances out the previous point.

- There are hackers but they aren't as bad compared to other fps games. Still the anti-cheat system needs improvement.
Like a few hours into a game I saw a ban wave of like 20 players banned for cheating. That does not bode well for the game.

- Abuse of the report system. Someone can decide to report you even if you did not do anything. This means a group of people can basically kick you or ban for no reason.

- A fair bit of toxicity. Some of it's trolls, and others are just pricks. This is both from chat and voice chat. It ain't as bad as other fps games, but would not be surprised if it did eventually reach the same level.

- Voice chat. It can be hilarious at times and enjoyable, other times it's just mic spam of music, really loud toxic yelling, etc. Not much of a way to fix this problem, just going to have to live with it.

- Can't change loadouts outside of a match. You have to be in-game to change anything.

- The same matches over and over again. Same maps, same game modes, cause people want those. Wouldn't be so bad if it worked like other games with custom matches or something. Like servers dedicated to gamemodes or even to a single map (TF2 for example). For now the match finder system is not that great.

- Vehicles are paper-thin. Sure it's realistic but I rarely see any ground based vehicles survive for long. This is at least a problem on 64v64 or 127v127. At least vehicles like the jeep respawn quickly.

- Currently drones are very broken with the fact that someone can just send out a drone and mark the entire enemy team (a bit exaggerated but point still stands). 

None of these by themselves are alone major problems but it does add up when put all together. It's still very fun, but expect some sour moments.

I take back my previous negative review. The devs to this game have gone above and beyond to improve the player experience and they listen to feedback critically to ensure they patch the bugs and make the game fun for all. I regret my tirade I had put on this game towards the beginning of its life.

For some reason keep coming back to this game though I shouldn't, but i need to set aside the want for this game to be great and write a review. It's great for about 5 minutes if you are lucky. Most every engagement involves you dying in one shot across the map by anything but a sniper rifle. Armor is meaningless as you soot someone and it appears to work for them. However when you are shot at it acts like paper and you along with your entire squad die wondering how. The weapons in this game are to far from being considered as balanced. Every engagement you have that is in your favor the person you are shooting at 180's you and head shots you after you've fired an entire mag into them, and you being left there to be confused how they did not die. I love the amount of involvement the devs have but the game is not in the right state, I had the most fun during the play tests, but as soon as the game became readily available to more players. I've sen such an increase in players with impossible movement, reaction time, aim bot accuracy, invincibility, spawn traps, and game breaking bugs. The game has just been increasingly impossible to play. I want to see this game succeed but in the state that it's in now and has been since early access launch. This game is sadly becoming just another broken Battlefield wannabe title.

Not gonna say this is a bad game, just not for me. At it's best this game is fun. A symphony of chaos as two huge teams duke it out, RPGs flying, buildings being blown apart, while a radio tower collapses in the distance.

The game is rarely like this. 98% of the time it's basically playing hardcore COD on a big map. TTKs are extremely low so most fights decided by who saw the other first. Select weapons like the UMP, Vector, M4A1 that can be modded to not recoil like a wild mule vastly outclass the numerous that do. You'll quickly notice that about half the population is running around with the same ~5 weapons because guns that land their bullets will always outclass ones that don't no matter how the DPS or whatever other 'mathematical balance' pencils out on paper. Snipers take you out from a km away, at least you can try to spot and ping them for your team to ignore and it doesn't seem like they contribute much to the match, still infuriating. Bunch of maps but the community picks the same 5 over and over. Occasionally the comms are hilarious, but usually it's someone yelling into the cheapest microphone imaginable, preventing you from hearing the footsteps of the enemy soldiers running in the back door of the building you're occupying.

Still more fun than any Battlefield I've played in the past 15 years. If you like the type of game and can just accept that random bullets from someone 300 yards away are going to by fluke chance embed themselves in your skull, or you're going to step on a landmine in a bush that you had no way of seeing, or someone's going to walk up behind you and kill you before you can even turn 180 degrees, a lot, you'll probably enjoy it. But it's not for me.

This game was friggin AWESOME for the first couple of months. But, as happens with everything else, the devs listened to the community, and now it just sucks, particularly if you played from release day. They added community servers, which largely scattered the player population, as well as made "improvements" to the server selection screen, which is essentially pointless now, because say you wanted to hit refresh until you saw the map/gamemode you wanted, it won't happen. The function is still there, but with the way servers are set up now, your Night River match (or whatever you were in the mood for) ain't coming. 

All of it is basically off-putting when combined with changes to the weapon system. Vector needed nerfed a little bit (just because too many people were using it) but beyond that things could have been left largely alone. It was a game of low-poly graphics and comical gameplay, and as soon as the BF players showed up and started demanding stuff, that aspect of it was gone. Save your money. It WAS worth it.

I'm just going to back to single player games exclusively. Anything multiplayer is subject to the same flaw, which is over-development as a result of pressure from (what is usually) the loudest minority.  Because gamers think they know what they want, until they get it, or what they want is poorly implemented, but the community is usually the party responsible for destroying the things we claim to love. So screw you fellow gamers. There's Baldur's Gate 3 and soon enough, Starfield. And then an election which we're unlikely to survive. You can't even vote in correct game changes...I have no faith in you to elect stable leadership :P

I have been playing FPS shooters ever since the first Call of Duty launched at the turn of this century. I never liked that kind of gameplay, preferring games that require team tactics and objectives. Also, I always went for games with the most realistic graphics, which is why I played a LOT of Red Orchestra 2 and its sequals, Hell Let Loose, Insurgency Sandstorm, etc. due to realistic weapon mechanics.

When I saw this game, the graphics looked like some kid game called "Roblox", but I heard it was fun. So I got a copy for my son and I to try out.

It is, without overstating, the most fun I've had playing shooter games in a LONG time. I think the lower level of graphics helps with the massive servers of 250+ players on at once, with fully destructible building and OH SO MUCH CHAOS.

It's not realistic. It's not some military simulation. It's an amazingly fun game to play for the fun of playing.

Just buy it. No regrets!

[h1]Battle Bit Remastered: From Battlefield Roots to Skinner-Box Shift[/h1]
I can only conclude Battle Bit Remaster's (BBR) title as a "runaway success" is what has compelled the developers to persistently employ a heavy hand in "rebalancing" the game. The transformation of BBR into a [u]"live-service game"[/u] due to these changes is the primary reason I cannot recommend it.

It is evident that BBR initially launched as a nearly finished product, drawing significant inspiration from the Battlefield series. It offered a refreshing, low-render take on solid gameplay mechanics that accommodated a wide range of playstyles. However, as the game approaches its 1.0 release, [u]the updates have aggressively extended past the publishers roadmap[/u] and have become sweepingly [b]balance-breaking, meta-shifting, playstyle-killing, gameplay focused changes.[/b]

The developers have shown a lack of sympathy when implementing changes that isolate playstyles not aligned with their current vision of BBR. These changes in no way resolve the more substantial issues the game is currently experiencing, such as the unstable and janky vehicle platform that has been ongoing since launch.

What these updates have accomplished is limited and narrowed the range of gameplay options, [u]promoting a Skinner-box gameplay model.[/u] This involves removing gameplay options that could hinder the reward seeking behavior designed to keep players constantly engaged, alienating those who purchased the game for the liberties its Battlefield-like roots originally offered.

These changes lead me to believe that the developers have shifted away from their initial Battlefield inspiration. Instead, it seems they are now focused on [u]creating a game space that maximizes cheaply retaining players attention and opening opportunities for monetization.[/u] This shift is evident in their recent "deal" and in-game advertisements featuring the United States Air Force. 

Irrespective of your preferred play style, the updates this game has experienced have been so drastic that it no longer resembles the game I initially purchased. [u]Updates since launch have gradually undermined various playstyles, rendering them virtually unapproachable.[/u]The developers have proven themselves very capable at launching a title, but they are [b]objectively deficient at understanding a live environment, incremental change, and multiplayer balance at a fundamental level.[/b]
